editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

lg.l: CAe≈øar, who≈øe brain contriv'd at once the fate
Of his great ≈øelf and of the Romane State,
With mightie action caus'd, where-ere he ≈øtood,
The trembling place to ≈øweat forth humane bloud.
Who tam'd rebellion ≈øo, as in that ≈øinne
His own contrivance had the traitour bin.
How nimble-ear'd! and with what piercing ≈øight
He could di≈øcern advantage! and then fight.
Cold, waves, winds, hunger, watching, labour, warre
Were accidents through which he oft did dare.
How patient for his ends! How quickly he
Unthought of could defeat his enemy!
Who≈øe expedition, as an engine hurl'd
Him from one ≈øide to th'other of the world;
Who≈øe way of victory begot the fame,
That he but went, and ≈øaw, and overcame.
Dark ≈øtratageme, quick action, and the all
Of him built up a mighty Generall.
And to make wonder gaze more, he could be
Th' Hi≈øtoriographer and th' Hi≈øtorie:
As if his mightie acts to vanqui≈øh men
Had been on purpo≈øe done to trie his pen.
Oblivion ≈øo threw du≈øt upon what he
Mo≈øt fairly wrote unto po≈øteritie.
And thou, brave man at arms, great Roan, ha≈øt tane
His lively portraict out of Mars his fane,
And arm'd thy ≈øelf by him: yea, ≈øhown to all,
Thou knew'≈øt to write, and be a Generall.
See with what art the Chymi≈øt deals, and how
Spirits from bodies he extracts, ≈øo thou.
How ≈ømart he gives his ≈øtratagemes, and where
Their hidden vertue lies he makes appeare!
Mark with how curious hand he tho≈øe doth trie
And fit unto our times, and ≈øo apply.
The Grecian tacticks Ce≈øar brought to Rome,
And this brave Duke to us, as from their tombe.
What weapons and what forms may fit again
He well revives which ≈øeem'd before but vain.
If e'r Pythagoras were right to hold
A tran≈ømigration, he doth it unfold.
But view his own directions, quick and wi≈øe;
He makes towns ≈øtrong, but ≈øtrangely doth ≈øurpri≈øe:
He rouzeth lazie minds, and ≈øeems to write
Men into field, and teach them how to fight.
Mirrour of manhood, that art here, though gone;
Then Vertues ≈øelf a better tombe there's none.
And Thou, my Friend, that freely do≈øt di≈øcover
So rich a jewel, and ha≈øt brought it over,
Merit'≈øt no mean applau≈øe. Me thinks, I ≈øee
Each noble mind admire thy indu≈øtrie,
And cheri≈øh thy rare worth; ≈øince few there are
That for the publick undergo ≈øuch care.
Mount ≈øtill in thy endeavours, and ≈øhine bright:
His glorie's great that lends to others light.

A Great book is a great mi≈øchief (as it is in the Greek Adagie) and therefore it was well ≈øaid of Seneca, Magni artificis e≈øt clau≈øi≈ø≈øe multum in exiguo. Such an Arti≈øt the late great Generall the Duke of Rohan hath here proved him≈øelf, in his excellent abbridgement of Ce≈øars warres, with his own ob≈øervations upon them; and his Militia of the Greeks and Romanes. His work is like fruits which are dried in the ≈øunne; contracted
to a ≈ømall bulk, but full of ≈øub≈øtance and virtue. The tran≈øcendency thereof moved me to communicate it to our Nation in the≈øe times of action. May it plea≈øe you to afford it your Patronage, and to accept it as a te≈øtimonie of all due re≈øpects from

div.head: The complete Captain, OR An Abbridgement of Ce≈øars warres. The I. Book.
div.p:
CESAR having the government of the Gauls for the ≈øpace of five years, the fir≈øt war that he made there was again≈øt the Sui≈ø≈øes, Helvetii. cau≈øed by the ambition of Orgetorix, who was a rich, noble and powerfull man in that Nation: He per≈øwaded this people (which were hardy by nature, and exerci≈øed in arms by the warres which they had with their neighbours) to inlarge them≈øelves into Gallia, a countrey more ≈øpacious and better then their own. For this effect (re≈øolution being taken) they take three years ≈øpace to make their preparations: In which time they furni≈øh them≈øelves with waggons and hor≈øes of burden, taking order that all their countrey be imployed to all ≈øorts of grain to make their provi≈øion of victuall, and name Orgetorix to be their Generall and Conductour, who for his part imployeth that time in fortifying him≈øelf by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his neighbours,Sequanus. per≈øwadeth Ca≈øticus a Burgundian to make him≈øelf Lord of his countrey as his father had been,Aeduus. draweth in Dumnorix of Autun, brother to Divitiacus to the ≈øame de≈øigne, the mo≈øt powerfull man of his citie, and giveth him his daughter in marriage. But the Sui≈ø≈øes, being ever jealous of their libertie, and perceiving that Orgetorix a≈øpired to
bring them under ≈øubjection, ≈øei≈øed on his per≈øon; and during the conte≈øtations about his triall (having a great train of kinsfolks and partakers) he died in pri≈øon. This abated not the de≈øigne of this people; which on their appointed day having taken as much victuall as would ≈øerve them for three moneths, burnt the re≈øt of their corn, and all their cities to the number of twelve, and 4. hundred villages, and having per≈øwaded tho≈øe of Ba≈øil, Rauraci. Tulingi. Latobrici. Di≈øtalingen, and Clacky, their neighbours, to do the like, they depart and march towards Geneva, there to pa≈ø≈øe the Rho≈øne. Ce≈øar having intelligence thereof goeth ≈øpeedily to Geneva, a≈ø≈øembleth what forces he can, cau≈øeth a bridge to be broken down which lay upon the Rho≈øne, Rhodanus. and maketh a ditch and rampire of eighteen miles long from the lake of Geneva to the hill Jura, to hinder their pa≈ø≈øage over the Rho≈øne. Which the Sui≈ø≈øes under≈øtanding ≈øend deputies to him to de≈øire pa≈ø≈øage: he holdeth them in ≈øu≈øpen≈øe, and promi≈øeth them an≈øwer at another time; mean while he prepareth to hinder them: and they (after refu≈øall, and having attempted the pa≈ø≈øage in vain) take their way through Burgundie which Dumnorix procured for them. Which Ce≈øar ob≈øerving, leaveth Labienus at Geneva, goeth and levieth new Legions, followeth them, and lighting upon them at the pa≈ø≈øage of the Sao≈øne defeateth the fourth part of their troups,Arrar. which were not as yet pa≈ø≈øed over. After that, he maketh a bridge over the river, and pur≈øueth them: but his victuall beginning to fall ≈øhort, and perceiving that Dumnorix hindered tho≈øe of Autun from affording him ≈øuch provi≈øions
as they had promi≈øed, he acquainteth Divitiacus with it, being his great friend and brother to Dumnorix; who confe≈ø≈øeth it, intercedeth for him, and obteineth his pardon. After that, having learned that the Sui≈ø≈øes were incamped at the foot of a hill, he cau≈øeth it to be viewed, and finding it to be of ea≈øie acce≈ø≈øe, he ≈øendeth Labienus thither (cau≈øing him to march all night) to gain the top of the hill: and in the morning, having put his forces into battalia, he di≈øpatcheth Con≈øidius to di≈øcover; who, having taken the allarm of Labienus, returneth to Ce≈øar that the enemy had ≈øei≈øed the top of the hill, which ≈øtayed him that day from defeating the Sui≈ø≈øes. The day following he taketh the way of Beaulne to di≈øtribute corn to his armie: which the Sui≈ø≈øes perceiving,Bibracte. follow him. Ce≈øar ≈øeeing them coming po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelf of a hill, embattelleth his army about the middle of the de≈øcent, & on the top he quartereth two new levied legions and all the baggage, alighteth and ≈øendeth away his hor≈øe, and cau≈øeth all the re≈øt to do the like, to ≈øhew them that they mu≈øt overcome or die. The Sui≈ø≈øes charge him; he defeateth them and pur≈øueth them hotly, forbiddeth tho≈øe of Langres to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them with victuall,Lingones. and in the end con≈øtraineth them to ≈øubmit to his di≈øcretion: He di≈øarmeth them, receiveth ho≈øtages, and forceth them to return to inhabit their countrey, and reedifie their hou≈øes. And of three hundred ≈øixtie eight thou≈øand per≈øons (whereof there were ninetie two thou≈øand bearing arms) there returned in all but an hundred and ten thou≈øand.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: THe re≈øolution of this people, which ≈øeemeth to be barbarous, and which for the bad ≈øucce≈ø≈øe is univer≈øally condemned, hath neverthele≈ø≈øe the ≈øame principles which all Conquerours have, namely, the de≈øire of command and enlarging them≈øelves: and they are remarkable in their forecast of three yeares preparation, in their con≈øtancie for not deficting from their de≈øigne after the death of their Generall; and in the execution thereof, burning their goods and hou≈øes to the end they might leave them≈øelves no hope of ≈øafetie, but onely in the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of their ≈øwords. Whence we may gather, that we ought not to undertake any great de≈øigne timorou≈øly, nor to look to the means of e≈øcape but rather of overcoming. For if in the beginning of a dangerous de≈øigne you make known a way of e≈øcape, the impatience or naturall timorou≈øne≈ø≈øe of men maketh them find out that way upon the lea≈øt accident that befalleth. And if the Sui≈ø≈øes had not met with the incomparable virtue of Ce≈øar, who by his valour, industrie, diligence and good fortune ≈øtayed their furie, they might have atteined the ≈øcope of their enterpri≈øes.

In the managing of his warre Cae≈øar hath ≈øhewed (as in all other) that that which hath made him fortunate in his exploits hath principally been his invariable order of encamping ≈øtrongly, alwayes entrenching him≈øelf, that ≈øo he might never be compelled to fight but when he plea≈øed, and that he might lay hold on ≈øuch occa≈øions as offered them≈øelves to defeat his enemies; al≈øo his providence in taking care that his provi≈øion of victuall failed not; and his continuall keeping of his ≈øouldiers in exerci≈øe and in breath, to make them able to execute his de≈øignes readily and in good order.

The pardon of Dumnorix is ob≈øervable: his naturall clemency induced him to it, ≈øuffering him≈øelf to be overcome by the intreaties of his brother Divitiacus whom he loved: Neverthele≈ø≈øe he cau≈øed heed to be taken to his deportments, that ≈øo he might receive no new inconveniences by him afterward.

The errour of Con≈øidius ≈øheweth how much it concerneth to ≈øend men of experience to di≈øcover an army: And the commanding of the Sui≈ø≈øes to return and reinhabite their countrie was an act of prudence, thereby hindering
the Germanes (being a mo≈øt powerfull nation) from preoccupation thereof, and by that means their neighbourbood to Provence.

div.head: The ≈øecond warre.
div.p: THe ≈øubject of the ≈øecond warre was this: The divi≈øion of the Auvergnats and Autunois pui≈ø≈øant people in Gallia had called in the Germanes, Averni & Aedui. by the help of which the fir≈øt had overcome the other; neverthele≈ø≈øe they all found them≈øelves oppre≈ø≈øed, and the conquerours much more then the conquered: for the≈øe were di≈øcharged for ≈øome tribute and ho≈øtages, and from the other the Germans took away the greate≈øt part of their lands, in≈øomuch that all ≈øeeing them≈øelves ≈øubdued, they hold an a≈ø≈øembly of States by the permi≈ø≈øion of Ce≈øar to de≈øire his aid, which he promi≈øeth. But having ≈øent to Ariovi≈øtus, the Generall of the Germanes, to this end, he received replies ≈øo in≈øolent, that at la≈øt they fell fowl; where Ce≈øar defeated him, and chaced both him and all the Germanes out of Gallia, forcing them to pa≈ø≈øe the Rhine again.
The≈øe two wars were fini≈øhed in one ≈øummer.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
VVHereby we may ob≈øerve how dangerous ≈øuch auxiliarie ≈øuccours are, e≈øpecially when you require them of a people more powerfull then your own. Ce≈øar hath indeed driven out Ariovi≈øtus, but the Gauls have done nothing but changed mai≈øter. He imbarked him≈øelf in this war for two rea≈øons: the fir≈øt, becau≈øe be ≈øu≈øpected that this pui≈ø≈øant nation, taking footing in Gallia, might come to gain upon Provence, and ≈øo draw near to Italy; and the other, that thereby he in≈øinuated him≈øelf in≈øen≈øibly into the conque≈øt of the ≈øaid Gauls. Which bu≈øine≈ø≈øe he managed ≈øo dextrou≈øly by enterteining their divi≈øions among≈øt them,
that by the aid of the one he conquered the other, and in the end ≈øubdued all.

We mu≈øt further ob≈øerve his diligence (≈øo much recommended in all his actions) to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him≈øelf of Be≈øancon, having prevented his enemies, and by this means provided for the nouri≈øhment of his armie. There it was that a panike fear ≈øei≈øed upon his ≈øouldiers, which began by the voluntiers: who de≈øiring to depart di≈øcouraged the re≈øt, that ≈øo they might cover their own ≈øhame by the generall delinquencie of the armie: which is a mo≈øt dangerous thing, and whereof a Generall of an army ought to take extraordinary care, never to hazard any battel untill he hath recovered his ≈øouldiers ≈øpirits again; which Ce≈øar did at this time by making an oration to them, wherein he excelled. He further helped him≈øelf (as many other commanders, e≈øpecially Marius) by encamping ≈øtrongly before this terrible armie, and making his ≈øouldiers know by ≈ømall skirmi≈øhes that their enemies were not invincible nor more valiant then them≈øelves; and cau≈øing them to conceive that joyning order and militarie di≈øcipline to the prudence of their Generall, they were their ≈øuperiours. For the Romanes have never conquered other nations by their great number, nor by their valour, but by their knowledge in warre, (which they alwayes exerci≈øed) by the ob≈øervation of their order, and entrenchment of their camp. Whereupon we must con≈øider that Ariovi≈øtus being encamped between Ce≈øar and the place from whence he had his victuall, and that Ce≈øar not being able to draw him to battel in five dayes, after that he had well fortified that camp be goeth with all his army in battaglia to fortifie a ≈ømall one, in a place of advantage, two miles di≈øtant from the first, and which favoured the way for his victuall, making the third part of his army to work whilest the other two thirds ≈øtood in battaglia, which repul≈øed the troups which Ariovi≈øtus ≈øent to hinder the ≈øaid fortification: which being made he leaveth two legions there, and leadeth away the rest into his old camp. The next day Ce≈øar putteth him≈øelf into battaglia between the two camps, but being retired, Ariovi≈øtus a≈ø≈øaulteth the ≈ømall one, and is repul≈øed. Ce≈øar having thus reconfirmed the courages of his ≈øouldiers, ≈øallieth out with his whole armie in battaglia, and goeth up to the very trenches of Ariovi≈øtus, provoketh him to fight; who ≈øallieth out, and is defeated.

div.head: The third warre. The II. Book.

div.p:
CE≈øars third warre was again≈øt the Belgae, the third part of Gallia, and at that time the mo≈øt warlike. The principall cau≈øes were, that, ≈øeeing the re≈øt of the Gaules in peace with the Romanes, they feared an a≈ø≈øault; be≈øides they were ≈øolicited by certain Gauls di≈øcontented, or ambitious: the one of which took as little plea≈øure to ≈øee the Romanes as Germanes in their countrey; and the other apprehen≈øive that during their abode they ≈øhould not be able to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves of any principalitie or dominion. The number of their forces amounted to two hundred eighty and one thou≈øand fighting men. Ce≈øar, having under≈øtood the≈øe great preparations,Bellouaci. cau≈øeth tho≈øe of Beauvais to be a≈ø≈øailed by Divitiacus and tho≈øe of Autun; and being a≈ø≈øured of tho≈øe of Rhems, which declared them≈øelves for him, he goeth & encampeth upon the river Dai≈øne near to Soi≈ø≈øons, relieveth Brenne, Axona. Sue≈ø≈øones. Bibrax. and (the enemy attempting to pa≈ø≈øe that river) he oppo≈øeth and killeth a great number of them. After that, victuall growing ≈øhort for ≈øo great an armie, and they of Beauvais under≈øtanding that Divitiacus harried their countrey, they re≈øolved to return every man to his own home, and be in a readine≈ø≈øe to relieve the fir≈øt that ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øaulted: But they retreated in ≈øuch di≈øorder, that Ce≈øar had lei≈øure to overtake them; who charging on the rear, routed them, where he made a great ma≈ø≈øacre;Noviodunum. and in pur≈øuit of them he be≈øiegeth and taketh Noyon. All the≈øe ≈øubmitted,
except they of Tournay, Nervii. e≈øteemed the mo≈øt valiant of al; who having di≈øpo≈øed of their old men, women, and children, re≈øolved to defend them≈øelves. Ce≈øar goeth to them: who a≈ø≈øault him ≈øo furiou≈øly as he was going to his quarters, that they had like to have defeated him: ≈øo that he confe≈ø≈øed, that in this conflict his good fortune had equall ≈øhare with his valour and indu≈øtrie. Neverthele≈ø≈øe he defeated them, after which he findeth no more re≈øi≈øtance; the renown of who≈øe victories made him dreadfull even as farre as Germanie, and gained him all Normandy and Bretain, which Publius Cra≈ø≈øus one of his Lieutenants ≈øubjected to the Romanes with onely one Legion.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: VVE mu≈øt here ob≈øerve the judgement of Ce≈øar, who by his diligence a≈ø≈øured him≈øelf of tho≈øe of Rhems, by his indu≈øtrie and affabilitie held them faithfull, and by his fore≈øight prepared a diver≈øion against tho≈øe of Beauvois, (a bold and ≈øtout people) which redounded much to his profit. Further it is to be con≈øidered that an army of thirtie or fourtie thou≈øand men trained and well di≈øciplined, is able (with patience well intrenching and encamping it ≈øelf) to di≈øcomfit the mo≈øt numerous armies, which for want of victuall de≈øtroy them≈øelves; and if they fight (provided that you avoid being ≈øurrounded on all parts) their di≈øorders and confu≈øion will al≈øo break them. The warres of the Romanes do prove this true; who have never defeated their enemies but with le≈ø≈øer number; nor were ever forced to ≈øallie out of their retrenched camp, to give battel again≈øt their wills: and particularly this pre≈øent, wherein Ce≈øar hath had more to do again≈øt one Province ‚Ä¢ lone of the Belgae then again≈øt all the re≈øt together, having very particularly de≈øcribed the battel which he had against tho≈øe of Tournay, as one of the mo≈øt dangerous which he ever had; wherein there be diver≈øe things worthy con≈øideration.

The fir≈øt, That tho≈øe of Tournay being adverti≈øed that Ce≈øar cau≈øed every Legion to march with its baggage after it, they re≈øolved to lay an Embu≈øcado and to fight with them, truly judging that the baggage ≈øeparating the Legions in an inclo≈øed countrey, they ≈øhould not be able to relieve each other, and that otherwi≈øe they might (with all their forces) ≈øet upon each Legion apart.

The ≈øecond, That they found them≈øelves deceived in their pre≈øuppo≈øition; becau≈øe that though Ce≈øar commanded his army to march ≈øo in a countrey of ≈øecuritie for the commodiou≈øne≈ø≈øe thereof; neverthele≈ø≈øe when he was in a ≈øu≈øpected countrey, he cau≈øed ≈øix Legions to march together, then all the baggage, and in the rear of that two Legions newly levied. And it was in this order, and upon his encamping, when they charged him.

The third is the confe≈ø≈øion of Ce≈øar: who freely acknowledgeth that his armie was a≈ø≈øaulted ≈øo unex≈øpectedly and couragiou≈øly, and in a countrey ≈øo inclo≈øed, that it was neither his cu≈øtomary order which ≈øaved him (for he had no lei≈øure to embattel) nor his exhortations, nor his appearance in all parts (for he was forced to fight in the place he then was in) but he attributed the ≈øafetie thereof onely to the continued di≈øcipline of his ≈øouldiers, which knew of them≈øelves to range where they ought, & to that that he ever made all his officers exactly ob≈øerve the performance of their duties, whilest the intrenchment of the camp was a making; ≈øo that in all parts were found ≈øome ready to command, and others to obey; which made good the re≈øi≈øtance, and hindred the affrightment.
The fourth, That a ra≈øh re≈øolution is oftentimes to be feared; and to avoid it, mu≈øt never be omitted what≈øoever dependeth on military di≈øcipline.

And the fifth, That the trea≈øon which tho≈øe of Bolduc (whom he had be≈øieged in the be≈øt of their fortre≈ø≈øes) would have committed against him after they had yielded them≈øelves,Aduatici. ≈øhould teach us that we ≈øhould alwaies di≈øtrust an enemy, and keep our ≈øelves ≈øo much the more upon our guards, the nearer we are to overcome.

div.head: The fourth warre. The III. Book.

div.p:
THe fir≈øt exploit of arms was again≈øt Servius Galba one of Ce≈øars Lieutenants, who having ≈øent him with a Legion and ≈øome hor≈øe into the countreyes of Aelen, Antuates. Veragri. Seduni. Allobroges Lacus Lemanus. Valias, and Sion (which extendeth from Savoy to the lake of Geneva) to a≈ø≈øure the traffick of merchants, after ≈øome ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull combats, made peace with that people, received their ho≈øtages, and having left two companies in the countrey of Aelen, he goeth with the re≈øt of the Legion to quarter at the town of Martanach ≈øituated in a valley,Octodurus. and divided into two by a little river called the Bran≈øe: on the one ≈øide whereof he intrencheth his camp, and on the other he quartereth the Gauls which were with him. The ≈ømall number of ≈øouldiers which he had in his camp (as yet not in good defen≈øe) emboldned tho≈øe people to revolt; hoping that they ≈øhould at the fir≈øt a≈ø≈øault defeat him. For it was in≈øupportable unto them that he ≈øhould have their children in ho≈øtage: and they feared al≈øo that the Romanes would annex tho≈øe places to Provence, which was near at hand. So that he ≈øaw him≈øelf a≈ø≈øaulted on all parts, before he had lei≈øure to under≈øtand the danger he was in; and finding his affairs in great extremitie, having neither victuall to ≈øub≈øi≈øt nor men to make a long re≈øi≈øtance, de≈øpair made him follow the coun≈øel of Publ us Sextius Baculus fir≈øt Centurion of that Cohort,Tribunus. and of Caius Volu≈øenus Colonel of a thou≈øand men, which was to ≈øally out from all
parts upon the enemy: which they did ≈øo violently, that they which thought they were not able to defend them≈øelves in their trenches defeated them in open field. That done, he maketh u≈øe of their di≈øcomfiture to retire his Legion into a place of ≈øafetie.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: SO ended this warre: where we will ob≈øerve fir≈øt the profitablene≈ø≈øe of the intrenchments of camps, which in entire countreys ≈øerve for a bridle, as citadels to cities; the Romanes having never been able to have held ≈øo many conquered States under their obedience, but onely by that means: For armies garri≈øoned in ≈øever all towns may by being ≈øo ≈øeparated be defeated totally, or in part, by con≈øpiracie; be≈øides, the delicacies of cities do overthrow all militarie di≈øcipline, and aba≈øe all generous courage. How≈øoever if there be more fortre≈ø≈øes then can well be mainteined, you must demoli≈øh them, to the end that nothing may be able to re≈øi≈øt the armie: which being always in an intire body, oppo≈øeth it ≈øelf again≈øt all combinings of con≈øpiratours; it being most certain, that not onely for the keeping reliefs out of a conquered Province, but al≈øo for the con≈øervation of your countrey again≈øt greater forces then your own (giving order that there be no want of victuall) it is to be done by intrenching ≈øtrongly: for who≈øoever putteth him≈øelf wholly upon the defen≈øive, and ≈øhutteth him≈øelf up in walled towns, mu≈øt in time nece≈ø≈øarily peri≈øh, unle≈ø≈øe he receiveth forreign reliefs: for that by two or three yeares ≈øpoil of the increa≈øe of the champains the cities mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie ≈øtarve, and thereby know your inabilitie to pre≈øerve them; ≈øo that they will rather yield to your enemy then peri≈øh.

In the ≈øecond place we will con≈øider how Cra≈ø≈øus was put to it, when he had to do with commanders which had been trained under Sertorius, and which (according to the cu≈øtome of the Romanes) could make benefit of the advantage of grounds, fortifie their camp, and cut off their enemies victuall: for by ≈øuch a manner of warring they had brought the ≈øaid Cra≈ø≈øus to ≈øuch a pa≈ø≈øe that he was con≈øtrained to a≈ø≈øault their camp; which albeit he forced (whether by having better ≈øouldiers, or by finding ≈øome part of it ill fortified) yet it is certain that he undertook that task out of de≈øpair rather then judgement, as being in danger to peri≈øh for want of victuals.

We will further ob≈øerve that Ce≈øar in all the≈øe actions by no diver≈øitie of making warre was ever astoni≈øhed, whether he were a≈ø≈øaulted in open field or in his camp, whether ≈øurpri≈øed, or whether his enemie retired into places inacce≈ø≈øible; alwayes finding them out in all places, and that without omitting one onely point of militarie di≈øcipline. For though our enemies ≈øometime do actions which have ≈øhew of fear, the better to circumvent us; yet mu≈øt we not therefore di≈øe≈øteem them: no profe≈ø≈øion being like to that of a ≈øouldier, wherein one fault can never be repaired, and wherein one houre cau≈øeth the lo≈ø≈øe of that reputation which hath been thirtie yeares acquiring.

To conclude this di≈øcour≈øe I will onely adde this, That the crueltie which Ce≈øar u≈øed towards tho≈øe of Vannes ought not to blemi≈øh his clemencie manife≈øted in the whole cour≈øe of his life; but we must rather believe that he forced his di≈øpo≈øition in this ≈øevere action to cha≈øti≈øe the violatours of the law of nations, in that they impri≈øoned tho≈øe which (under promi≈øe of ≈øafetie) went to negotiate with them; and al≈øo to give a terrour to all that people ≈øo ≈øubject to revolt, by letting them ta≈øt the ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe of a mild government while they kept within the lists of obedience, and by u≈øing them rigourou≈øly when they departed from it.

div.head: The fifth warre. The IV. Book.

div.p:
THe Germanes of Francfort and He≈ø≈øen, U≈øipetes. Tenchtheri to the number of foure hundred thou≈øand ≈øouls, finding them≈øelves per≈øecuted by the Suevians (the mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant and hardy people of Germanie) abandon their native homes; and after, wandring through divers countreys, they approch the Rhine about the Provinces of Gueldres and Gulick: out of which they drive the inhabitants, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them≈øelves of their territories on both ≈øides of the river. Ce≈øar (which knew the humour of the French to be turbulent and ready to ≈øhake off the yoke of ≈øervitude) re≈øolved not to ≈øuffer the Germanes to ≈øettle them≈øelves on this ≈øide the Rhine. And though he well perceived that they had begun a treatie with them, he di≈ø≈øembled it, and (anticipating the time which formerly he u≈øed for his going into the field) ha≈øtneth directly to fight with the fore≈øaid Germanes: Which (being a≈øtoni≈øhed at this diligence) ≈øend Emba≈ø≈øadours to him to treat of peace. He giveth them fair audience and courteous an≈øwer, but holdeth on his march ≈øtill towards them: at la≈øt they come to accord, conditioning with Ce≈øar to remain where he was three dayes; he granteth them one: whereupon his cavalrie (to the number of five thou≈øand) advancing to forrage, encountreth with eight hundred Germane hor≈øe; which charge them bravely, rout them, and chace them even to the Romane camp: but the next day ≈øending all their principall commanders to
Ce≈øar to excu≈øe this action, and to make appear unto him that it was by mere accident. He reteineth them pri≈øoners, marcheth with his army towards the Germanes, ≈øurpri≈øeth them, and cutteth them all in pieces. Which done he makes a bridge over the Rhine, goeth into Germanie, relieveth the citie of Cullen, Ubii, or Colonia Agrippina. granteth peace to ≈øuch as would deliver ho≈øtages, burneth and wa≈øteth the re≈øt, and at the end of eighteen dayes breaketh down his bridge and returneth into France.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: VVE mu≈øt here ob≈øerve Ce≈øars wi≈øe conduct, who by his ready and unexpected march di≈ø≈øolved the practices which were in agitation between the Germanes and Gauls; by his di≈ø≈øimulation towards the Gauls (pretending not to know their plottings, and te≈øtifying his confidence of them) held them in fair quarter and hindred them from precipitating them≈øelves into a league with the Germanes; by his indu≈øtrie delayed them by treaties, whilest he ≈øtill marched towards them; and when occa≈øion ≈øerved took his advantage to take them in di≈øorder and de≈øtitute of commanders, making them believe they had fir≈øt broke the treatie.

Next we mu≈øt con≈øider, that upon the fame of this great defeat he cau≈øed the Romane Eagles to flie on the other ≈øide of the Rhine, to ≈øtrike a terrour into the Germanes, and be a means to retein them for the future from further attempting: Be≈øides, he would not pa≈ø≈øe over the Rhine by boats, as a thing too full of hazard, but he made a bridge, which he cau≈øed to be fortified and guarded on both ≈øides of the river: neither ≈øtayed be longer in that countrey then was nece≈ø≈øary for the reputation of his armie; and at his return brake down his bridge, taking away by that cour≈øe the means from the Germanes of making u≈øe thereof.

I adde further, that the defeat of five thou≈øand Romane hor≈øe, by eight hundred of the Germane cavalrie,
and the day after, the defeat of foure hundred thou≈øand Germanes by thirtie or fourtie thou≈øand Romanes, ≈øheweth plainly that it is not the naturall valour of one nation above another, nor the greater number above the ≈ømaller, which giveth the conque≈øt; but the exact ob≈øervation of militarie di≈øcipline, and the continuall exerci≈øe of arms: which instructeth men not onely to fight well, but al≈øo to take advantages, and to know when to fight and when not.

div.head: The ≈øixth warre.
div.p:
CE≈øars ≈øixth warre was again≈øt the Britains, becau≈øe the inhabitants of that I≈øland did oftentimes a≈ø≈øi≈øt the French again≈øt him. To this end he enquireth of merchants which trafficked there, what nations did inhabit it, what their manner of warring, under what laws they lived, and which were their be≈øt havens. Then he di≈øpatched C. Volu≈øenus to di≈øcover the coa≈øt: Then ≈øent for his ≈øhipping, which he had u≈øed in his war again≈øt tho≈øe of Vannes, and prepared all things nece≈ø≈øary for his de≈øigne. The noi≈øe of this preparation gave occa≈øion to many cities of Britain to ≈øend Emba≈ø≈øadours to him, to promi≈øe obedience, and to offer him ho≈øtages; which he returned with fair language, and with them Comius (whom he had made king of Arras) under which pretext he might the better di≈øcover the countrey: Neverthele≈ø≈øe,Atrebates. Comius, not daring to tru≈øt him≈øelf among≈øt the Britains, ≈øtayed onely five dayes upon their coa≈øts, and then returned to give an account of what he had di≈øcovered. Mean time Ce≈øar makes peace with tho≈øe of Terovenne, Morini. that ≈øo he might leave no warre behind him, taketh two Legions and part of his cavalrie, ≈øendeth the re≈øt of his army into the countrey of Gueldres, Menapii. under the
command of Q. Titurius Sabinus, and Arunculeius Cotta, giveth the guard of the Port from whence he imbarqued unto P. Sulpitius Rufus, and putteth to ≈øea. He arriveth ≈øafely upon the coa≈øt of Britain (with his Infanterie onely) which he findeth all in arms; he attempteth to land there, where finding too much difficultie, he goeth and doth it eight miles further, and yet not without danger: Neverthele≈ø≈øe he ≈øo affrighted the Britains that they ≈øent to him to de≈øire peace. But a tempe≈øt ari≈øing, which battered many of his ≈øhips, and drove a-ground all tho≈øe which carried his hor≈øe, gave them new courage; and in ≈øtead of giving him ho≈øtages, they armed all the countrey again≈øt him, ill intreating one of his Legions which went to forrage; which he relieveth, and bringeth ≈øafely off. In the≈øe extremities Ce≈øar taketh care for the repairing of his navie, for provi≈øion of victuall, and for the ≈øecuring of his camp; and being again a≈ø≈øailed by the inhabitants of the I≈øland, he giveth them combat, and defeateth them: Which forceth them afre≈øh to de≈øire peace: he granteth it, taketh ho≈øtages of tho≈øe that would readily deliver them, and carrieth back his armie into Gallia ≈øafe and ≈øound; onely two ≈øhippes with three hundred ≈øouldiers, which landed a little lower, were ≈øet upon by tho≈øe of Teraenne; which Ce≈øar being informed of, ha≈øtneth thither with his cavalrie, re≈øcueth them, and defeateth the enemies.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: IT is to be ob≈øerved, that to beginne a warre in autumne, without apparent advantage, in a countrey undi≈øcovered, not having any intelligence there, and the Ocean to pa≈ø≈øe, is an enterpri≈øe (in my opinion) well worthy the invincible courage of Ce≈øar, but not of his accustomed prudence. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, this e≈øcape mu≈øt be attributed to his good fortune, which he had ≈øubjected to his will. For in this de≈øigne, where it ≈øeemed that men and elements were conjured again≈øt him, the earth refu≈øing him victuall, the ≈øea battering his ≈øhips, the air furni≈øhing tempe≈øts, and the countrey where he landed con≈øpiring his ruine, he con≈øtantly re≈øi≈øted all this; oppo≈øing against famine his providence of making provi≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n for his armie; again≈øt the wracks of the ≈øea, his diligence in repairing his ve≈ø≈øels; again≈øt the a≈ø≈øaults of his enemies, his armies to re≈øi≈øt them, in≈øomuch that he constrained them to beg for peace: and ≈øo he returned gloriou≈øly from a bad countrey, where any el≈øe would have ≈øuffered extremely. Let us al≈øo con≈øider, that before he departed from France he took care to provide what was nece≈ø≈øarie to keep it in obedience, and for the ≈øecuritie of his return. Let us further note, how abundant Ce≈øar was in his inventions, for the advantagious taking of his time, in the very occa≈øion it ≈øelf: for perceiving that his ≈øouldiers (not accu≈øtomed to ≈øea-fights) were di≈øtracted at their landing‚ñ™ he (in the very action) changeth his fir≈øt order, and with his galleys approcheth nearer the coast, and in ≈øpite of his enemies landeth; and they (≈øeeing a kind of ve≈ø≈øels they knew not) were affrighted, and betook them≈øelves to their heels. Al≈øo we ought to admire in Ce≈øar two things which he had to perfection, and which render a commander excellent; namely that he foreca≈øt and provided for all things which might either further or hinder this de≈øigne before he undertook it; and that in the very execution be ≈øailed not to take his advantage when occa≈øion pre≈øented it, or to remedy upon the in≈øtant ≈øuch unexpected accidents as befell; wherein he hath been inimitable.

CE≈øar not ≈øatisfied with his fir≈øt voyage into Britain imployeth the winter to cau≈øe ≈øuch equipage to be prepared as was nece≈ø≈øarie for his pa≈ø≈øage thither the ≈øecond time, and according to his cu≈øtome goeth into Lombardy, from whence (before his return) he pa≈ø≈øeth into Sclavonia to quiet ≈øome ≈øeditions which were there befallen:Illyricum. afterwards returneth to his armie, findeth all in good order, commendeth every man for their diligence in getting all things in readine≈ø≈øe. But before his departure he goes to Triers, a very powerfull people, about a divi≈øion fallen between Induciomarus and Cingentorix, the two great men of the town: The la≈øt cometh to him and promi≈øeth him all obedience: the other prepareth for warre; neverthele≈ø≈øe, fearing to be abandoned, yieldeth him≈øelf; Ce≈øar receiveth him, but dimini≈øheth his authoritie, and augmenteth that of Cingentorix, whom he believeth be≈øt affected to him: which done, he continueth his de≈øigne, takes along with him the principall men of Gallia in this warre. Dumnorix of Autun makes difficulties; Ce≈øar pre≈ø≈øeth him, he excu≈øeth him≈øelf; then attempts to ≈øeduce the Gauls, at la≈øt he flies; Ce≈øar ≈øendeth after him, but refu≈øing to return,Iccius. is ≈ølain. He imbarkt at Calice, where he left Labienus with three legions and two thou≈øand hor≈øe; he pa≈ø≈øeth into Britain, and landeth without re≈øi≈øtance: he fortifieth a camp to guard his ve≈ø≈øels, leaveth Q. Atrius there, and pa≈ø≈øeth further; forceth the camp of the Britains not farre di≈øtant from thence. The next day Atrius
≈øendeth him word that the tempe≈øts had ≈øhattered the greater part of his navie; he returneth thither, imployeth ten whole dayes about repairing them, draws them on ≈øhore, cau≈øeth the camp to be well fortified, commandeth Labienus to cau≈øe n ‚Ä¢ w ≈øhips to be built, then advanceth towards Ca≈ø≈øivellanus, declared Generall for the Britains, who dares not a≈ø≈øail him but when he goes to forrage, which cau≈øeth him to go ≈øtrong and in good order; & after he had triall of his manner of fight by ≈øome skirmi≈øhes, he defeated him by C. Trebonius one of his Lieutenants, who went thither with three legions and all the cavalry. After this defeat there appeared no more enemies in gro≈ø≈øe; and Ce≈øar, being come to the river Thames pa≈ø≈øeth it at the onely place where it was fordable, in de≈øpite of the Britains, who endeavoured to their utmo≈øt to hinder him: which ≈øo a≈øtoni≈øhed Ca≈ø≈øivellanus, that all his care was to hide him≈øelf in the woods; & ≈øeeing that divers towns had yielded them≈øelves to Ce≈øar, he al≈øo ≈øent to him; who received him, giving ho≈øtages, impo≈øing a certain tribute upon the countrey. TheÃÑ ≈øeeing the ≈øea≈øon much ≈øpent, and fearing ≈øome tumults in France, he repa≈ø≈øeth the ≈øea, bringing back his armie gloriou≈øly, which (contrary to his cu≈øtome) he was con≈øtrained (by rea≈øon of the barrenne≈ø≈øe of the yeare) to ≈øeparate into divers garri≈øons to keep it alive. But before he could go into Italie, Ambiorix and Cativulcus in≈øtigated by Induciomarus take arms, a≈ø≈øail Sabinus and Cotta two of his Lieutenants, defeat and kill them as they were removing from their camp; from thence they go and a≈ø≈øail Cicero in his camp,
another of his Lieutenants, which defendeth him≈øelf with much difficulty; Ce≈øar relieveth him, and defeateth the Gauls. The report of the defeat of two Romane legions inciteth the other Gauls to revolt; in≈øomuch that Labienus is a≈ø≈øaulted in his camp by Induciomarus: he with≈øtandeth the a≈ø≈øault, afterwards conquereth and killeth him. As the fir≈øt defeat of the Romane legions moved all the Gauls to revolt, ≈øo the≈øe two la≈øt overthrows made them lay down their arms.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
IN this ≈øecond voyage of Ce≈øar into Britain, though he went thither with greater forces and better prepared then at fir≈øt, having ≈øupplied tho≈øe defects which were wanting before; neverthele≈ø≈øe going into a countrey which he could not come to but by ≈øea, where he had no intelligence, and going from another newly conquered, ≈øubject to revoltings, and which grudgingly endured ≈øubjection, he rather therein ≈øatisfied his own ambition, then that he added any great profit to the Romanes. Wherein we will fir≈øt ob≈øerve his dexterity and prudence, in that he carried along with him (as voluntaries) all the ≈øtirring ≈øpirit ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ among≈øt the Gauls, which ≈øerved as ho≈øtages for him. But it appears, his naturall clemency made him commit an errour, in contenting him≈øelf to have dimini≈øhed the authority of Induciomarus, when indeed he ≈øhould have ruined him; whereof he found the inconvenience afterward.

Secondly, that he never was moved at any unexpected accidents, for which he was prepared as if he had fore≈øeen them, which he made to appear to good purpo≈øe in this great tempest, which ≈øhattered all his ≈øhips, and would have driven any but him≈øelf to de≈øperation.

Thirdly, though he were renowned for the Captain which be≈øt knew how to make u≈øe of his victories, and which hath pur≈øued them home≈øt; he would not do it here, becau≈øe he was in an unknown countrey, and his camp not as yet well fortified.

Let us con≈øider al≈øo, that how≈øoever the ≈øcarcity of corn
compelled him (contrary to his custome) to cau≈øe his army to make their winter-garri≈øons in ≈øeverall places, and not all together, to the end that they might with more facility be furni≈øhed with victuall; yet he did it with ≈øuch judgement, as that the places where they quartered were not ≈øo far di≈øtant, but that they could ea≈øily relieve each other; nor ≈øo near, but they held divers States in obedience. Neverthele≈ø≈øe the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe ≈øheweth us evidently, that it is not ≈øo good as to be quartered in an intire body, becau≈øe it is ea≈øier to a≈ø≈øail a ≈ømall troop then a great; which gave encouragement to the Gauls to revolt and to a≈ø≈øail the camp of Sabinus & Cotta: where the artificiall oration of Ambiorix per≈øwading them that the revolt was ≈øo generall, that at the ≈øame instant all the other camps were a≈ø≈øaulted, and could not relieve each other, put them into ≈øuch a confu≈øion in matter of coun≈øel, that fear made them choo≈øe the wor≈øt, which was to for≈øake their camp and retreat. Whence we may learn, That he never ≈øpeedeth well that followeth the coun≈øels of an enemy; and, That a retreat in view of the enemy is the most dangerous action that can be undertaken.

Cicero his re≈øi≈øtance ‚Ä¢ ithi ‚Ä¢ his camp, which refu≈øed to follow his enemies coun≈øel, and re≈øolved to defend him≈øelf within his trenches, proved for his ≈øafetie and great glory; and gave time to Ce≈øar to relieve him: wherein there be two things remarkable; The fir≈øt of Ce≈øar, who having under≈øtood that the Gauls came towards him to give him battel, finding him≈øelf weak maketh choice of an advantageous place, fortifieth it, maketh his camp very ≈ømall, to the end he might the better defend it, and make his enemies believe that he was exceeding weak; whom (after they had many times provoked him to fight) they began to di≈øregard, which begot a neglect of all order among≈øt them; ≈øo that they a≈ø≈øaulted him ever after di≈øorderly: having thus lulled them a≈øleep, on a day he chargeth them ≈øo furiou≈øly, that he defeateth them without re≈øi≈øtance And Lab ‚Ä¢ enus one of his Lieutenants by a like ≈øtratageme did the like to Induciomarus. The ≈øecond of the Gauls, who not being able to force the camp of Cicero, ≈øhut him up by a retrenchment which conteined ten miles in circuit, made in three houres, and by men which had nothing to dig with but their ≈øwords, and nothing to carry earth with but their clothes: which argueth they were a great multitude, and ≈øheweth what may be done by armies well regulated and well provided.

div.head: The eighth warre. The VI. Book.

div.p:
CE≈øar, perceiving the affairs of the Gauls to incline to warre, fortifieth him≈øelf by three Romane Legions, and as many other ≈øouldiers as he could get; which fell out very happily for him: for after the death of Induciomarus the Trevois put their government into the hands of his kindred, which made league with all that would revolt, and particularly with Ambiorix; whereof Ce≈øar being adverti≈øed, joyns foure legions together in winter, ≈øurpri≈øes tho≈øe of Tournay, forceth them to yield & deliver ho≈øtages. And in the ≈øpring following cau≈øeth the Gauls to a≈ø≈øemble at Paris, Lutetia. from whence, on the ≈øame day that the a≈ø≈øembly brake up, he goeth and a≈ø≈øaulteth tho≈øe of Sens, Senones. Carnutes. then tho≈øe of Chartres, who (finding them≈øelves ≈øurpri≈øed) yield. From thence he prepareth to ≈øet upon Ambiorix and tho≈øe of Triers, but fir≈øt he laboureth to draw away from them their allies: To which end he di≈øcardeth all his baggage, which he commits to Labienus (who was in the countrey of Triers) with two legions to guard it, and him≈øelf with five goeth to a≈ø≈øail the Gauls. For execution whereof he divided his army into three parts; for that he well knew they were not able to di≈øpute the champain with him, and ≈øo burnt and pillaged their countrie, that he con≈øtrained them to yield, to deliver ho≈øtages, and to for≈øake Ambiorix. At the ≈øame time they of Triers a≈ø≈øail Labienus; who making a ≈øhew of fear, and retreating as if he had fled, draweth them in di≈øorder into places of di≈øadvantage, where he defeateth them, and
taketh the very citie of Triers. This expedition being fini≈øhed, Ce≈øar maketh a bridge over the Rhine, and pa≈ø≈øeth it: they of Cullen adhere to him; he fortifieth his camp, and maketh provi≈øion of victuall, attempteth to compell the Suevians to battel; but ≈øeeing them retreat into va≈øt and deep forre≈øts, he forbeareth to pur≈øue them; repa≈ø≈øeth the Rhine, cutteth off (on the Germane ≈øide) onely 120 foot of his bridge, maketh a good tower on the end thereof, at the other end on the ≈øide of Gallia he buildeth a fort, leaving twelve cohorts to guard that and the ≈øaid bridge. (In this place Ce≈øar maketh a de≈øcription of the manners and cu≈øtomes of the Gauls and the Germanes) That done he goeth to continue the warre again≈øt Ambiorix; and the better to ≈øurpri≈øe him he ≈øendeth L. Minutius Ba≈øilius before, with all the cavalrie, forbidding him the making any fire in his camp to the end his approch might be undi≈øcovered, by which means he thought to have ≈øei≈øed upon Ambiorix; who ≈øaved him≈øelf miraculou≈øly by flying from one place to another, & Ce≈øar (the better to follow him) conveys again his baggage into a ca≈øtle of the Liegeois called Vatucca, Eburones. Wachtendonck. for guard whereof he left Q. Tullius Cicero with one legion, commanding him for ≈øeven dayes (the time which his expedition would take up) to look carefully to his guards, and not to ≈øtirre out of his trenches. Then divided he his army into three parts to harra≈ø≈øe all that countrey; who meeteth with nothing in the form of an army to oppo≈øe him, in≈øomuch that his greate≈øt care was to prevent that his ≈øouldiers (covetous of booty) ≈øtraggled not too far abroad, for fear of being cut off by the enemies, which lay
hidden in forre≈øts and boggs. The report reached pre≈øently to the other ≈øide of the Rhine, that Ce≈øar expo≈øed the countrey of Gueldres to pillage;Menapii. which occa≈øioned the We≈øtfalians to participate of the booty:Sicambri. they pre≈øently get together two thou≈øand hor≈øe, pa≈ø≈øe the Rhine, pillage without re≈øi≈øtance, & are ≈øo well plea≈øed with ta≈øt thereof that they re≈øolve to ≈øet upon the Romane camp; when by misfortune, that day being the ≈øeventh from Ce≈øars departing, Cicero (which had ob≈øerved his command very exactly, and having no news, nor ≈øu≈øpecting an enemie) ≈øuffered him≈øelf by the importunity of his ≈øouldiers to give way to them to forrage, and at the ≈øame in≈øtant was (unexpectedly) a≈ø≈øaulted by the We≈øtfalians, again≈øt whom he had much ado to defend him≈øelf; untill that his ≈øouldiers returning from forrage, part of them made their way through the enemies, and regained the camp; but the re≈øt were cut in pieces. Neverthele≈ø≈øe this relief bereft the enemies of all hope of forcing the camp; and ≈øo they returned to their countrey with their bootie. A while after arrived Ce≈øar, who rebuked Cicero for tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing his command. Then he re≈øolveth afre≈øh to expo≈øe the countrey of Gueldres to fire and ≈øword, and to pur≈øue Ambiorix, who had yet e≈øcaped: after that he ≈øendeth his army to garri≈øon, which he ≈øupplieth with corn, and then goeth into Italy.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
IN this warre Ce≈øar had no great re≈øi≈øtance, all fleeing before him, having nothing to do but to pillage and burn the countrey; notwithstanding there be very good ob≈øervations to be made thereupon: for though you learn not hence how to fight a battel, or to expugne fortre≈ø≈øes, yet you may
here learn how to deal with ≈øuch as ≈øave them≈øelves by flight and by retiring into inacce≈ø≈øible places: wherein many Commanders have failed for the not ob≈øerving of three principall things, which Ce≈øar did: Fir≈øt, to prevent the enemy by ≈øuch extraordinary diligence, as to ≈øurpri≈øe them before they be able to retire them≈øelves or their victuall into the forrests; ≈øo that by this means you may con≈øtrain the one to yield, and the other to peri≈øh through famine. The ≈øecond, to divide your army into as many parts as you can with ≈øafety, that ≈øo a≈ø≈øayling a countrey in ≈øeverall places all at once, the inhabitants thereof will be doubtfull to what part to retire unto. And the la≈øt is, to hinder the ≈øouldiers from di≈øbanding when they go to pillage, for fear they be cut off by the enemies. By which over≈øight many great inconveniences have often befallen conquering armies; which ≈øhould teach us never to ≈ølacken the ≈øeverity of military di≈øcipline, though we believe our ≈øelves far from an enemie, and in great ≈øecurity. The example we have in this book of Q. Cicero is excellent in that kind, who received a great lo≈ø≈øe, and had like to have been utterly defeated, by ≈øuffering him≈øelf to be per≈øwaded by the importunity of his ≈øouldiers, which (contrary to Ce≈øars command) would needs go out of their trenches to forrage.

We „Äà‚óä„Äâ further ≈øee the difference between old ≈øouldiers and new, who (for want of experience) knew not how to choo≈øe what was for their ≈øafety and honour, but retreated to a hill and there were cut in pieces: but the other, knowing there was no ≈øafetie but by recovering the camp, made their way with their ≈øwords, and ≈øaved both them≈øelves and their camp. Here we may ob≈øerve how ingenious ≈øear is to ≈øeek out ≈øubjects to augment it ≈øelf; for becau≈øe this place was the ≈øame where Titurius and Cotta had been defeated the yeare before, they took it for an ill omen.

Let us further ob≈øerve, that Ce≈øar (when he would make an expedition for ≈øeven or eight dayes, wh re was diligence required) di≈øcharged him≈øelf of his baggage, which in truth is a marvellous impediment in a champain; & it is impo≈ø≈øible to conduct an army well, if (according to occa≈øions) you do not ≈øtrongly intrench your camp, or march without baggage.

Let us al≈øo admire the good intelligence Ce≈øar had by ≈øpies; a thing of ≈øuch utilitie, as that a Prince or Generall ought to ≈øpare no co≈øt for, it being the mo≈øt powerfull means to undertake
brave de≈øignes, and to avoid great ruines.

Neither must we forget his dexterity in dividing tho≈øe which were entring into a combination again≈øt him, and his a≈ø≈øaulting them ≈øeverally, nor his customary d ligence in ≈øurpri≈øing them; having atteined to the end of the most part of his great de≈øignes by the≈øe wayes.

We will conclude the ob≈øervations of this book with the ≈øtratageme of Labienus: who, de≈øirous to fight with tho≈øe of Triers before the G rmanes were joyned to them, re≈øolved to make it publickly believed that he was afraid of them, and that he would retreat; knowing right well that there were Gauls in his own army which would di≈øcover it to them; and in the mean time gave order ≈øecretly to retreat with a great noi≈øe, & making ≈øhew of much fear: whereof they of Triers having intelligence, without ≈øtaying for the Germanes, conceiving they ought not to let ≈ølip the occa≈øion which offered it ≈øelf unto them, pa≈ø≈øed the river, and came di≈øorderly as to an a≈ø≈øured victory: but Labienus turneth upon them in good order, and defeateth them. Yet would I not coun≈øel you at any time to attempt ≈øuch a ≈øtratageme with new-levied ≈øouldiers, which u≈øually are fearfull when they ≈øee men running towards them and without order; which (on the contrary) a≈ø≈øureth tho≈øe which are experienced.

div.head: The ninth warre. The VII. Book.

div.p:
THe affairs of Gallia quieted, Ce≈øar goeth into Italy, according to his cu≈øtome: where he heareth of the death of Pi≈øo, and the garboils of Rome; which gave new occa≈øion to the Gauls of revolting. Chartres began, the Auvergnats followed, and at length many others. Vercingetorix an Auvergnat is cho≈øen Generall for all. Ce≈øar hearing this cometh away in the depth of winter,Gaballi. pa≈ø≈øeth the mountains of Genaudan covered with ≈ønow, and appeareth in Auvergne before it was known that he was come from Jtaly: which cau≈øed many to hold for him, and
≈øtartled tho≈øe which were revolted. With the ≈øame diligence he pa≈ø≈øeth into Burgundy and Champaigne, where he a≈ø≈øembleth his army, cometh to Berry, and be≈øiegeth it;Bituriges. and taketh Vellaudunum (from whence he takes 600 ho≈øtages) then forceth Gien (or Orleans) where was made a great ≈ølaughter: Vercingetorix, Genabis. ≈øeeing the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of his enemie, and conceiving his army in≈øufficient to deal with him in the field, endeavoureth to conquer him by taking away all means of ≈øub≈øi≈øtence; and to this purpo≈øe burneth more then twenty towns,Avaricum pre≈øerving onely Bourges (and that too again≈øt his advi≈øe,) Ce≈øar be≈øieged it, where he ≈øuffered much, and found him≈øelf in great difficulties and nece≈ø≈øities; at length having overcome them, he taketh the town, putteth to the ≈øword fourty thou≈øand men, & there refre≈øheth his army. During this ≈øiege he attempted to ≈øurpri≈øe Vercingetorix his camp, but was repul≈øed yet was not di≈øcouraged at all with all this ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, but continueth the warre with much re≈øolution and prudence; and Vercingetorix, to hinder his enemie from pa≈ø≈øing the river of Alier, Elaver. breaketh down all the bridges: neverthele≈ø≈øe Ce≈øar making ≈øhew to pa≈ø≈øe in one place, taketh advantage to do it in another; then goeth and be≈øiegeth Clairmont. Gergobia. Vercingetorix encampeth on the other ≈øide, where were many a≈ø≈øaults and brave combats: neverthele≈ø≈øe Ce≈øar is con≈øtrained to quit the ≈øiege, whether for that he made doubt of taking the town, or whether to prevent the revolt of the Autunois artificially procured by Litavicus; who having procured him≈øelf to be cho≈øen Commander of a relief ≈øent to Ce≈øar, being but ten leagues from him, pretended
to have received news from the army, that all the Autunois there were put to the ≈øword; which news he pre≈øently conveyeth to Autun, ≈øo that both there and in his camp all that was Romane ≈øuffered the like, with the lo≈ø≈øe of their goods to boot, but chiefly the corn which they carried to relieve the army withall: Whereof Ce≈øar being adverti≈øed by Eporedorix, without con≈øultation taketh foure legions and all his cavalrie, marcheth day and night, overtaketh Litavicus with his forces, maketh known his fraudulent dealing to the ≈øouldiers, and without ≈øtriking ≈øtroke reduceth them to obedience, and with great diligence ≈øendeth to tho≈øe of Autun, to give them knowledge of what had happened; & with the ≈øame celeritie returneth very opportunely to his camp, which he relieveth, finding it ≈øtrongly a≈ø≈øaulted and hardly put to it by Vercingetorix. That done, he taketh his way again towards the river of Alliers and pa≈ø≈øeth it; mean time Litavicus (who was fled towards Vercingetorix) procureth a league of the Autunois with him;Noviodunum. Eporedorix and Viridomarus ≈øei≈øe upon Nevers, where Ce≈øar had left his ho≈øtages, corn, and publick trea≈øure, which they pillage and burn: Which drove him into great ≈øtraits, becau≈øe that Vercingetorix alwayes coa≈øted him, and cut off his victuall. At la≈øt he re≈øolved by great marches to gain the river Loyre, Ligeris. which he pa≈ø≈øed over to joyn with Labienus, to whom (in the beginning of this warre) he had given foure legions to go towards Paris. While≈øt things pa≈ø≈øed in this manner, Labienus was much di≈øtracted by the garboils of all the≈øe revolts:Melodunum. notwith≈øtanding having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of Melun, he gave jealou≈øies
to his enemies in many places, in≈øomuch that by this trick he pa≈ø≈øed the river Seine, Sequana. & before that all the≈øe revolted people could joyn forces, he defeated the fir≈øt which oppo≈øed them≈øelves, took Prouvins, Agendicum. and from thence joyned with Ce≈øar. At the ≈øame time the Gauls renew their con≈øpiracies and intelligences, they hold an a≈ø≈øembly, where almo≈øt all the Gauls are pre≈øent, they again choo≈øe Vercingetorix Generall, who maketh provi≈øion of great ≈øtore of cavalrie to the end he might di≈øaccommodate the Romanes by cutting off their victuall. On the other ≈øide Ce≈øar maketh his provi≈øions, payeth his Germane cavalry; but Vercingetorix being carried away with good opinion conceived of his cavalry, adventureth a battel with Ce≈øar, where he was defeated. After that he retireth him≈øelf to Alexia, whither Ce≈øar followeth him and re≈øolveth to be≈øiege him: Vercingetorix perceiving his de≈øigne gathereth together all the victuall of the town, cau≈øeth it to be di≈øtributed by mea≈øure, and judgeth that by well managing thereof there would be enough for near upon two moneths, di≈øchargeth his cavalry, ≈øendeth every one into his countrey to procure him relief in time, and he with eighty thou≈øand fighting men ≈øhutteth him≈øelf into Alexia: which Ce≈øar ≈øurroundeth with double & treble trenches, then maketh a ≈øecond circumvallation, to keep out reliefs from without, with an incredible labour and diligence, and maketh a provi≈øion of victuall ≈øufficient to make the be≈øieged con≈øume theirs; which ≈øuffer great extremity. At length relief cometh under the conduct of Comius, to the number of two hundred and fifty thou≈øand; he maketh three ≈øtrong
a≈ø≈øaults at divers times, two in the day and one in the night, is repul≈øed, and retreateth: whereby they of the town are con≈øtrained to yield them≈øelves to the di≈øcretion of Ce≈øar, who reteined the Autunois and Auvergnats, to regain tho≈øe towns which were nece≈ø≈øary for him, and di≈øtributeth the re≈øt among≈øt his ≈øouldiers. After this, all the re≈øt ≈øubmitted. Thus ended this warre, the greate≈øt and mo≈øt dangerous of all that Ce≈øar had in Gallia.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: ALl Ce≈øars other warres in Gallia have been made by divided parts, having made u≈øe of their divi≈øions to ruine them; but this, by a generall con≈øent of almost all: they cho≈øe one ≈øupreme Commander, great in prudence & courage, who, well perceiving that the good di≈øcipline of the Romanes and their knowledge in the art military, made them invincible by way of battels, changed his own way of making warre again≈øt them, and by prolonging time without hazarding a generall battel, finding him≈øelf ≈øuperiour in hor≈øe, and the countrey to friend, not ready to ≈øupply their armies with victuall, made ju≈øt account to have ruined them: whereupon we may make very good ob≈øervations.

First, upon Vercingetorix, who having been by a generall con≈øent cho≈øen Generall of divers States (which had emulations one towards another) hath known ≈øo well how to govern them, that what adver≈øitie ≈øoever he met with in his affairs, he hath alwayes mainteined him≈øelf in great authority and aw amongst them; not ≈øparing to be ≈øevere where occa≈øion required (fear being the most powerfull means to keep men in order:) ill ≈øucce≈ø≈øes never being able to deject him or dimini≈øh his confidence. Even at that time when he was accu≈øed to have had intelligence with the enemy, he ≈øo boldly defended him≈øelf by an oration, that he came off more authori≈øed then before. Al≈øo it is an efficacious means to continue ≈øeverall people in a fair ob≈øequencie, to parle often with them upon ≈øuch affairs as happen. He had the power to make them ≈øet fire on above twenty cities to di≈øcommodate their enemies, which argued his great judgement,
for it was the onely way to have overcome the Romanes (≈øtronger then they in battel) to have fought with them by famine. And in ≈øuch affairs all moderate coun≈øels, or but half executed, are ruinous: as the taking of Bourges ≈øerveth us for a memorable example, for the ≈øaving of it from burning pre≈øerved it for the benefit of the Romanes; which (by taking thereof) found therein ≈øuch commodious things as they ≈øtood in need of. His great credit is very remarkable: for to a free people at the beginning of a warre, before they had ta≈øted of bad ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and in their hope to be able to overcome without being driven to ≈øo ≈ømart remedies, he prevaileth with them to fire their hou≈øes and goods, for the con≈øervation whereof warre is for the mo≈øt part made. It was a very hard enterpri≈øe, for that the lo≈ø≈øe of things certain and pre≈øent which we ≈øee and feel, is preferrable (with the ignorant) to things whereof the events are uncertain, and the benefits remote; and no man can well apprehend this difficulty that hath not experimented it in the government of the people. He hath be≈øides ≈øhewed his con≈øtancy even to the end, and made no ≈øcruple (being the chief of ≈øo many ≈øeverall nations) to be ≈øhut up in a citie, where he did all that a provident and brave Generall ought to do, and hath ≈øurmounted hunger and the di≈øcommodities of a ≈øiege, having held out even untill his relief was repul≈øed and defeated; but becau≈øe hi≈øtories make not but for the victorious, we ≈øee u≈øually none had in esteem but the ≈øonnes of fortune.

Now let us examine Ce≈øars carriage in this warre, which brake out he being in Italy, in the depth of winter, his army di≈øper≈øed in ≈øeverall countreys, far di≈øtant from each other, and the revolted States ≈øo in his way, as it was almost impo≈ø≈øible for him to unite his legions. In ≈øo great difficulties he findeth no other means but to ≈øurmount them by incomparable labour, wherewith he maketh way over the mountains covered ≈øix foot thick with ≈ønow, and affrighteth his enemies more appearing in the midde≈øt of them (when they believed him ≈øtill in Italy and out of po≈øsibility to get to them) then by his great forces. He al≈øo added to this a≈øtoni≈øhment by industry, cau≈øing his cavalry to ≈øhew it ≈øelf in ≈øeverall places at one and the ≈øame time, to cau≈øe a belief that he was very powerfull.

Let us further con≈øider that Ce≈øar ≈øeeing the fa≈øhion of the warre changed, and that the enemy avoided battel, applyeth him≈øelf to ≈øieges, wherein he ≈øheweth him≈øelf no le≈ø≈øe a
ma≈øter then in his other actions of warre. For all that which the mo≈øt excellent modern Generalls put in practice, is drawn from his actions: and what≈øoever we admire of O≈øtend, Breda, The Bu≈ø≈øe.
‚Ä¢
Bolduc, and many other ≈øieges of the late Prince Maurice (who hath ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed all others in that matter) is infinitely inferiour to the two circumvallations of Alexia, where the industry, the labour, and the ≈øhort time in which they were fini≈øhed, farre exceedeth all that hath been done el≈øewhere. I am not ignorant that the invention of powder and of artillery hath changed the manner of fortifications, of a≈ø≈øaults, and of the defen≈øe of towns; but not in ≈øuch ≈øort, but that the principall foundations whereupon they are e≈øtabli≈øhed are particularly taken from Ce≈øar, who in that hath far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øed all the Romane Generalls.

He is al≈øo admirable in his inventions and ≈øtratagemes, & in the undauntedne≈ø≈øe of his enterpri≈øes, who when he intended an a≈ø≈øault upon the trenches which were about Clermont, he put a jealou≈øie into them by a body which he made of the hor≈øe-boyes and baggages of the camp, which he cau≈øed to march in their ≈øight towards that part which he meant not to a≈ø≈øault, but not at ≈øo near a di≈øtance that they might di≈øcover what kind of people they were; and having laid a legion in embu≈øcado in the night-time, and cau≈øed ≈øome ≈øelected ≈øouldiers to convey them≈øelves into the little camp which was nearer to the town, he a≈ø≈øaulteth them ≈øo at unawares that he made him≈øelf master of all their trenches.

When he would have pa≈ø≈øed the river of Alliers, which Vercingetorix attempted to oppo≈øe, he cau≈øed ≈øome legions to lie in ambu≈øh near to a bridge which had been broken, and with the re≈øt of the army (which he made ≈øhew as if it had been intire) he pa≈ø≈øeth along the river, as if he had ≈øought ≈øome other pa≈ø≈øage, by which means he ≈øo deluded the enemies, as that he cau≈øed the bridge to be repaired before it could be taken notice of, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øed over without any hindrance.

When Vercingetorix (in the time of the ≈øiege of Burges) was gone out with his cavalry, he departed by night, and went and a≈ø≈øaulted his infantery within the camp, and wanted little of defeating it.

When at the ≈øiege of Clermont he under≈øtood of the revolt of ten thou≈øand Autunois which came to his relief, he taketh foure legions, marcheth day and night to overtake them: which he doth, and took them all, and returneth time enough
to defend his camp, which was a≈ø≈øailed by Vercingetorix. Whereby we may ob≈øerve by the way the benefit of having a camp alwayes well fortified, to the end we may be ever in a readine≈ø≈øe to attempt upon the enemy as occa≈øions ≈øhall offer them≈øelves.

I cannot forget his great modesty. Comius (whom he had favoured, rai≈øed to wealth & honour, and on whom he much tru≈øted) he rather excu≈øeth then blameth for revolting; alledging that he was forced to comply with the generall re≈øolution for recovering the liberty and glory of all Gallia.

Let us ≈øpeak a word or two of Labienus, one of his Lieutenants; who finding him≈øelf in a ≈øtrait with foure of Ce≈øars legions, in this generall revolt, encircled on all parts with enemies, and being to pa≈ø≈øe the river Seine upon boats, to joyn him≈øelf to Ce≈øar, oppo≈øed by ≈øtrong forces which encrea≈øed every houre, in this extremity be imployeth both his courage and indu≈øtry, divideth his troups into three parts, maketh great appearance of pa≈ø≈øing over in two places, where indeed he intended it not; by which means having ≈øeparated their forces into divers troups, not knowing where to attend to oppo≈øe him, he pa≈ø≈øeth over by night with three legions, or le≈ø≈øe, with which he fought with the fir≈øt troups that came again≈øt him, and defeated them; in≈øomuch that having pa≈ø≈øed the rest of his troups at their ea≈øe, joyned them (without further inconvenience) to Ce≈øar. Whereupon I will make this ob≈øervation, namely, That he which is not very carefull and diligent in the guarding of a pa≈ø≈øage of a river or mountain, is for the mo≈øt part circumvented: becau≈øe he which hath the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof ≈øleepeth ≈øecurely upon the advantage he hath; and he which would have it ≈øearcheth out all po≈ø≈øible means (and at la≈øt findeth them) to remove all ob≈øtacles.

div.head: The tenth warre. The VIII. Book.

div.p:
THe Gauls de≈øirous to make one attempt more to ≈øhake off their yoke of ≈øervitude, divers towns con≈øpired together to revolt: whereof Ce≈øar being adverti≈øed, ≈øurpri≈øeth them ≈øo unexpectedly,
as that he continued tho≈øe in their fidelity which were not as yet revolted, and reduced the re≈øt. Eighteen daies after his return to his winter-garri≈øons, they of Bourges gave him knowledge that they were a≈ø≈øaulted by tho≈øe of Ca≈øtres; he goeth to relieve them, & (notwith≈øtanding the un≈øea≈øonable weather) bringeth them to ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. After that tho≈øe of Rhems de≈øired his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance again≈øt the people of Beauvois, the mo≈øt powerfull and valiant of Gallia, led by Corbeius and Comius two brave Commanders; he marcheth thither, taketh care to get intelligence from them, encampeth him≈øelf before them, where his ≈øouldiers receive an affront going to forrage; but after that Corbeius had charged his camp, and better fortified his quarters, he under≈øtood that he had laid an embu≈øcado for his ≈øouldiers which went to forrage; whither he goeth ≈øo ≈øtrong that he defeateth and killeth him. This victorie obliged tho≈øe of Beauvois to yield them≈øelves. But Comius fled, not daring to tru≈øt him≈øelf among≈øt the Romanes, becau≈øe that a little before Labienus would have cau≈øed him to have been made away by Vollu≈øenus contrary to publick faith. This warre thus ended, Ce≈øar goeth and wa≈øteth Ambiorix his countrey, to procure him hatred among≈øt his own people, under the command of Fabius one of his Lieutenants; he relieveth Limoges which was a≈ø≈øaulted by Dumnacus, Lemovicum. whom he pur≈øueth; and as he ha≈øted to gain the river Loyre to put him≈øelf into ≈øafetie, he defeateth him. Then ≈øubjugated tho≈øe of Chartres and Bretagne with great promptitude and alacritie. Under the command of Caninius he be≈øiegeth Drapes and Luterius in the citie of
Cadenac: Uxellodunum. who ≈øallying out to provide corn for the town, Luterius going about to convey it in is defeated; and at length Drapes is a≈ø≈øaulted and taken in his camp. After this, he really formed the ≈øiege, whither Ce≈øar came in per≈øon, who found means to hinder them from water, ≈øo that this poore people yielded them≈øelves to his di≈øcretion; with whom he dealt rigorou≈øly, cau≈øing their hands to be cut off which had born arms; which ≈øo went to the heart of Drapes (then their pri≈øoner) as that he wilfully ≈øtarved him≈øelf: and a few dayes after Luterius was taken and brought to Ce≈øar. At the ≈øame time Labienus defeated tho≈øe of Triers, and the Germanes, and took all their Commanders.

After ≈øo many happy victories of Ce≈øar, obteined by him≈øelf or his Lieutenants, he fini≈øheth that ≈øummer by vi≈øiting the towns of Gallia, the better to a≈ø≈øure his conque≈øt, e≈øpecially in Ga≈øconie, where he had been but little, and di≈øper≈øeth his army (compo≈øed of ten legions) into ≈øuch places as he conceived mo≈øt advantageous; which ≈øerved him for a ≈øtrong ≈øupport to maintein him≈øelf in the civil broils of his native countrey, which he was going into.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
SOme attribute the ≈øo frequent revolts of the Gauls to their changeable and impatient humour, which cannot endure to be lorded over by ≈øtrangers: and others, to the too great clemency of Ce≈øar. I grant that clemency apt to pardon emboldens to revolt; for that we ea≈øily forget all benefits which do not intirely e≈øtabli≈øh our liberty; but if cruelty cau≈øeth them le≈ø≈øe frequent, yet it renders them more dangerous; for that when de≈øpair driveth men thereunto, and that the hope of ≈øafety re≈øteth onely in victory, the revolted become all valiant, obstinate, con≈øtant, and faithfull to the end;
which never falleth out where there is hope of the enemies clemency. We have here plentifull examples thereof. Ce≈øar in the greater part of the revolts of the Gauls hath often found great facilities to reduce them to his obedience, by rea≈øon of his clemency; which hath been a powerfull means for him to make divi≈øions among≈øt them≈øelves, and to prevent ob≈øtinacy in their revolts: and if ≈øometimes it hath ≈øo happened that he hath u≈øed ≈øeverity, it hath been occa≈øioned by fowl and unworthy acts; as when they of Vannes under publick faith impri≈øoned the Romane officers which came to them to buy corn for the ≈øu≈øtenance of the army, (but I cannot excu≈øe that of Cadenac.) On the contrary, the cruelties of the King of Spain executed by the Duke of Alba drove poore fi≈øhermen ≈øo into de≈øpair, that they have ≈øhaked off his in≈øupportable yoke; and with an admirable con≈øtancie have mainteined and enriched them≈øelves, and are grown ≈øo potent as that they are able to re≈øist him by land, and by ≈øea take from him his trea≈øure in the Indies.

Ce≈øar ≈øheweth us al≈øo by ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s care and indu≈øtry to get intelligence of the enemies proceedings (whether by taking pri≈øoners in the field, or by having good ≈øpies) the advantage which may be made thereof; many of his ≈øucce≈ø≈øefull de≈øignes having been founded thereupon, there being great advantage in the attempting them; for that he which a≈ø≈øaileth hath more courage then he which is a≈ø≈øailed, and alwayes believeth the a≈ø≈øaliant to be the ≈øtronger, not knowing what part he will a≈ø≈øail, and ever jealous that he hath ≈øome ≈øecret intelligence. Briefly, all that a well exerci≈øed and well di≈øciplined army is able to do in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, is to defend it ≈øelf; but where are new-levied ≈øouldiers fall out great di≈øorders: which was the rea≈øon he took ≈øo much care to fortifie his camp very ≈øtrongly, to the end he might defend it & all his baggage with a few men, & might without danger execute many brave de≈øignes, being alwayes a≈ø≈øured of his retreat. Let us further take view of the ≈øiege of Cadenaci which Ce≈øar judging to be impregnable by force, and knowing it to be well provided of corn, undertaketh by a great and dangerous labour to keep them from water, which was from a fountain without the town, from whence they were onely ≈øupplyed: which the be≈øi ‚Ä¢ ged perceiving, having ≈øet fire on Ce≈øars works, by a ≈øalley they hindred him from quenching it. Ce≈øar not being able to repul≈øe them by rea≈øon of the advantage of the place, re≈øolveth to make an a≈ø≈øault upon the town; which apprehen≈øion cau≈øed them to retreat.

div.head: The Abbridgement of the civil wars of Ce≈øars Commentaries. The I. Book.
div.p:
THe true cau≈øe of the civil warre between Pompey and Ce≈øar was, becau≈øe the one would have no companion, and the other could not endure a ≈øuperiour: but that which appeared, was the refu≈øall made to Ce≈øar of admitting his ≈øolicitation for the Con≈øu ‚Ä¢ ≈øhip being ab≈øent (though it had been promi≈øed him) or el≈øe becau≈øe they would have him alone di≈øarm, and that they which were his declared enemies ≈øhould continue ≈øtill armed: a forced re≈øolution, and contrary to the will of the Commons; in≈øomuch that the Tribunes of the people were con≈øtrained to quit the citie, and to go find out Ce≈øar: Who taking occa≈øion by the forelock, of his private cau≈øe he maketh a publick; declaring to his ≈øouldiers that he is not in arms to other purpo≈øe but to re≈øtore the people (now oppre≈ø≈øed by the Senate) to their libertie; and having well incouraged them thereupon, he departeth from Rimini, Ariminum. which was yet part of his gove ‚Ä¢ nment, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelf of all the marches of Ancona; which cau≈øed a great a≈øtoni≈øhment at Rome. Pompey and the Con≈øuls for≈øake the citie, and dare not gather their gro≈ø≈øe nearer then Capua: mean time Ce≈øar continuing his march be≈øiegeth Domitius Aenobarbus within Corfinium: who with all the Senatours which accompanied him were delivered
unto him by his own ≈øouldiers, which adhere to Ce≈øars partie. He gave leave to Domitius and the Senatours to di≈øpo≈øe of them≈øelves where they plea≈øed, cau≈øing all to be re≈øtored that belonged unto them. Following his de≈øigne he be≈øiegeth Pompey in Brundu≈øium: who unwilling to ≈øu≈øtein the ≈øiege, cro≈ø≈øeth the ≈øeas with his armie, which he could not do but at two times, for want of ≈øhipping; yet u≈øed he much art and precaution to conceal his retreat from Ce≈øar, and to prevent tho≈øe of Brundu≈øium from giving means to his enemie to entrap him. Ce≈øar, not being able to follow him for want of ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øendeth Valerius into the I≈øland of Sardinia, and Curio into that of Sicilia; Cotta abandoned the one, and Cato the other; complaining that Pompey had very incon≈øiderately imbarked them in this warre, and ≈øo went into Africa. Mean while Ce≈øar cometh to Rome, ju≈øtifieth his actions, and offereth to conde≈øcend to a rea≈øonable peace: but ≈øeeing that his enemies protracted time, he pa≈ø≈øeth into Gallia, to ≈øtrengthen his armie with Gauls. M ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øitia. Mar≈øeilles refu≈øeth him entrance; he be≈øiegeth it, and in the mean time ≈øendeth C. Fabius to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him≈øelf of the pa≈ø≈øages of the Pyrenean mountains; which he doth bravely. Then approcheth to Petreius and Afranius, which had their camp below Ilerda, and encampeth on the river Segre, Sicoris. where he maketh two bridges. At fir≈øt there pa≈ø≈øed onely ≈ølight skirmi≈øhes between them, untill that two of Fabius his Legions being gone to forrage by that bridge which was furthe≈øt from the camp, it happened to break; whereof the enemies being adverti≈øed, they go with foure Legions and
all their cavalrie to give on upon them; but being retreated to a hill of advantage, and Fabius mi≈ødeeming ≈øomething, going to relieve them, delivered them out of that danger. While the≈øe things were a doing, Ce≈øar having left C. Trebonius Lieutenant Generall at the ≈øiege of Mar≈øeilles, and D. Brutus commander of his naval armie, arrived in his camp; where being, he would encamp him≈øelf between Ilerda and his enemies camp; bu ‚Ä¢ after a long fight (whereof either of them made advantage) both the one and the other retreated into their camp.
