Pre≈øently after, the continuall rain carried away both the≈øe bridges, and made the river altogether unpa≈ø≈øable, which drave him to extreme nece≈ø≈øities, not being able to ≈øupply him≈øelf with victuall, nor receive tho≈øe new forces which came to him out of Gallia, nor repair his bridges by rea≈øon of the violence of the waters, and the hindrance which his enemies gave him, which were on the other ≈øide of the river: At la≈øt he cau≈øed boats to be made, and while≈øt the Pompeians bu≈øied them≈øelves to entrap certain Gauls which came to joyn with him, he carrieth boats on wagons twentie miles from his camp, putteth them into the river, cau≈øeth ≈øome ≈øouldiers to pa≈ø≈øe over to the other ≈øide, and without lo≈øing time conveyeth thither two legions more, by favour whereof he maketh his bridge: and by that means recovereth his way, and ≈øafe pa≈ø≈øage for his victuall, and receiveth tho≈øe troups which came to relieve him. This action rea≈ø≈øured his army, a≈øtoni≈øhed the enemy, and gave ≈øo much reputation to his affairs (with the news which he received at the ≈øame time,
that Brutus had defeated the Mar≈øeillians at ≈øea) that five good cities yielded them≈øelves, and divers others came to parle. But following this good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, he maketh divers trenches to cut off the water from his enemies camp, and to make the Segre fordable. Afranius and Petreius, fearing the pro≈øperitie of his de≈øignes, re≈øolved to gain Octoge≈øa, ≈øited upon the river Iberus, whither they had beforehand ≈øent to have a bridge made: To this end they depart at midnight; Ce≈øar cau≈øeth them to be pur≈øued by his cavalrie, which he maketh to ford over, becau≈øe his bridge was a great way off: afterward (leaving his baggage within his camp) he followeth with his Infantery, and pur≈øueth them ≈øo hotly that he overthroweth their de≈øigne, hindring them from going whither they intended, and returning from whence they came, in≈øomuch that he drave them into ≈øuch extremitie of hunger and thir≈øt that (without ≈øtriking one blow) they were con≈øtrained to yield them≈øelves to his mercy. He di≈ømi≈ø≈øeth them all, and winneth them by incredible courte≈øies, never u≈øed el≈øewhere towards enemies. Thus he remaineth ma≈øter of Spain, ≈øending away his enemies laden with di≈øgrace, and al≈øo with obligations to publi≈øh (though unwillingly) his clemency and valour.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
IT is a most dangerous thing for a people, a Generall of an army, or an army it ≈øelf, to be ≈øurpri≈øed with fear for that it is alwayes ≈øeconded with perver≈øe and ruinous accidents: which all Leaders and Commanders of armies ought to fore≈øee and carefully to prevent. There be three not able examples in this book on this ≈øubject; The fir≈øt,
when Ce≈øar pa≈ø≈øed the Rubicon; for before that they declared him enemy to the weal-publick. Pompey undertaketh with a ≈øtamp with his foot to rai≈øe an armie to him; that at his approch Ce≈øars own ≈øouldiers ≈øhall deliver their Generall into his hands; neither doth he think him worthie con≈øideration; ≈øuch as dare but name Ce≈øar are driven out of Rome; briefly, he is proceeded again≈øt as a criminall offender. Notwithstanding ≈øo ≈øoon as he had but ≈øet the fir≈øt ≈øtep to declare the warre, and though he did the ≈øame at Pezaro which he did at Rimini, having not the fourth part of his armie, every man was amazed; Pompey and the Con≈øuls betake them to their heels; the care of leavying of ≈øouldiers is ca≈øt a≈øide, and Rome it ≈øelf abandoned. The cau≈øes of this great change proceeded from this, that Pompey never imagined that Ce≈øar dur≈øt have undertaken ≈øo high a de≈øigne; grounding upon a pre≈øumption which his vertues and good fortune had added unto him; which made him rather thoughtfull how to maintein his partie in the citie, then provide for defen≈øe thereof: In≈øomuch that when he ≈øaw things go otherwi≈øe then he had publi≈øhed, he ≈øtood ama≈øed. It was therefore no great wonder if an ignorant people (which toke a≈ø≈øurance or fear from the good or bad countenance of him into who≈øe protection they had delivered them≈øelves) did the like. Whereupon I will ≈øay, that in affairs of ≈øuch importance we ought (in imitation of Ce≈øar) before we enter into them, to con≈øider maturely the wor≈øt that can befall, ≈øo that evil ≈øucce≈ø≈øe di≈ømayeth us not; but when we are imbarked, we mu≈øt not check at what≈øoever happeneth, but with constancie go on to the end.

The ≈øecond example is, when Domitius Aenobarbus (being out of hope of being relieved by Pompey) took a re≈øolution to ≈øave him≈øelf within Corfinium, where he was be≈øieged: but for that his countenance was ≈øadder then u≈øuall, his ≈øpeeches le≈ø≈øe re≈øolute then the time required, and by ≈øome neglect of the nece≈ø≈øary works for the common defen≈øe, he di≈øcovered to his ≈øouldiers that which he would have concealed from them, ≈øo that (preventing his flight they delivered him unto Ce≈øar. It is a fair le≈ø≈øon for a commander, to teach him that in greatest danger he ought to ≈øhew mo≈øt re≈øolution; for his ≈øouldiers become courageous or fearfull according to that they ob≈øerve in his countenance.

The third is, when Ce≈øar di≈øcovered the fear of Afranius and Petreius ≈øouldiers, in that they ≈øeconded not each other, that they ≈øcarcely had received the brunt of the cavalrie but their en≈øignes were all on a heap, that they made not good their ranks nor distances, and that they ≈øtirred not from the field of battel where they could not ≈øub≈øi≈øt for want of water. And how≈øoever in the≈øe times armies approch not ≈øo near each other as then they did, by rea≈øon of the canon; neverthele≈ø≈øe, experimented Captains will make profitable u≈øe of ≈øuch judgements. I have ≈øeen Henry the Great cha≈øe eight hundred hor≈øe with le≈ø≈øe then two hundred; judging they would not dare to combat him becau≈øe of their confu≈øion and not ob≈øerving di≈øtance ‚Ä¢ which fell out as he had foretold it.

And how≈øoever to retreat from a be≈øieged citie by a port of the ≈øea ≈øeemeth to be no very hard matter, neverthele≈ø≈øe the precautions which Pompey u≈øed to retire him≈øelf into Brundu≈øium, was that which ≈øaved him. For having to do with a people which he abandoned, and an enemy vigilant, he had been lost if he had not walled up the gates and barricadoed up all the entries into Brundu≈øium, except onely two (which were covert enough) by which his men i≈ø≈øued to the haven; becau≈øe when his la≈øt men departed from the walls, the inhabitants at the ≈øame in≈øtant of time cau≈øe ‚Ä¢ tho≈øe of Ce≈øars to mount them; for which rea≈øon in all kinds of retreats a captain cannot take too much care t ‚Ä¢ make it ≈øafe and orderly: and though he may do it whe ‚Ä¢ he plea≈øeth him≈øelf, yet mu≈øt he do it in ≈øo good time an ‚Ä¢ ≈øo readily as that he be not engaged to fight. In this place I will relate a di≈øpute between Afranius and Petreius; the one being for retreat by night, the other by day: They which were for the night alledged that they ≈øhould gai ‚Ä¢ the mountains and places of ≈øafetie before they ≈øhould be di≈øcovered: but the others judged that having to do with Ce≈øar, and he ≈øtrong in cavalrie, they ≈øhould never be able to get off from him without fighting, and in ≈øuch a ca≈øe the day was to be preferred to the night, which alwayes cau≈øeth di≈øorders in retreats; which opinion prevailed, but not at all to their advantage. For my part I hold the other opinion the better: for be≈øides that it is a mo≈øt dangerous thing to retreat in the day time, in the pre≈øence of an enemy; a well advi≈øed Captain will never engage him≈øelf to pur≈øue an army by night; for that it is hard for him to prevent falling into an ambu≈øh.

div.head: The ≈øecond Book.
div.p:
WHile≈øt things pa≈ø≈øed thus in Spain, Caius Trebonius continueth the ≈øiege of Mar≈øeilles; to the relief whereof Pompey ≈øendeth L. Na≈ø≈øidius, who joyning his navall forces with tho≈øe of the Mar≈øeillians, gave battel to Brutus, where he was beaten. The lo≈ø≈øe fell upon the Mar≈øeillians, becau≈øe they fought more ob≈øtinately then the re≈øt, as being more intere≈ø≈øed, having to con≈øerve both goods and libertie; and that which afflicted them mo≈øt was, that they had conceived too great hope of deliverance; how≈øoever they forbare not to continue a re≈øolute re≈øi≈øtance. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, the indu≈øtry of Trebonius was ≈øuch, that with mantilets and other engines he approched a Towre, which he ≈øapped,Vincae. and overthrew part of it: which ≈øo affrighted the Mar≈øeillians, as they promi≈øed to yield them≈øelves ≈øo ≈øoon as Ce≈øar ≈øhould return, and de≈øired a truce till then: Trebonius granteth it; who≈øe ≈øouldiers negligent of their guard upon confidence of the truce, on a very windy day the Mar≈øeillians make a ≈øudden ≈øalley, and burn all the engines of the Romanes. Trebonius was but little di≈øcouraged for all this, and diligently repaireth them, whereby Domitius was forced to ≈øave him≈øelf by ≈øea, before Ce≈øar's arrivall, who (though the affairs of Italy called upon him) would not leave Spain untill it was all at his devotion. There onely remained M. Varro, who at fir≈øt ≈øpake of Ce≈øar with great re≈øpect; but when he conceived his affairs ≈øtood doubtfull, he alienated him≈øelf and tho≈øe of his partie from him: in ≈øo much that after the defeat of Afranius and Petreius he found him≈øelf engaged to ≈øu≈øtein the warre.
But Ce≈øar having called an a≈ø≈øembly at Cordova, Corduba. all came thither to attend and acknowledge him, and divers towns forced from them Varro's garri≈øons: who found him≈øelf ≈øo farre for≈øaken, that of two Legions which he had, the one fell ab≈øolutely from him, in≈øomuch that he was con≈øtrained to have recour≈øe to Ce≈øars mercy as well as the re≈øt. That done, he left L. Ca≈ø≈øius Longinus in Spain, and pa≈ø≈øeth to Mar≈øeilles, which yieldeth to him; then goeth to Rome. At the ≈øame time Curio pa≈ø≈øeth from Sicilia into Africk with two Legions onely and five hundred hor≈øe, encampeth him≈øelf in a place called Cornelius camp, near ∆≤tica, where Petreius Accius Varus had his camp; again≈øt whom he had an advantageous battel with his cavalry. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, upon ≈øome di≈øcour≈øes which one S. Quintilius Varus had with Curio's ≈øouldiers, there grew a panike fear among≈øt them; which taken away by an oration he made unto them, he went and pre≈øented battel, and beat Varus again, and drove him to retreat into ∆≤tica; where (with help of the ill will the inhabitants bore him) he put him hard to it; and under≈øtanding that king Juba was coming to relieve him, Curio retireth him≈øelf into his camp, with re≈øolution there to attend the coming of the re≈øt of his army which was in Sicilie. But having intelligence that king Juba came not in per≈øon and that he onely ≈øent a weak ≈øupply under the coÃÑmand of Saburra, it cau≈øed him to change that ≈øo good a re≈øolution. Then puffed up with his former victorie, and having been more exerci≈øed in making orations to the people of Rome then in commanding their armies, he marcheth night
and day to encounter this relief: his cavalrie in the night meeteth with ≈øome of the Numidian hor≈øe, and beateth them. This ≈øucce≈ø≈øe heighteneth him more and more, in≈øomuch that he marcheth as if he had pur≈øued a victory; but thus wearied and in di≈øorder, he meeteth with a fre≈øh and complete army, which defeateth him: whereupon he concludeth it his be≈øt cour≈øe to expiate his ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe by his death, and ≈øo died a better ≈øouldier then commander.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: IT is a maxime held by all, and neglected by mo≈øt, That in the time of truce there ought to be a better guard then at any other time. We have here a notable example thereof: Trebonius by a marvellous labour had brought the Mar≈øeillians to the la≈øt ga≈øp, when during the time of a truce (which out of pitie he had granted them) his ≈øouldiers ≈øo neglected their guards that they invited the enemie to their ruine, and he ≈øaw in one houre burnt what had co≈øt him the labour of many moneths. Which ≈øhould teach us in warre never to ≈ølacken the ≈øeveritie of military di≈øcipline, though the ≈øouldiers grumble never ≈øo much: for you ought rather to content them by any other means then that; and when they ≈øhall ≈øee their commanders ≈øhare the dangers and labours of the warre with them, they will undergo them chearfully. For we may reade that by the exact ob≈øervation of military di≈øcipline many commanders have ≈øurmounted great difficulties and obteined glorious victories, and that many others for di≈øregarding it have been ≈øhamefully defeated; but it hath never been read that the ob≈øervation thereof hath been the cau≈øe of the lo≈ø≈øe of one battel or of the overthrow of any one enterpri≈øe.

A great courage without experience is likelier to commit a great errour in warre then a more temperate one: for the fir≈øt is u≈øually accompanied with pre≈øumption, and is more incapable of coun≈øel then the other; e≈øpecially when he hath made his entrie into armies by ≈øome happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe. Curio is a fair example thereof, who of a Tribune of the people ≈øeeing him≈øelf a Generall of an armie,
committed many errours, and tho≈øe not ≈ømall ones: for after that he had the good hap to beat his enemies, to ≈øhut them up into Utica, and upon the news of king Juba his coming to re≈øolve for the be≈øt, which was to retreat into his camp on the ≈øea-≈øide, well fortified and well provided of munitions, there to attend the re≈øt of his armie; upon the fir≈øt news that was brought him that the relief was weak, and that Juba was not there in per≈øon, without ≈øtaying for confirmation thereof, refu≈øing to advi≈øe with, or give credit to any, he cro≈ø≈øeth his first re≈øolution, and goeth to give them battel; after which his cavalrie meeting with ≈øome of Juba's hor≈øe, of which foure were brought pri≈øoners to him, he asked who commanded them; they an≈øwering that it was Saburra, he pre≈øuppo≈øeth that Juba was not there; ≈øo confirmeth him≈øelf in the fir≈øt errour, and marcheth ≈øo fast and ≈øo farre as that he findeth him≈øelf five and twentie miles from his camp, in a countrey which he knew not, with part of his forces (the re≈øt not being able to follow) much hurried and in di≈øorder: which was the cau≈øe that Juba ea≈øily defeated them. Which ≈øheweth us plainly, that neither a great courage alone maketh a good commander (however it helpeth well thereto) nor the reading of books, nor abilitie of di≈øcour≈øe; but it mu≈øt be atteined by long experience, and the being pre≈øent at many overthrows as well as victories: for he that hath not had his ≈øhare therein, is not able to imagine what belongeth thereto, the bravest ≈øouldiers ≈øometimes doing the poore≈øt actions, as it happened here; where (though the re≈øidue of this armie was retreated into a well-fortified camp, and not a≈ø≈øaulted, yet the≈øe imbarked them≈øelves ≈øo confu≈øedly and di≈øorderly as that a great part of them were drowned. Therefore I conclude that it is much better to make le≈ø≈øe ha≈øte and to know whither to go then to be forced ≈øhamefully to run away or peri≈øh.

div.head: The III. Book.
div.p:
CE≈øar being cho≈øen Dictatour provideth for the affairs of the city of Rome, cau≈øeth him≈øelf to be publi≈øhed Con≈øul with P. Servilius, giveth over his dictatour≈øhip at the end of eleven daies, and after imbarketh him≈øelf at Brundu≈øium,
whither he had ≈øent ≈øeven legions to attend him; but found not ≈øhipping enough for half his army; in≈øomuch that he was con≈øtrained to pa≈ø≈øe over with fifteen thou≈øand foot and five hundred hor≈øe, leaving Marcus Antonius there with the re≈øt, to whom he promi≈øeth to ≈øend back the ≈øhipping. Pompey (who had all the yeare to prepare him≈øelf) had gathered together great ≈øtore of men, victuall, and ≈øhipping, ≈øo that Ce≈øar pa≈ø≈øed over not without trouble and danger; and in≈øtantly ≈øent back his ve≈ø≈øels to Antonie: but Bibulus, chief Commander of all Pompey's navie, took a ≈øquadron of thirty of them, which he fired, and put to death all the mariners to the end to deterre the re≈øt from undertaking that pa≈ø≈øage; and did ≈øo ob≈øtinately continue his de≈øigne (notwith≈øtanding the winter-≈øea≈øon) as that he hindred Antonie from pa≈ø≈øing over. At the ≈øame time M. Octavius (Pompey's Lieutenant) be≈øiegeth Salones in Dalmatia, which defendeth it ≈øelf ≈øo couragiou≈øly as (without help of any) it compelleth him to rai≈øe his ≈øiege, and by a ≈øallie beateth him ≈øhamfully from thence; from whence he retireth to Pompey at Durazzo. Dyrrachium. On the other ≈øide, Ce≈øar having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of divers towns upon the ≈øhore, hindred him al≈øo from refre≈øhing him≈øelf. At la≈øt Bibulus dieth: and the ≈øea not being ≈øo exacty guarded, Antonie pa≈ø≈øeth over; where the winds ≈øo favour the good fortune of Ce≈øar, as that they change in the ju≈øt in≈øtant to put his navie into ≈øafetie, & to ca≈øt away that which pur≈øued it. This news coming both to him and to Pompey at one and the ≈øame in≈øtant, (becau≈øe they were encamped near each other) the one goeth to joyn him≈øelf to
Antony, which he doeth; and the other to oppo≈øe him; which though he might have done, yet returneth to encamp him≈øelf at A≈øperagne, A≈øparagus. belonging to the territory of Durrazo, and ≈øendeth to Scipio to bring his forces, and joyn with him. Ce≈øar ≈øeing that the warre was like to be drawn out at length, ≈øendeth part of his army into Macedonia and The≈ø≈øaly to make provi≈øion of corn; becau≈øe that Pompey having the command of the ≈øea, he was to expect none from out of Italy. But Scipio in his pa≈ø≈øage meeting (at the ≈øame time) with an opportunitie, thought to have cut in pieces L. C. Longinus, with ≈øome of Ce≈øars legions; which he had done had not M. Favonius (whom he had left to guard his baggage with eight cohorts) ≈øent to him that unle≈ø≈øe he made ha≈øt to relieve him, Domitius was coming to defeat him: So he de≈øi≈øted from than purpo≈øe, and arrived oportunely for the relief of Favonius. At the ≈øame time young Pompey having under≈øtood that Ce≈øar (now the third time) was ≈øending his ≈øhipping to Brundu≈øium, and having left ≈øome few at Oricum under the charge of Caninius, with three cohorts he came and a≈ø≈øailed them, and either took or fired them all. That done, Ce≈øar goeth and encampeth him≈øelf between Durazzo and Pompeys camp, to hinder him the benefit of Durazzo: but Pompey encamped at a place called Petra on the ≈øea-≈øide, where being a ≈ømall haven, by means of his ≈øhipping he receiveth ≈øome benefit by it. Then Ce≈øar attempteth to enclo≈øe him by trenches, and Pompey by other trenches enlargeth him≈øelf as much as po≈ø≈øibly he could; who finding him≈øelf the ≈øtronger in forces a≈ø≈øaileth the trenches, and in
two encounters had the be≈øt ont, and hoped to have defeated him. Ce≈øar, not being able to abide here longer, retreateth towards Apollonia and Oricum, where having mu≈øtered his army, and taken order for tho≈øe two places, he pa≈ø≈øeth into The≈ø≈øaly to joyn with Domitius his armie. Pompey followeth him, who al≈øo joyneth Scipio's forces to his own. The two armies (whereon the deci≈øion of the whole Romane Empire depended) encamp them≈øelves in ≈øight of each other. Ce≈øar ≈øought all occa≈øions to fight, and Pompey evaded them; at la≈øt he ≈øuffered him≈øelf to be overruled, fir≈øt by the revilings of his ≈øouldiers, and afterward by the valour of Ce≈øar, who pur≈øued him ≈øo fiercely after the victory of the battel of Phar≈øale, Phar≈øalia. as he gave him no lei≈øure to rally his forces, arriving in Egypt almo≈øt a≈ø≈øoon as him≈øelf, where king Ptolomee, violating the right of ho≈øpitality, & forgetting the benefits which his father had received from Pompey, cau≈øed him to be murdered, thinking by this wicked act to gain the victours favour; who revenged it, as we ≈øhall ≈øee in the book following. At the ≈øame time Ca≈ø≈øius Generall of the forces of Syria, Phenicia, and Cilicia ≈øet on fire the ≈øhipping which Pomponius kept in the port of Me≈ø≈øina; and Lalius took a little i≈øland before the port of Brundu≈øium, as Libo had done in former times. But the news of Pompey's defeat overthrew all the de≈øignes of the Lieutenants.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
IF the clemency and liberality of Ce≈øar be ≈øo much recommended in all the cour≈øe of his life, it ≈øeemeth that in this civil warre he hath out-done him≈øelf. To refu≈øe to defeat
whole and intire armies in Spain by the ≈øword, and having reduced them to yield to his mercy, to let them go with their Commanders, not ≈øo much as binding them from making war again≈øt him any more: To ≈øatisfie his enemies their ≈øtipends, whilest he borroweth money of his captains to pay his own ≈øouldiers; re≈øtoring to Domitius Aenobarbus a hundred and fifty thou≈øand crowns at a clap, which Pompey had given him out of the publick trea≈øury to make warre against him: To relea≈øe all the pri≈øoners he took without ran≈øome, and even to cau≈øe all to be restored which belonged unto them, while≈øt Bibulus, Labienus, and others, put to the ≈øword as many of his as they could take; are actions in my ob≈øervation rather to be admired then like to be imitated, e≈øpecially in an age who≈øe practice is much contrary to this genero≈øity, and even to that which he u≈øed in Gallia: where (≈øometimes) he practiced great ≈øeverity. Therefore ≈øearching into the rea≈øons which cau≈øed in him this blind clemency, who ≈øeemed cruel to his own, I conceive we ought to di≈øtingui≈øh the de≈øignes. In Gallia he was a conquerour, in ≈øuch ≈øort as when they abu≈øed his fir≈øt and naturall clemency, he u≈øed ≈øeverity; to keep tho≈øe in aw through fear which by affability could not be made pliant. But here is a civil warre, wherein (under pretext of mainteining the libertie of the people) he intendeth to bring both people and Senate into ≈øubjection. For this end he depre≈ø≈øeth all pa≈ø≈øions to attein the height of his de≈øignes. The m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e cruel his enemies are towards him, the le≈ø≈øe he ≈øpleeneth them: in≈øomuch that they which make warre again≈øt him, fear him not but in battel, and not de≈øpairing of pardon, become the more inclinable to yield upon the fir≈øt rever≈øe of fortune which befalleth them. It is not ≈øo in a civil warre, which we make not but for the defen≈øe of our per≈øon or religion: for then having no de≈øigne to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe your ≈øelf of the State, you are obliged to repell cruelty by cruelty, otherwi≈øe you ≈øhould find none to take part with you. But when you fight for rule and domination, you mu≈øt (to attein it) appear ≈øuch a one as that they may not ≈øu≈øpect either revenge or cruelty in you, and that they believe you to abound in liberality and all other ≈øorts of vertues: for no man at any time de≈øireth change of condition, but to better his own. So by this liberall re≈øolution and clemency, not continuing his Dictatour≈øhip above eleven dayes, doin nothing but by the u≈øuall order, alwayes ju≈øtifying his actions as a Protectour of the Common-wealth, ≈øhewing him≈øelf ≈øo much
the more affectionated to peace by how much Pompey held off from it, that ≈øo he might the ea≈øilier work the indignation of his citizens and ≈øouldiers again≈øt him, and by that means go the better through with the warres, he atteined the end of the highe≈øt and mo≈øt glorious de≈øigne that ever was undertaken by man.

Ce≈øar having drawn all his forces together, attempteth to fight with Pompey: and not being able to draw him to it, he undertaketh a high de≈øigne, namely, to be≈øiege him in his camp, though he were the weaker of the two. This was near Durazzo, where he goeth about to enclo≈øe him with trenches, helping him≈øelf with the advantage of little hills of difficult acce≈ø≈øe, which in my opinion induced him to this de≈øigne. The rea≈øons which he alleadgeth are, that being weak in cavalry, and wanting corn, he could not get it if Pompey's hor≈øe were at liberty; from which he ≈øhould al≈øo take away the benefit of forraging, and render it unprofitable to all the offices of war. Be≈øides, it was a way to dimini≈øh the reputation of Pompey throughout the whole Empire, and encrea≈øe his own, when it ≈øhould be reported that Ce≈øar kept him be≈øieged, and that he dur≈øt not fight with him: a matter of great con≈øequence, for that men u≈øually turn to that ≈øide which is ≈øtronge≈øt. On the other ≈øide, Pompey, being unwilling to quit the ≈øea-≈øide or Durazzo where he had made his Arcenall & Magazine, re≈øolveth not to budge: and ≈øeeing that his cavalry might ≈øuffer too much if it were hindred from forrage, he maketh an enclo≈øure of trenches of fifteen miles compa≈ø≈øe on his ≈øide. So both Generall ‚Ä¢ omit nothing that maketh for their de≈øignes. In the end Pompey finding him≈øelf di≈øcommodated by being thus cooped up, ≈øetteth upon one of the angles of Ce≈øars trenches; where he had ≈øuch advantage in two encounters which fell both in a day, that Ce≈øar confe≈ø≈øed, if he had known how to have pro≈øecuted his victory he had defeated him. By this may be ≈øeen how nece≈ø≈øary retrenchments are, & how by means thereof may be prevented to fight with an army one is fearfull of: one may al≈øo rea≈ø≈øure affrighted forces, and fami≈øh a more potent army then ones own. For the art of warre con≈øi≈øteth principally in not fighting but when men are willing; and to this end you mu≈øt take good order for your victuall, you mu≈øt well exerci≈øe your ≈øouldiers in the u≈øe of their arms, and in the ob≈øervation of all orders, and know very well how to make their retrenchments. And if Ce≈øar had had to do with any but Pompey, who ≈øhut him≈øelf up from the very beginning,
he had either ruined his army, or el≈øe compelled him to fight.

Ce≈øar ≈øeeing that he could not continue Pompey longer in that ≈øtrait, nor ≈øtay ≈øo near him without a great di≈øcommodity for want of victuall, he undertaketh to make a long retreat and for many dayes. To this end he cau≈øeth all the baggage to be ≈øent away over-night with one legion, about midnight all the re≈øt of his army ≈øaving two legions, and his cavalry (wherewith him≈øelf marched) at break of day. Pompey followeth him with all diligence, finding him quartered where he had been encamped before, and lodgeth him≈øelf al≈øo within his own old camp clo≈øe by him. But upon Ce≈øars making ≈øhew of ≈øending his cavalry to forrage (cau≈øing them to return ≈øecretly into the camp again) Pompey ≈øendeth out his hor≈øe to the ≈øame purpo≈øe in good earne≈øt; and then al≈øo the greate≈øt part of his ≈øouldiers being returned to their old camp to look for baggage which they had left behind them, Ce≈øar departeth ≈øuddenly in the ≈øame order as the day before. In≈øomuch that Pompey, not being able to pur≈øue him for the pre≈øent, & he continually marching by great journeys in the ≈øame order, leaving him no po≈ø≈øible means to overtake him, at the end of foure dayes gave over his pur≈øuit. This is a fair le≈ø≈øon to teach us how dangerous it is for armies to retreat in view of an enemy; be≈øides, how carefully we ought to avoid fighting when we retreat, and what order ought to be given that we be not pe≈øtered with the baggage; and that al≈øo a retreat is better made with a part of the army then with the whole. For if Ce≈øar were afraid to retreat in the view of Pompey, with an army ≈øo ‚Ä¢ ell exerci≈øed and accu≈øtomed to overcome, being redoubted by Pompey him≈øelf; what ≈øhould then the captains of the≈øe times do, which command armies newly levied, without order, without obedience, overlaid with baggage, the ≈øouldiers not knowing how to u≈øe their arms, nor the captains them≈øelves to teach them? Yet neverthele≈ø≈øe they would think it a blemi≈øh to their honour to make a private retreat. Certainly pre≈øumption and ignorance are two bad coun≈øellers in warre.

At the battel of Phar≈øalia Pompey was twice as ≈øtrong as Ce≈øar, e≈øpecially in cavalry, whereupon he principally grounded his victory; but he had not an army ≈øo well di≈øciplined nor ≈øo exerci≈øed to fight as Ce≈øar had: in≈øomuch that fearing that if his gave the charge they would do it di≈øorderly, he commanded them to attend the giving on of the enemy, with charge not to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rre from their places. Ce≈øar, di≈øliking that cour≈øe,
commanded his ≈øouldiers to give on upon the adver≈øe army, alledging that this exciteth the courage of ≈øouldiers to play the men, which ought rather to be increa≈øed then abated, not di≈øapproving the ancient cu≈øtome of beginning the fight with a generall ≈øhout. And experience teacheth us that in all actions of warre, he which giveth the charge redoubleth his courage, and he which is charged dimini≈øheth his.

Touching Pompey's order of battel; Having a river on his right hand, he placed all his hor≈øe on the left, promi≈øing to him≈øelf that after he had repul≈øed Ce≈øars cavalry, he ≈øhould enclo≈øe his army. Ce≈øar, judging his cavalry not of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength to re≈øist that of Pompey, ≈øtr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gtheneth it by foot, which were fitted for that purpo≈øe, and mingled among≈øt them. Be≈øides that, he taketh from every battalion one troup, whereof he compo≈øed a battalion to be as a re≈øerve, which he placeth without the ranks of the three orders of infantery, and commandeth them not to ≈øtirre to the conflict untill he appointed: ≈øo that when Pompey's hor≈øe had repul≈øed Ce≈øars (which they could not do without putting them≈øelves into di≈øorder) they met with this battalion, which put them to a ≈øudden ≈øtop, and afterward to ≈øhew their backs, and wholly to abandon the left wing of Pompey's army; by which means Ce≈øar following his advantage ea≈øily putteth all the re≈øt to rout. Whereupon we ought to ob≈øerve two things: the one, That we ought never to hazard all our troups upon one onely charge, but make a re≈øerve of the one to relieve the other: and the other, That we ought ≈øo well to ob≈øerve the di≈øtances or intervalls, as well to the flanks as the rear, that the fir≈øt troups happening to be rever≈øed, they rever≈øe not tho≈øe which ≈øhould relieve them; but to leave them a convenient ≈øpace to fall back, and to rally them≈øelves again in the rear.

If Ce≈øar knew how to conquer, he knew better how to pro≈øecute and make his benefit thereof, but in none like to this of Phar≈øalia; where he contented not him≈øelf to force the camp, to be≈øiege the re≈øt of the army on a hill whither they retired, nor to pur≈øue Pompey's per≈øon certain dayes journeys, but with three or foure thou≈øand men onely followed him ≈øo clo≈øe both by ≈øea and land, that he found him dead in Egypt, where he arrived almo≈øt a≈ø≈øoon as the other; never giving him lei≈øure to recollect him≈øelf, or reinforce his troups. Which ≈øerveth to teach us to make u≈øe of occa≈øion when it offereth it ≈øelf favourable unto us, & not to deferre that to another time which may be pre≈øently executed: for the affairs of the world are ≈øubject
to great revolutions. And the affairs which Ce≈øar yet had after the death of Pompey give us occa≈øion enough to judge, that if (in imitation of many great per≈øonages) he had gathered the fruits of his victories before they had been ripe, or tasted of repo≈øe before he had been ≈øecured, he might full well have repented thereof.

div.head: Of the Alexandrine warre written by Aulus Hircius, or Oppius. The IIII. Book.
div.p:
AS≈øoon as Ce≈øar was arrived in Alexandria with three thou≈øand two hundred foot, eight hundred hor≈øe, ten Rhodian galleys, and ≈øome ≈øhips of A≈øia, he under≈øtood of the death of Pompey; and upon the bad quarter he perceived was between the ≈øouldiers of Pompey and the people of the city he ≈øent for new Legions into A≈øia. Mean time he required to be informed of the te≈øtament of the late king Ptolemee, who had made the people of Rome his executours; and to this end ordained that Ptolemee the elde≈øt ≈øon & Cleopatra the elde≈øt daughter ≈øhould di≈øcharge their army, & come to him to give an account of their rights. But Ptolemee's Coun≈øel did not approve of this way of accommodation, and underhand ≈øendeth for his troups which were at Pelu≈øium, under the command of Achillas: whereof Ce≈øar being adverti≈øed, and that the King him≈øelf had intelligence with the ≈øaid Achillas, he deteineth him, and prepareth for defen≈øe: he giveth them the repul≈øe at their fir≈øt approch, then cantons him≈øelf in one part of the city and the re≈øt in the other part. Ar≈øinoe the Kings ≈øecond
≈øi≈øter cau≈øeth Achillas to be ≈ølain, putteth Ganymedes into his place, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth her ≈øelf of the authoritie, who continuing the former de≈øigne putteth Ce≈øar to great extremities, infecting his fre≈øh waters; which he readily remedied by digging great ≈øtore of pits. He al≈øo ≈øendeth for ≈øouldiers, ≈øhips, and arms from all parts; and upon the news which he received that the thirty ≈øeventh Legion with great provi≈øions of victuall and arms was arrived on the coa≈øt of Africa, but could not get to him by rea≈øon of contrary winds, he putteth him≈øelf alone into a ≈øhip, taketh all his ≈øhipping with his mariners onely, and putteth to ≈øea in the very face of them. The enemies, knowing him to be without ≈øouldiers, a≈ø≈øail him; he beateth them, and without other relief getteth to his legion; then returneth to Alexandria. This fir≈øt conflict affrighted the Alexandrians; neverthele≈ø≈øe they make their naval army ≈øtronger then ever, which Ce≈øar defeateth the ≈øecond time; where Euphranor Captain of the Rhodian galleys behaved him≈øelf very bravely. There is an i≈øle before the haven of Alexandria built and inhabited, which ≈øheltreth the town, and is joyned to the city by the peer, which is 900 paces long and 60 broad, upon which there were two forts. Ce≈øar thinketh it nece≈ø≈øarie to take this i≈øle, that ≈øo he may have the ≈øea at liberty. He taketh it, then taketh one of the forts of the peer: but at the other he had a hot skirmi≈øh, and was repul≈øed with ≈øo great di≈øorder as not being able to hinder the ≈øouldiers from ca≈øting them≈øelves abord, he ≈øaveth him≈øelf by ≈øwimming rather then to peri≈øh. The Alexandrians, a≈øtoni≈øhed by the≈øe brunts, betake them to
their ≈øubtilties, demand of Ce≈øar their King, who delivereth him to them, hoping it would be a means to facilitate agreement. While≈øt the≈øe things were in agitation Mithridates a Pergamenian, a man of high de≈øcent, a great ≈øouldier, of great valour and mo≈øt faithfull to Ce≈øar, arriveth to his relief with goodly forces, taketh Pelu≈øium in his way, & cometh to pa≈ø≈øe the Nile at a place called Delta. Whereof Ptolemee being adverti≈øed goeth in per≈øon to oppo≈øe him; and Ce≈øar on the other ≈øide goeth to relieve Mithridates, who, before the arrivall of either of them, had already encountred with and beaten Ptolemee's forces; and Ce≈øar al≈øo before he could come to Mithridates had defeated others. After which he goeth and a≈ø≈øaulteth a ≈ømall fort which was between his camp and that of Ptolemee's, which he taketh; and the day after he a≈ø≈øaileth the camp, which he al≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ceth; and the King attempting to ≈øave him≈øelf by water, is drowned. After which returning victorious to Alexandria, all ≈øubmi ‚Ä¢ to him. Mean time the provinces of the Empire re≈øted not quiet. Domitius Calvinus Ce≈øars Lieutenant was defeated by Pharnaces, who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the kingdome of Pontus. In Illyricum Gabinius Ce≈øars Lieutenant was defeated, and died at Salona: And Octavius one of Pompey's party, intending to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him≈øelf of that province, found Cornificius to oppo≈øe him in that de≈øigne. So did ∆≤atinius; who being a ‚Ä¢
Brundu≈øium and hearing this news putteth to ≈øea, meeteth Octavius, giveth him battel and defeateth him in Spain. Ca≈ø≈øius Longinus, whom Ce≈øar had left there, had made him≈øelf hatefull through his covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe as well to tho≈øe of
the countrey as his own ≈øouldiers. They combine again≈øt him and ≈øorely wound him, and believing him dead each one di≈øcovereth his joy: he recovering rigourou≈øly puni≈øheth the con≈øpiratours; neverthele≈ø≈øe that hindred not the revolt of his army. And as he thought to have remedied it in one place it breaketh out in another, and by a generall con≈øent they choo≈øe Marcellus for their commander, who incamped him≈øelf beneath Cordova, which was at his devotion. Longinus ≈øendeth to de≈øire aid of the King Boguld, who ≈øendeth him a great recrute: neverthele≈ø≈øe Marcellus mainteineth him≈øelf without fighting; and Lepidus coming with fre≈øh forces to labour a reconciliation between them, Longinus mi≈øtru≈øteth him, and withdraweth him≈øelf from them; but upon the approch of Trebonius his ≈øucce≈ø≈øour in the government, he imbarked for Africa where Ce≈øar had de≈øigned him, and was drowned at the mouth of the river Iberus. Let us return to Ce≈øar: who though he were much pre≈ø≈øed to vi≈øit Rome, yet would he fir≈øt revenge the defeat of Domitius; he departeth from Egypt with the ≈øixth Legion onely, leaving the re≈øt of his army for the guard of that kingdome: and with tho≈øe forces which he gathereth together in A≈øia he giveth battel to Pharnaces, defeateth him, taketh from him what he had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of, and giveth the kingdome of Bo≈øporus to Mithridates the Pergamenian as a recompen≈øe for the good ≈øervice he had done him in the Alexandrian warre: then triumphantly after ≈øo many victories he returneth to Rome.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p: OF all the warres which Ce≈øar hath made I find not one le≈ø≈øe nece≈ø≈øary, more dangerous, and wherein he hath ≈øhewed le≈ø≈øe fore≈øig ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ then in this. For having under≈øtood the death of Pompey at Alexandria, to ≈øet down there with three or foure thou≈øand men, and in this weak estate to attempt to force a young king to make re≈øtitution of part of his kingdome in favour of his ≈øister Cleopatra, was an argument that he tru≈øted much to his good fortune, or was very amourous. But as this beginning was much ≈øhort of his ordinary prudence, ≈øo the progre≈ø≈øe and the end thereof ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth all his other actions; and it ≈øeemeth that he hath not here erred but to make his vertues ≈øhine ≈øo much the brighter. This hath been a warre without rule: for he hath been put to defend cro≈ø≈øe wayes of ≈øtreets, and to barricado him≈øelf there, to di≈øpute the one half of the town again≈øt the other, to remedy unthought of accidents, to rea≈ø≈øure his ≈øouldiers, to fight with a navall army without ≈øouldiers, and to beat them; and, as if he were fallen into another world, to make a warre after a new manner. Which ≈øheweth that he excelled in three things principally; namely, that he was never left hopele≈ø≈øe, that he was of great experience, and that he confounded not him≈øelf in his commands.

This warre fini≈øhed, he goeth against Pharnaces; wherein we will onely ob≈øerve two things: the fir≈øt, that how≈øoever he de≈øired to fini≈øh this war ≈øpeedily, becau≈øe his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe required him el≈øewhere, yet he goeth not to a≈ø≈øault him ra≈øhly, but alwayes beginneth by encamping him≈øelf ≈øtrongly; then (having left his baggage in ≈øafetie) he goeth with all his armie to make another camp near to Pharnaces, leaving a great valley between both; to the end that if he would hinder him from fortifying there, and a≈ø≈øault him, he could not get to him without great di≈øadvantage. The other is to ≈øhew the advantage which he hath that a≈ø≈øaileth: for Ce≈øar him≈øelf ob≈øerveth, that though Pharnaces a≈ø≈øaulted him ra≈øhly, yet his ≈øouldiers were ≈øtruck with fear, and put into ≈øome di≈øorder upon their fir≈øt approch. Which may ≈øerve to confirm that he which a≈ø≈øaileth hath a great advantage, and that there is nothing more nece≈ø≈øary in warre then retrenchments.

div.head: Of the Africane war, written by Aulus Hireius, or Oppius. The V. Book.
div.p:
THe broken forces of Pompey's partie being rallied in Africa under Scipio, Cato, and king Juba, Ce≈øar goeth thither in the moneth of December, and arriveth there at the beginning with no more then onely three thou≈øand foot and ≈øome few hor≈øe. He pre≈øenteth him≈øelf before Adrumetum, but Con≈øidius ≈øeeing him ≈øo weak ≈øtandeth upon his guard: and Ce≈øar in his retreat was a≈ø≈øaulted by a ≈øally from the town, and by the hor≈øe which were come to their aid, which he repul≈øeth: where it was ob≈øerved that thirtie French hor≈øemen put above two thou≈øand Moors to the recoil. The fame of his arrivall opened the gates of many cities and ca≈øtles, which furni≈øhed him with victuall. He made choice of the ≈øite of Ru≈øpina to encamp him≈øelf, and there to expect the re≈øt of his armie; but not having patience to attend, he goeth to the port, imbarketh him≈øelf, and goeth to find them out; and as he was about to hoi≈øe ≈øail a good part of them arrive. After that he goeth with thirty cohorts to look about for corn, and in the way meeteth with Labienus, with whom he had a great skirmi≈øh, and had the be≈øt on't, and ≈øo retired him≈øelf into his camp, which he fortified more then ever, becau≈øe he found him≈øelf weak. He drew two trenches from the town to the port for his better ≈øecuritie: then he di≈øpatcheth into Sicilia, Sardinia and Italy, for
≈øupplies of men and corn. On the other ≈øide Scipio and Cato, de≈øirous to fight with him before he ≈øhould gather more ≈øtrength, ha≈øten Juba to come with his armie: but he, being on his march towards them, is con≈øtrained to turn back the ≈øame way he came, by rea≈øon that P. Sitius Ce≈øars Lieutenant, and king Bogud a≈ø≈øaulted his kingdome. Mean time Labienus joyneth with Scipio; they come and encamp near Ce≈øar: both ≈øides attempt to take advantages, and divers skirmi≈øhes pa≈ø≈øe between them, yet without hazarding a battel. Ce≈øars nece≈ø≈øities increa≈øed dayly, which he ≈øupported with great con≈øtancy, and onely mainteined the hopes of his own ≈øide by chearfull words and looks: he di≈øpatcheth others to ha≈øten his troups and victuall: ≈øome of his ≈øhips are ca≈øt away; and hearing that others were chaced even into the port of Leptis, he po≈øteth thither with all ≈øpeed po≈ø≈øible, imbarketh, and with what he could there gather together goeth and relieveth his men, chaceth his enemies, taketh ≈øome of their ≈øhips, and recovereth his own which were taken. At la≈øt his troups come from divers parts, he beginneth with purging his army of ≈øome ≈øeditious per≈øons and libertines; then re≈øolveth upon a definitive battel. To this end he goeth and encampeth before Thap≈øus, which he environeth with trenches, not doubting but Scipio would come and relieve the town: who having cau≈øed king Juba to return again, they come and encamp near Ce≈øar in three ≈øeverall camps. And there was the battel fought, which Ce≈øar gained with lo≈ø≈øe of fiftie ≈øouldiers onely, and ≈øome few hurt: but on the other ≈øide were ten thou≈øand
≈ølain, and the three camps taken. Thap≈øus on the report of this victory was yielded to C. Rebilius. Cato ≈øeeing he could not prevail with his men to re≈øolve to defend them≈øelves killeth him≈øelf. ∆≤tica openeth her gates to the Victour: Adrumetum doth the like. Zama ≈øhutteth hers again≈øt her conquered king, and calleth in Ce≈øar: all the re≈øt of Juba his kingdome revolteth: he and Petreius kill each other through de≈øpair. Sitius having defeated and killed Saburra Juba's Lieutenant, and coming to Ce≈øar, meeteth with Afranius and Fau≈øtus Sylla, which were going for Spain: the≈øe he defeateth and taketh pri≈øoners, who afterwards in an uprore were both ≈ølain. Scipio and divers Senatours, having imbarked them≈øelves for Spain, were by a tempe≈øt ca≈øt among≈øt Sitius his fleet, where all peri≈øhed or killed them≈øelves. This was the ≈øequele of that battel, wherein all things concurred (as if by con≈øent) to ≈ømooth the way to Ce≈øars ab≈øolute victory, who pardoned all that had recour≈øe unto his clemencie, and after that returned to Rome.

div.head: Ob≈øervations.
div.p:
CE≈øar hath done three things in this warre which came near to ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe: the fir≈øt, to pa≈ø≈øe into Africa in the dead of winter with a ≈ømall force, not having any a≈ø≈øured port there, for which cau≈øe he was not able to appoint any Rendes-vous for his ≈øhipping; which thing was imputed him as a want of fore≈øight. Neverthele≈ø≈øe after his pa≈ø≈øage his manner of proceeding was altogether admirable: He maketh choice to encamp him≈øelf near the citie Ru≈øpina, which was within half a league of the port, which he joyneth to the citie and his camp, and fortifieth it exceedingly: for from thence he had one foot on land and the other on the Sea, and could (as occa≈øions ≈øhould require)
act by either ≈øea or land, and be ≈øecured from being ≈øhut up, what≈øoever ≈øhould befall. This is a good le≈ø≈øon for ≈øuch as enterpri≈øe upon a forrein countrey, being weak at the beginning: for in this po≈øture great attempts may be withstood, and in all extremitie a good retreat may be made. The ≈øecond, to leave his army near Ru≈øpina, and without giving knowledge to any man to ca≈øt him≈øelf abord to go ≈øeek his ≈øhipping. And the third, having news of the defeat of his fleet, to leave his camp, to hasten in full carier to Leptis, to ca≈øt him≈øelf into a ≈øhip, and to rally others, and a≈ø≈øault the enemies: and although he peri≈øhed in none of them, there can be nothing ≈øaid in his defen≈øe, but that he tru≈øted wholly to his good fortune, and that he never was wearied or di≈øheartned in the mo≈øt dangerous or laborious de≈øignes.

It is ob≈øervable that Ce≈øar in all his warres hath alwayes been inferiour to his enemies in number; for which cau≈øe he hath alwayes helped him≈øelf by fortifications, more then ever any other hath done, which he made much the better when he found him≈øelf not ≈øufficiently ≈øtrong to give battel, as he was a long time in Africa; in≈øomuch that Scipio him≈øelf wondered at his coldne≈ø≈øe: neverthele≈ø≈øe he alwayes continued his ≈øouldiers in exerci≈øe, and him≈øelf exerci≈øed new-levied men, and entred them by ≈ømall ≈økirmi≈øhes, wherein by his indu≈øtry for the most part he had the be≈øt; and alwayes attempted ≈øomething upon his enemy. Which is an excellent maxime to give courage to your ≈øouldiers, and ≈øecure you from being ≈øurpri≈øed.

div.head: The Spani≈øh warre again≈øt Pompey's ≈øonnes. The VI. Book.
div.p:
THe reliques of the Africane troups rea≈ø≈øemble them≈øelves once more in Spain under Cneus and Sextus, the ≈øonnes of Pompey. Ce≈øar goeth thither: He findeth the one laying ≈øiege to ∆≤lla, and the other in Cordova. He ≈øendeth relief into the fir≈øt, and goeth and encampeth him≈øelf
before the other: which inforceth Cneus to quit his ≈øiege to relieve his brother. Some skirmi≈øhes pa≈ø≈øed between both armies: but Ce≈øar, not being able to draw his enemy to battel, goeth and be≈øiegeth Ategua, and after a bold re≈øi≈øtance he taketh it in view of Cneus. Afterwards both armies had divers encounters and combats, but to little purpo≈øe: at la≈øt they encamp them≈øelves in a champain near Munda, both re≈øolving not to refu≈øe battel: neverthele≈ø≈øe
‚Ä¢ neus took a high an ‚Ä¢ advantageous ground for his field of battel, where Ce≈øar making difficultie to a≈ø≈øail him was put upon it by the fury of his ≈øouldiers. The fight was long and doubtfull, even by his own confe≈ø≈øion, and with much ado he got the victory, which was bloudy. Thirtie thou≈øand on Pompey s part died upon the place, and a thou≈øand on Ce≈øars: they which ≈øaved them≈øelves into Munda were con≈øtrained to yield them≈øelves. Sextus Pompeius abandoneth Cordova: Cneus is ≈øwiftly pur≈øued, overtaken and killed. All places yield them≈øelves to the victour. This was Ce≈øars la≈øt battel, and the deadly wound to Pompey's party.

div.head: The military order of the Grecians: and particularly of their Phalanx.
div.p: THe order of the Grecians is but ob≈øcurely to be found among≈øt their authours, becau≈øe the mo≈øt part of the books which they have written thereof are lo≈øt, and none have come to our hands but fragments, ≈øo that it is hard to collect it very exactly. The Phalanx was formed after this manner.
Zugos, Jugum, ≈øignifieth two men in front, and more joyned together make a rank; and ≈øo the word is often taken.
Stichos, Ver≈øus, ≈øignifieth two men one behind the other, and more behind each other make a file; and ver≈øus is often taken for a file.

Lochos, Decurio, ≈øignifieth a file, which the Grecians made of ≈øeverall depths, but never exceeded the number of ≈øixteen, as being ≈øufficient to ≈øu≈øtein the violente≈øt charge: conceiving that to give a greater depth to their Phalanx was but to imploy men unprofitably; and that it was better to extend the battalia into breadth, to prevent overwinging, and ≈øo to be charged on the flanks, or el≈øe by this means to overwing the enemie, then to give ≈øo great a depth to their Phalanx.

The Phalanx was compounded of hoplitae onely (that is, heavie-armed) with ≈øari≈ø≈øas
(that is, long pikes) and their bucklers: for the archers, ≈ølingers, and other ca≈øting-weapons had their orders apart.
In a Lochos or file of 16 men, there were five which had command; namely, the fir≈øt, fifth, ninth, thirteenth, and ≈øixteenth; as we may ≈øee by the figure following, and their names.

div.head: The fir≈øt figure.
div.p: They made the mo≈øt valiant the File-leader, and the mo≈øt prudent the Bringer up.
Now to begin their order; They joyned two files together, which made 32 ≈øouldiers; & tho≈øe two files ≈øo joyned they called Dilochia, and the Commander of the≈øe two files they called Dilochites.
Then they doubled the number of tho≈øe two files, which made foure files and 64 ≈øouldiers; and this troup they called Tetrarchia, which had a Commander called Tetrarcha.
After that they doubled the number of the≈øe, which made eight files and 128 ≈øouldiers; and this body was called Taxiarchia, and their Commander Taxiarcha.
Then they doubled tho≈øe eight files, ≈øo made them 16: and this body was called Syntagma, and the Commander of this body was called Syntagmatarcha.
To this body they appointed five generall officers: An En≈øigne, a Lieutenant, a Trumpeter, (for they had no Drumme) a Cryer, and a Sergeant.
The En≈øigne was placed in the middle of the fir≈øt rank, as all will appear by the figure following.

div.head: The ≈øecond figure.
div.p: The Phalanx was compo≈øed of ≈øixteen bodies, like to the foregoing figure.
This body of 16 files they doubled, which made 32 files, and called it Pentaco≈øiarchia, and the Commander of it Pentaco≈øiarcha.
Then the≈øe 32 files they doubled, which made 64; and this body they called Chiliarchia, and the Commander Chiliarcha.
The≈øe 64 files being doubled made 128 files, and were called Merarchia, and their Commander Merarcha.

And 128 files being doubled make 256, called Phalangia, and the Commander Phalangiarchos; ≈øo that the Phalanx is compo≈øed of 4096 ≈øouldiers, and of one Phalangiarchos, which commanded in chief, two Merarchas, foure Chiliarchas, eight Pentaco≈øiarchas, 16 Syntagmatarchas, 32 Taxiarchas, 64 Tetrarchas, and 128 Dilochites, as the next figure ≈øheweth.

div.head: The third figure.
div.p: Now according to the ability of their Commonwealths they augmented this army by doubling the Phalanx, which was called Diphalangarchia, and the Commander Diphalangarcha: or by doubling the Diphalangarchia, and this they called Tetraphalangarchia, and the Commander Tetraphalangarchos: who then was the highe≈øt Commander: And this they held to be a complete army, which afterward hath been called a Phalanx. Neverthele≈ø≈øe it was alwayes divided into foure bodies as foure Phalanges, and was compo≈øed of 16384 ≈øouldiers.

div.head: The fourth figure.
div.p: This is the order of the Grecian phalanx for the heavy-armed, called hoplitae, namely, of pikes and targets; which took up (allowing ≈øix foot for each ≈øouldier, and without accounting the three intervalls) ≈øix thou≈øand one hundred fourty foure foot in breadth, and ninetie ≈øix foot in depth.

To this army they joyned half that number of light-armed ≈øouldiers, called P≈øyllagi, which fought from afarre off with flying and ca≈øting-weapons, and were ordered into battalia behind the Phalanx in equall front (but that their files were but eight deep) in the ≈øame order, and with the ≈øame officers: And when they were to begin the battel, they pa≈ø≈øed through the intervalls and a≈ø≈øailed the enemy; when the armies were drawn ≈øo near each other as to come to the ≈øhock, they retreated by the ≈øame intervalls into their places behind the heavy-armed, and over their heads poured a ≈øhowre of ≈øtones, darts, and arrows upon their enemies, and fortified the depth of the Phalanx to ≈øu≈øtein the ≈øhock, being now of 24 men in depth.

div.head: The fifth figure.
div.p: Concerning the cavalrie, they alwayes placed them on the wings: and whether it were the cavalrie or the infantery, they changed the form of their order according to the ≈øite of the places, or to the number of the enemies forces with whom they had to do, or to the order wherein they were ranged into battalia, enlarging the front by le≈ø≈øening the depth, & doubling their front by the half files, as Cyrus did in the battel which he fought agai≈øt Cre≈øus; for fearing to be overwinged, he made his files (which were 24 deep) but 12, and ≈øo augmented the front of his army by the one half.

Be≈øides they made u≈øe of ≈øeverall orders of battalia according to occa≈øions; as the Orb, and the light-armed in the middle, to ≈øu≈øtein a ≈øtrong charge on all parts; or the Wedge, the better to enter into a battalion; or a Half-moon to enclo≈øe or overwing; and others, which are of no great u≈øe in the≈øe times.

And that they might not confound them≈øelves in ≈øuch orders when occa≈øions ≈øerved, they had publick Schools, where all the younger ≈øort of men went to exerci≈øe them≈øelves, which they called Gymna≈øia, and had Ma≈øters to teach the u≈øe of arms and motions, called Tactici. Now to perform all the motions they allowed to every ≈øouldier ≈øix foot of ground ≈øquare; and for fight, three foot; and to ≈øu≈øtein a violent charge
they ≈øerried them ≈øo as they took up but a foot and a half.

By this means it was that ≈øo many ≈ømall Commonwealths of the Grecians maintained their liberties ≈øo long, & have performed ≈øo brave actions, having repul≈øed ≈øo great armies with ≈øo ≈ømall forces, and having even planted their tropheys in A≈øia and el≈øewhere; untill their divi≈øions overthrew them: which Philip dextrou≈øly laying hold on brought them to ≈øubjection; and after that, Alexander his ≈øonne with them and their Militia conquered a great part of the world.

It is true indeed that the con≈øtitution of tho≈øe Commonwealths was more proper for a happy mainteining of their liberty then to encrea≈øe them≈øelves: for how≈øoever they all addicted them≈øelves to arms, ≈øo that none were exempted from them, yet their poverty, and the ≈ømall number of ≈øouldiers of every Commonwealth apart by it ≈øelf, hindred them from making any great progre≈ø≈øe; ≈øo did their divi≈øions; it being a hard matter that ≈øo many ≈øovereigne Commonwealths ≈øhould agree together, unle≈ø≈øe it were in a common nece≈ø≈øity, to defend them≈øelves, as they did divers times again≈øt the Per≈øians; but not for a conque≈øt, where men cannot agree, neither about places of command, nor about ≈øharing of what is gotten.

Concerning their retrenched camp, which they called Aplectos, they cho≈øe rather ≈øtrong ≈øites, then that they fortified them by indu≈øtry neither had they any certain form, as the Romans had, but according to the advantage of places they fortified one part more then another: and hereof there is nothing certain to be found in writing among≈øt ancient Authours.

div.head: The Militarie di≈øcipline of the Romanes.
CHAP. I. Of the election of ≈øouldiers, and their arms.
div.p: ROmulus having built the citie of Rome divided it into centuries and militarie orders; every body conteined foure thou≈øand foot and three hundred hor≈øe: Now becau≈øe the mo≈øt valiant were cho≈øen, it was called Legio, which ≈øignifieth as much as a ≈øelect company.

The citie being more populous by the addition of the Sabines, the Legions were doubled, which then became to be of ≈øix thou≈øand foot and ≈øix hundred hor≈øe; yet after that they have been of a greater number.

Tullus Ho≈øtilius third king of the Romanes e≈øtabli≈øhed military exerci≈øe, and di≈øtingui≈øhed all the people into five Cla≈ø≈øes or orders. They of the fir≈øt Cla≈ø≈øis (as being the riche≈øt) were bound to mount and arm them≈øelves to ≈øerve on hor≈øeback. The three following Cla≈ø≈øes were imployed on foot, and (according to their means) were Ha≈øtati Principes, or Triarii, and were bound to arm them≈øelves according as their order required. The fifth and la≈øt Cla≈ø≈øis, as being too poor, was exempt from going to the war. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, after that the Romanes made war by ≈øea, which was foure hundred eighty nine yeares
after the foundation of the citie, they cho≈øe out the able≈øt of this fifth Cla≈ø≈øis to make them ≈øerve at ≈øea; and yet they obliged them (in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øitie) to ≈øerve twentie years among≈øt the land-forces.

None could attein to the office of a civil magi≈øtrate in Rome unle≈ø≈øe he had ≈øerved ten years in the warre; nor by that could be capable of any ≈øuch office, unle≈ø≈øe he were twentie ≈øeven years of age: for at ≈øeventeen yeares of age they were inrolled, and then entred into the warre, and ended their ≈øervice at forty five years of age. They were obliged during the≈øe twentie eight years to ≈øerve fifteen: and when they had accompli≈øhed their ≈øervice, they were no more tied to take arms, but onely for the guard and defen≈øe of the citie.

After that the kings were driven out of Rome, they cho≈øe every year two Con≈øuls in their ≈øtead: Then tho≈øe Con≈øuls cho≈øe twenty foure military Tribunes, but afterwards the people would choo≈øe them: fourteen of them were to have ≈øerved already five years in the warres, and the other ten a longer time; namely in the infantery, eleven years; and in the cavalrie, fifteen years: which ≈øheweth what e≈øteem they had of their foot above their hor≈øe.

The Con≈øuls every year called out of all the Tribes ≈øuch as were from ≈øeventeen yeares of age to fourtie five to the Capitole or to Campus Martius: and ≈øuch as dd not there make their appearance were rigourou≈øly puni≈øhed; which was ea≈øily di≈øcovered, for by the ordinances of Tullus Ho≈øtilius they kept a regi≈øter of all that were born, and
that died: now they of the territorie were reckoned into the number of inhabitants as well as they which dwelt within the citie.

They alwayes cho≈øe foure Legions, two for each Con≈øul; ≈øometimes they levied more, but very ≈øeldome, and that according to the nece≈ø≈øitie of their affairs: And even in the time of Hannibal they had twentie three Legions, and yet every Con≈øul had but two, the re≈øt being commanded by Praetors, Procon≈øuls, and other officers. But after that the Common-wealth grew more powerfull, and their laws grew weaker, there have been under Ce≈øar in the warres of Gallia ten Legions.

Before they proceeded to election of their ≈øouldiers, they divided the twentie foure Tribunes among≈øt the 4. Legions: namely, of the fourteen younge≈øt of them they gave foure to the fir≈øt Legion, three to the ≈øecond, foure to the third, and three to the fourth: and of the ten elde≈øt they gave two to the fir≈øt, three to the ≈øecond, two to the third, and three to the fourth. By this means there were ≈øix militarie Tribunes for every Legion, and in every one both old and young ones.

The Tribunes being thus di≈øparted and divided into foure parts, the Tribes were drawn by lot; and of the fir≈øt they cho≈øe foure men of a like qualitie as near as could be: of the≈øe foure the ≈øix Tribunes of the fir≈øt Legion cho≈øe one; the ≈øix of the ≈øecond cho≈øe the ≈øecond; the ≈øix of the third, the third; and the ≈øix of the fourth had the fourth man Then they cho≈øe foure more, whereof the Tribunes of the ≈øecond Legion began to choo≈øe the fir≈øt; they of the third, the ≈øecond;
they of the fourth, the third; and they of the fir≈øt Legion took the fourth man which was left And ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øively they made their cho ‚Ä¢ ce throughout all the Tribes: In≈øomuch that by this choice the ≈øouldiers of the fir≈øt Legion had no advantage over tho≈øe of the la≈øt, but were all equally formed.
After the election thus made of the Infanterie, the Cen≈øor elected the Cavalrie.

Concerning the number of ≈øouldiers of every Legion, it hath differed at divers times. For the Infanterie, it hath been 3000, 3200, 4000, 4200, 5000, 5200, 6000, 6200, alwaies following that proportion of number, for the convenience which they found in it for the readie dividing them and forming of their Maniples, Centuries, and Cohortes.
So in their Cavalrie, it hath been at divers times 200, 220, 250, 300, 320, 330, 350, and 400.

The election being thus made, the Tribunes of every Legion made them take the oath one by one, (holding up their right hand, and rai≈øing up the thumb of that hand) to obey and perform what≈øoever ≈øhould be commanded them by thei ‚Ä¢ ≈øuperiours.

At the ≈øame time the Con≈øuls commanded the magi≈øtrates of Italy to make their elections afte ‚Ä¢ the ≈øame manner among≈øt the Allies of the Romanes, among≈øt which there was cho≈øen a like number of Infantery, and double the number of Cavalrie: ≈øo that in a Con≈øular armie there mu≈øt be foure Legions, two Romane and two Auxiliars.

That done, they were ≈øuffered to depart, having
a ≈øet day given them to meet at a place appointed without arms, where the Tribunes cho≈øe the younge≈øt and the poore≈øt to be Velites; the next, to be Ha≈øtati; the more vigorous, to be Principes; and the elder ≈øort, to be Triarii.

Then they were armed, and therein they ≈øometime varied: but mo≈øt u≈øually the arms of the Velites were a morion, a ≈ømall target, darts, and a ≈øword. Their archers and ≈ølingers were called extraordinary, and were auxiliars. The Hastati bare targets of foure foot high, an head-piece, and a ≈ømall brea≈øt of the cuirace: The richer ≈øort of them bare the whole cuirace, a ≈øword on the right thigh, (being ≈øhort, broad, and ≈øharp-pointed, and cutting on both ≈øides) and two darts to ca≈øt. The Principes and Triarii bare the like arms; onely the Triarii in ≈øtead of darts had javelins.
Concerning the Cavalrie; that was but ill armed at the beginning; but it learned of the Grecians afterwards to be armed with a cuirace, a buckler, and a ca≈øting-javelin.
The Allies (a≈øwell hor≈øe as foot) were armed and di≈øciplined as the Romanes.

Be≈øides the foure bodies of Velites, Ha≈øtati, Principes and Triarii, the ancient authours al≈øo make mention of Tirones, Rorarii, and Accen≈øes, all which were young ≈øouldiers, either Romanes or Auxiliars, and (in my opinion) fought not but with ca≈øting-weapons. And in effect there was no other body of the Infanterie among≈øt the Romanes but of tho≈øe three orders, the Ha≈øtati, Principes, and Triarii: for even the Velites had no body apart by them≈øelves, being both in the orders of battalias, as al≈øo in the encampings,
entermixed among≈øt the other three orders, and began not to be imployed by the Romanes but at the ≈øiege of Capua.

The election being made, the ≈øouldiers armed, and the orders formed, the Tribunes ≈øeparated every order by Centuries or Cohorts, then made two elections of ten men apiece: they of the fir≈øt were the more honourable, a≈ø≈øi≈øted at the coun≈øel of warre, and were as the Captains of our time; they of the ≈øecond repre≈øented our Lieutenants. Indeed all of them were called Centurions, but they of the fir≈øt election were called fir≈øt Centurions, and the other, ≈øecond Centurions. After that, the Centurions cho≈øe their Vexillarii, which are the En≈øignes of our times, and there were two of them in every Cohort. Then they cho≈øe twentie Tergiductores, which were Rear-commanders of the troups: ≈øo that in every Cohort there were two commanders for the front, and two for the rear.

div.head: CHAP. II. The divi≈øion of a Legion of 4200 foot and 300 hor≈øe.
div.p: A Legion was alwayes divided into five bodies: namely the Infantery into foure bodies, called Velites, Hastati, Principes, Triarii; and the Cavalrie into one. Every body was divided into ten troups, which among≈øt the Infantery were called Cohorts or Maniples, and among≈øt the Cavalrie were called Turmes.

In the three fir≈øt orders of Infanterie were 1200 ≈øouldiers apiece, each of which make ten
troups of 120 ≈øouldiers: and in the la≈øt, namely the Triarii, there were onely 600 men, which make ten troups of 60 men apeece.
The body of Cavalrie was of 300, which maketh ten troups of thirtie ≈øouldiers apiece.

Among≈øt authours there is a diver≈øitie in the names of Cohorts, Centuries, and Maniples, which here do ≈øignifie one and the ≈øame thing; but in ≈øome places of Titus Livius you may ≈øee the di≈øtinction from a Legion to a Cohort, from a Cohort to a Centurie, from a Centurie to a Maniple. Which I conceive grew from this, that when the Legions grew to be of 6000 and 7000 men, they then made tho≈øe ≈øubdivi≈øions.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of marching.
div.p: WHen they were to march, at the fir≈øt ≈øound of the trumpet they took down their pavilions, and packed up the baggage; at the ≈øecond they loded it; and at the third they parted away from their quarter: But none were allowed to take down their pavilion, untill the Con≈øuls and Tribunes had taken down theirs. The extraordinaries marched fir≈øt; then the right wing of the Allies, and their baggage in their rear; then the ≈øecond Legion, and their baggage after them; then the left wing of the Allies, and their baggage following them: the cavalrie was in the van and rear, and ≈øometimes in the flanks, thereafter as the enemy was to be ≈øu≈øpected.

Every Romane Legion with one wing of the Allies marched in the van by turns, that ≈øo
every one might have the commoditie of arriving fir≈øt at the camp.

If in the march there were greater ≈øu≈øpicion on the rear then on the van, or on the flanks, they ≈øtrengthened them≈øelves there accordingly. This was their ordinary manner of marching; but I find in Ce≈øar, that when he marched in an enemies territories, and particularly in a countrey inclo≈øed with hedges and woods, he made all the Legions to march in one body, then all the baggage together, leaving onely ≈øome new-levied troups on the rear thereof to guard it. When the army marched in three equidi≈øtant bodies, namely all the Ha≈øtati, a≈øwell Romanes as Allies, together, having their baggage before them, then the Principes and Triarii in the ≈øame order, the extraordinaries and cavalrie were to be on the flanks and on the van to ≈øecure the baggage, or at lea≈øt on tho≈øe parts where the mo≈øt danger was: And being ≈øo ordered, when an occa≈øion of fight befell, on what part ≈øoever it were, on a ≈øudden all the troups could be drawn out very ea≈øily (without being troubled by the baggage) to go and affront the enemy.

When the army drew near to the quarter, the Tribunes and Centurions ordained for that work marched before to con≈øider of the ≈øite of the camp: Which being made choice of, they fir≈øt marked out the place for the Con≈øuls lodging, or of the Generall, with a white banner; then they di≈øtingui≈øhed his lodging from others by a red banner; then with a ≈øecond red banner they marked out the Tribunes quarters; then with a third they divided and di≈øtingui≈øhed the lodgings of the Legions from the fore-mentioned
ones: after that they gave to every one their proportion of ground, which they marked with banners of other colours: then with a line they quickly marked out and divided all the lodgings, becau≈øe they never changed the mea≈øures nor form of the camp; and that they were exceeding well accu≈øtomed thereunto, by having alwayes the ≈øame way of encamping.
When the army arrived, every troup took notice of their lodging by the marks and banners; ≈øo that all went to them without confu≈øion, and without mi≈øtaking.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of embattelling the Army.
div.p: THey quartered their foure bodies of Velites, Hastati, Principes, and Triarii, under the name onely of the three la≈øt; and they divided and intermixed the Velites among≈øt the three other bodies: as may be ≈øeen in that which followeth.

The Romanes allowed ten foot ≈øquare of ground to lodge two ≈øouldiers; in≈øomuch that allowing 100 foot breadth of ground, and 1000 in depth, there was ≈øufficient to lodge 2000 ≈øouldiers: and ≈øo ten cohorts of Ha≈øtati, which made but 1680 ≈øouldiers, were lodged ≈øufficiently, and had room enough be≈øides for their baggage.
The ≈øame proportion of ground was allowed to the Principes, becau≈øe they con≈øi≈øted of the ≈øame number.
And the moity of that ground was given to the Triarii, becau≈øe their number was but the half of that.
To the cavalrie they allowed for thirty hor≈øes 100 foot ≈øquare; and for 100 Turms 100 foot in breadth and 100 foot in depth apiece.

For the allies they allowed the ≈øame proportion of ground to their infantery as they did to the Romane legions; but becau≈øe the Con≈øul took the fifth part of the legions of the allies near to him≈øelf, they cut off al≈øo the fifth part of ground in this place, which they allowed them el≈øewhere.

Concerning the cavalrie of the allies, it was alwayes double to that of the Romanes: but the Con≈øul taking a third part of theÃÑ to lodge round about him, there remained in the ordinary lodgings but one fourth part more of them then of the Romanes: and becau≈øe the ≈øpace of ground was more then ≈øufficient for them, their ground was not inlarged, but they had 100 foot in breadth and 100 foot in depth, as the Romanes.
This quarter was divided by five ≈øtreets, each of them of fifty foot in breadth; and divided in the middle by a ≈øtreet called Quintana, of the ≈øame length as the other.

At the front of the quarter there was a great ≈øtreet of 100 foot broad, next which the twelve Tribunes were lodged, ju≈øt over again≈øt the two Romane legions; and the twelve Prefects were quartered ju≈øt over again≈øt the two legions of allies: there was 50 foot ≈øquare allowed to each of the≈øe lodgings. Then there was the Con≈øuls lodging, called the Praetorium, which conteined 200 foot ≈øquare, and was placed in the middle of the breadth of the camp. On the right and left hand of the Con≈øuls lodging, there were two void places, the one for the market-place, the other for the Que≈øtor. On each ≈øide of the≈øe they lodged the 400 hor≈øe and 1630 foot which the Con≈øul drew out of the two legions of the allies, as al≈øo the voluntaries: and be≈øides that ≈øome lodgings were re≈øerved for the extraordinaries which might happen to come to the army, as wel cavalry as infantery; and the≈øe together made a perfect ≈øquare.

After all the lodgings were appointed, there was a ≈øpace left round about them of 200 foot broad: then they made a retrenchment, whereof the moat was more or le≈ø≈øe in depth & breadth, and the rampart higher or lower, thereafter as the enemy was more or le≈ø≈øe to be feared.

It is to be ob≈øerved that the infantery was alwayes quartered the neare≈øt to the trenches, as they which were to defend them, and which were to ≈øhelter the hor≈øe, which were lodged in the middle of the quarters. The figure following will make all this more plain.
