div.p: When the Con≈øuls armie was compo≈øed of more then foure Legions, they were quartered after the ≈øame manner, the one on the ≈øide of the other; ≈øo that in ≈øuch a ca≈øe the camp was a long ≈øquare. And when both the Con≈øuls armies were joyned and made but one camp, they took up the room of two ≈øquares. Sometimes both camps were near each other, but ≈øeparated.

Here Polybius hath omitted the number of the gates of the camps, and their names, and where they were placed, how the enclo≈øure of the camp was made, the lodgings for the Con≈øuls two Lieutenants (one for each Legion) of the Que≈øtor (who was their Trea≈øurer) of the Prefect of the camp (who was the fi≈øcall or mar≈øhall judge) of the twelve Prefects of the Allies, of the victuall, the arms, and the engines for war, of the apparel, and what the tents were made of; which (with the help of ≈øome authours, and according to probabilitie) we will here ≈øupply.
Fir≈øt we find in ≈øeverall hi≈øtories that the camp had foure gates, placed and called as is ≈øhewed in the foregoing figure.

Concerning the enclo≈øure of the camp, we reade al≈øo that they made the rampart of the earth which they took out of the moat; and to make the earth hold together they planted two or three rows of ≈øtakes, about which they enterlaced bru≈øh-wood, after the manner of hurdles.
For the lodgings of the Con≈øuls Lieutenants, it is probable that they were lodged about the Praetorium.

And for that of the Que≈øtor, who (be≈øides the money) had charge of the arms, of the engines for warre, of the victuall and apparel; I conceive that that great and ≈øpatious place which was given him, was to lodge all therein.
Concerning the tents, we find that even to Ce≈øars time they were made of the hides of bea≈øts.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the orders and guards of the camp.
div.p: BE≈øides the oath which was required of the ≈øouldiers after their election, they were made to take another in the camp, namely not to ≈øteal any thing, and if they found any thing to carry it to the Tribunes. Polybius reporteth that it was thus done between the hands of the Tribunes; and Cicero ≈øaith that they did it at the beginning of the election of ≈øouldiers between the hands of the Con≈øul.

That done, they divided the Cohorts of the Principes and Ha≈øtati as followeth: two to take care to keep clean the great ≈øtreet which was between the Tribunes and the re≈øt of the ≈øouldiers, and to ca≈øt water on it in ≈øummer, to avoid the di≈øcommoditie of du≈øt; for that was a place where every day a great part of the armie met: The other eighteen were divided to ≈øerve the Tribunes, namely three for every Tribune; of which they took every day eight ≈øouldiers for the guard of their lodging. The Cohorts of the Triarii made the guard for the Cavalrie; and one Cohort every day kept the guard before the Con≈øuls lodging.

The moats and the ramparts were made on the one ≈øide by the Romanes, and on the other ≈øide by the Allies. The Centurions made the ≈øouldiers to work at them, and two Tribunes had the charge to ≈øee the work well done.
The authoritie of the Tribunes in the camp was very great, and two of them together exerci≈øed it over their Legion for two moneths, after each other ≈øucce≈ø≈øively.

Concerning the Word; a ≈øouldier of the la≈øt Cohort of the Infantery, or of the la≈øt Turm of Cavalrie, was to come to the Tribunes lodging, and there to take it upon a writing-tablet, where al≈øo was written the name of the ≈øouldier which took it, and the place of his lodging; and this he delivered before witne≈ø≈øes to the commander of his troup: That officer delivered it to the commander next him; and ≈øo the tablet was delivered from hand to hand to the fir≈øt Cohort near to the Tribune, to whom it was brought back before night, ≈øo that by this means he was a≈ø≈øured that all the armie had the word. And if any tablet were wanting of being brought back again, it was ea≈øie to find where it had failed. It mu≈øt be ob≈øerved that here onely one Tribune is mentioned; which cau≈øeth me to believe that the two Tribunes which had the authority for two moneths time did agree to command every day by turns. Concerning the guard, it was kept day and night: and the foure and twentie houres were divided into eight watches.

Fir≈øt the Con≈øul was guarded by his ordinary Cohort; then every body made their guard round about his lodging; and be≈øides there were three guards kept, one at the Que≈øtors lodging, and
the two other at the lodgings of the Con≈øuls two Lieutenants.

The Tergiductours or Rear-commanders ordered the guards, which drew by lot which ≈øhould begin fir≈øt: and they which were to begin were led to the Tribune which then commanded, who gave them the order of the guard, and (be≈øides that) a little tablet with a mark; and all the guards were ≈øet after the ≈øame manner. The rounds were made by the Cavalrie, whereof the chief officer commanded foure for the day and foure for the night: the fir≈øt went and took their orders from the Tribune, who gave them in writing what guards they were to vi≈øit.

The relieving and vi≈øiting of the guards was done eight times in foure and twentie houres, at the ≈øound of the trumpet, and the fir≈øt Centurion of the Triarii had the charge to cau≈øe them to march when occa≈øion ≈øerved.

When the trumpet gave them warning, the foure forementioned ≈øouldiers drew lots, and he to whom it fell to begin, took ≈øome of his friends with him, and if in going the round he found the guards in good order, he onely took from them the mark which the Tribune had given them, and carried it him back again next morning: But if he found the guard abandoned, or any ≈øentinels a≈øleep, or any other di≈øorder, he made his report thereof to the Tribune with his witne≈ø≈øes: and pre≈øently a councel was called to prove the offen≈øe and to puni≈øh the delinquent according to his de≈øert.
The Velites made the guard round about the retrenchment, on the out≈øide and in≈øide of it, and at the gates. The Allies had the ≈øame order.
We find not in writing the number of their Corps-du-guards, how they placed their Sentinels round about the camp, and how many a day were free from the Guard.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of puni≈øhments and rewards.
div.p: NOne but the Con≈øul could condemne any to death, and he had this authoritie as well over the principall commanders of the army as over the meane≈øt ≈øouldiers thereof.
The Tribunes admini≈øtred military ju≈øtice, which was rigourou≈øly practiced. The manner of their ordinary puni≈øhing was thus,

So ≈øoon as the Tribune had touched the partie condemned with a ≈øtaff or a rod, every ≈øouldier laid on upon him with cudgels, or battered him with ≈øtones, and oftentimes before he could get out of the camp he was killed: but yet if he e≈øcaped, he was not received into his countrey again, and none of his kindred dur≈øt give him enterteinment.

He that oppo≈øed or neglected the orders given for the guard, or for the rounds, or other ≈øervice concerning the ≈øecuritie of the camp; or fal≈øely pretended to have done ≈øome ≈øignall act; or had for≈øaken the place where he had been placed; or had lo≈øt his arms in the battel; or had ≈øtolen any thing in the camp; or born fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe; or el≈øe had for≈øaken his en≈øigne, was puni≈øhed after this manner; as al≈øo he which committed ≈ømaller faults thrice.

If it happened that many Legions or one Legion, or a gro≈ø≈øe troup had run away, they were
puni≈øhed two wayes: the more rigourous way was to make them all draw lots, and to puni≈øh every tenth man; or more or fewer according to the exigence of the cau≈øe: by this means all were partakers of the fear, and a ≈ømall number of them were puni≈øhed. The more gentle way was, to cau≈øe them to lodge without the camp, and to give them barley in ≈øtead of wheat, which was a mark of ignominie; which many troups have wiped out by performing valourous and memorable acts.

Concerning their rewards, they excited tho≈øe ≈øouldiers by honourable acknowledgements and publick commendations in pre≈øence of all the re≈øt, which had performed ≈øome valourous and extraordinary act. Be≈øides that, to him that had wounded an enemy in ≈øome light skirmi≈øh, or that voluntarily had gone and a≈ø≈øaulted him, they gave a dart: To him which had killed and di≈øarmed him (if he were one that ≈øerved on foot) they gave a target: if he were a hor≈øeman, a hor≈øe-furniture.

To him that (at the a≈ø≈øault of a town) was fir≈øt got up upon the wall, they gave a crown, which they called Muralis: to him which had re≈øcued a Romane citizen, a crown called Civica, which was ≈øet upon his head by him which was ≈øo re≈øcued, whom he re≈øpected and honoured all his life after as his father.
The commanders had al≈øo their ≈øhares of honour, by the ≈øeverall triumphs which they obteined, according to the greatne≈ø≈øe of their actions and the felicitie of their victories.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of their Pay.
div.p: COncerning their pay; It began not untill three hundred fourty eight years after the foundation of Rome: before that every ≈øouldier armed and victualled him≈øelf at his own charge, which was no hard thing in tho≈øe times, becau≈øe their warre was then extended no further then Rome: But when they began to go out of Italy, it was nece≈ø≈øary to give them pay, which at the beginning was very ≈ømall: afterwards it encrea≈øed as the Romane empire grew in greatne≈ø≈øe. I will not trouble my ≈øelf to make the valuation of it according to our money, it being a thing of no utility: onely I will ≈øay, that the ≈øouldiers pay mu≈øt be ≈øo proportioned as he may maintein him≈øelf well thereby. I will further ob≈øerve here, that the Romanes charged them≈øelves with the furni≈øhing of bread, apparel, arms, and tents for all their ≈øouldiers; and be≈øides, barley for the hor≈øemens hor≈øes (abating the≈øe things out of their pay) which I find to be a good order, and above all things nece≈ø≈øary to make an army ≈øub≈øi≈øt: for be≈øides that the greater part of ≈øouldiers are bad husbands, and ≈øuch (as if a care be not taken) will never be well clothed nor well fed, it is impo≈ø≈øible that a ≈øouldier ≈øhould everywhere find bread to be bought, and that he ≈øhould carry all things with him which he ≈øtandeth in need of.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of their order of battalia.
div.p:
THere is a diver≈øitie of opinions about the order of battel of the Romanes. Some would have it that when the Ha≈øtati be not able to ≈øustein the enemies charge, in their retreat they ≈øhould fall into the order of the Principes by files; and both they into the order of the Triarii; and ≈øo to renew the fight three times. Others will have it to be done by troups, whereof I conceive there is much the greater probability, holding the fir≈øt way not onely impo≈ø≈øible to be put in practice but al≈øo mo≈øt dangerous, & the other exceeding fei≈øible and profitable. For to fall one into another in that maner by files, the Ha≈øtati mu≈øt then fight at ≈øo wide a di≈øtance, that between two files they might receive two other files, which ≈øheweth the weakne≈ø≈øe of this fir≈øt order, which being ≈øo ranged in battalia could not be able to repul≈øe nor ≈øu≈øtein the adver≈øe battallion. And even the files, being at ≈øo wide a di≈øtance from each other, were not able to keep them≈øelves right in fight nor to ob≈øerve their di≈øtances; but in the other way there are many conveniences to be found. Fir≈øt many bodies of a hundred and twenty men apiece (or thereabouts) a≈ø≈øaulting a battallion, they may very well defeat it; at the wor≈øt they may retreat without di≈øordering them≈øelves or loo≈øing their di≈øtances. And the ≈øecond order, which is embattelled behind the fir≈øt, ju≈øt over again≈øt their intervalls, may ea≈øily fill them: as al≈øo (in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity) the third body may ≈øupply tho≈øe di≈øtances which are re≈øerved for them, renewing the fight three
times. And that which confirmeth us the more in this opinion is, that in rea≈øon it ought to be ≈øo: next, the de≈øcription of the battel of Zama which Scipio fought again≈øt Hannibal, where it is ≈øaid that Scipio to hinder Hannibals elephants from routing his ≈øouldiers, cau≈øed the Cohorts of the Principes (which were placed ju≈øt over again≈øt the intervalls of the Ha≈øtati) to ≈øtand ju≈øt behind them, ≈øo to leave ≈øtreets for the pa≈ø≈øage of the elephants: which ≈øheweth plainly that the order of battalia was di≈øpo≈øed by Cohorts, and not by files.

I ≈øpeak not of the Velites in this order of battalia, nor of all other light-armed ≈øouldiers, becau≈øe they fought not but with ca≈øting-weapons, and afar off, and when the armies approched to give the ≈øhock, they retired them≈øelves behind the heavie-armed.

Now to form the ≈øaid order, I will ≈øay that the file was alwayes of ten men in depth; that a Cohort or Maniple of a Legion of foure thou≈øand two hundred men con≈øi≈øted alwayes of one hundred and twentie ≈øouldiers, and con≈øequently the Cohort made ten ranks and twelve files, conteining (at ≈øix foot ≈øquare of ground for every ≈øouldier) ≈øeventy two foot in breadth and ≈øixty in depth: and the moity of it when they were at three foot di≈øtance.

div.p: In each of the three orders, how≈øoever the Legions were weaker or ≈øtronger, there were alwayes ten Cohorts or Maniples; but the Cohorts were either increa≈øed or dimini≈øhed according to the proportion of the Legions.

div.head: The ≈øecond figure of ten Cohorts.
div.p: The two fir≈øt orders are of an equall number, and the la≈øt of half as many; and by this example of one Legion, you may ≈øee how all the troups pa≈ø≈øed into each other.

div.head: The third figure, of a Legion.
div.p: I conceive that between the Legions there was a far greater di≈øtance then between the Cohorts, that ≈øo they might prevent confu≈øion among≈øt them; which I judge to be ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, as that without the ob≈øervation thereof it was altogether impo≈ø≈øible to ob≈øerve any good order.

Concerning the cavalry; ≈øeeing it was divided into the like number of troups as the Infantery, it is like they fought in the ≈øame order; but the one half were on the right flank, and the other on the left: Thus the army was compo≈øed of ≈øix great bodies, namely foure bodies of infantery, and two bodies of the cavalry; and every body divided into ≈ømall troups, as hath been ≈øhewed before.

p.note: So in this figure; the intervalls ≈øhould be 4 times wider, if the bodies mu≈øt be ≈øo large; but I conceive a generall mi≈øtake in the figure, and that in Prai≈ø≈øac pag. 190. to be much better.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Sieges.
div.p:
NO Romane Commander hath made braver ≈øieges then Ce≈øar, nor de≈øcribed them more perfectly. He hath left examples for the a≈ø≈øailing of all ≈øorts of ≈øites, and to maintein a ≈øiege again≈øt all kinds of reliefs. At Brundu≈øium, which is upon the ≈øea, he con≈øtrained Pompey to abandon it, for that he ≈øhut up the haven by which that town was to be relieved. At Cadenac, which was a ≈øite inexpugnable, he con≈øtrained the garri≈øon to yield it, by taking away their water. At Alexia, where were 80000 ≈øouldiers within the town, and which expected two or three times as many, he ≈øo fortified him≈øelf before it, both again≈øt the town and again≈øt the enemy without, as he fami≈øhed it. And at Bourges and Mar≈øeilles he took the fir≈øt by a≈ø≈øault, and con≈øtrained the other to yield, when it was upon the point of being taken by a≈ø≈øault. I will not here particularize the engines
which they then made u≈øe of to force places of ≈øtrength, becau≈øe the cannon hath taken away the u≈øe of them. Yet I will onely ≈øay that they approched to the walls by degrees, as much ≈øheltred as they could, and then attempted to batter them down by their engines, or by mines to force an a≈ø≈øault, or at lea≈øt to lodge upon the breach: which I the rather ≈øpeak, to ≈øhew that how≈øoever we have changed the manner of fortifications, the better to make re≈øi≈øtance again≈øt our new thundring engines, neverthele≈ø≈øe the ancient maximes for the taking of towns are the ≈øame, which we make u≈øe of at this day. Concerning the ≈øiege of Alexia, it is the modell by which the Prince of Parma, the Prince of Orange, and the Marque≈ø≈øe Spinola have directed them≈øelves to make theirs. And all the≈øe great works and circumvallations which we admire, and by the help of which they have taken many great cities in ≈øight of greater armies then their own, which have not been able to relieve them, are nothing in compari≈øon of tho≈øe which Ce≈øar made at this ≈øiege of Alexia. To conclude, they which come neare≈øt to the manner of warring of the ancient Romanes, as well in ≈øieges as in the field, are they which prove the mo≈øt excellent Commanders.

div.head: CHAP. X. Ob≈øervations vpon ≈øome battels of the ancients.
div.p:
NOw that we have ≈øhewed the ancient Militia of the Grecians and Romanes, by means whereof they have obteined ≈øo many brave victories,
we mu≈øt yet ob≈øerve two principall cau≈øes, which their mo≈øt excellent Commanders have ≈øucce≈ø≈øefully ob≈øerved to obtein victories in battel: namely, to ≈øtrive to overwing their enemy, and never to cau≈øe their army to fight all at once. Cyrus, to keep him≈øelf from being overwinged in the battel which he fought again≈øt Cre≈øus, doubled the front of his army by as many more as they were, by making the files of his infantery but 12 deep, which before were 24: and to enclo≈øe his enemy, he placed his be≈øt men on the wings; who having defeated the wings of the adver≈øe army, came to a≈ø≈øault the body of the battel on their flanks and on their rear. At the battel of Cannae Hannibal placed all his be≈øt ≈øouldiers on the wings, and the meaner ones in the middle, that ≈øo the Romanes finding but little re≈øi≈øtance there, might in≈øen≈øibly ≈øink into them, and by that means they found them≈øelves enclo≈øed on both flanks. At the battel of Phar≈øale, Ce≈øar ≈øheltred one of the flanks of his army by a little river, and fortified his Cavalry (which was on his other flank) by a body of Infantery, to re≈øi≈øt Pompey's hor≈øe, which exceeded his own by much; ≈øo that having routed it by this means, he a≈ø≈øailed the army on the flank, and ea≈øily defeated it. At the battel of Zama Hannibal made a body of all his old companies of Italy, which he divided from all his army, that ≈øo when all the re≈øt (as well of the one part as the other) ≈øhould be weary with fighting, this body being fre≈øh, might carry away the victory. So that Scipio, after that he had defeated all that were before him, found him≈øelf a≈øtoni≈øhed to ≈øee a ≈øecond army for him to fight with afre≈øh.

Here may be an objection made, that the armies might be ≈øo unequall in number, as all the≈øe maximes might prove unprofitable; whereunto I an≈øwer, that when an army pa≈ø≈øeth a certain number of fourty or fifty thou≈øand men, the ≈øurplu≈ø≈øage ≈øerveth for no other end but to fami≈øh the army: for it is an ea≈øie thing by retrenching to avoid battel. And if you ≈øhould re≈øolve to give battel, if you would ob≈øerve the forementioned orders, there is no plain ≈øo ≈ømooth but you may find ≈øomething wherewith to ≈øhelter one of the flanks of your army; either by a river, wood, hill, or a ditch; and the other with waggons: nor nothing that ≈øhall be able to hinder you from having ≈øome body of re≈øerve which ≈øhall not fight at the beginning; nor from placing tho≈øe troups on the wings which you e≈øteem to be your be≈øt ≈øouldiers. Which things if they be exactly ob≈øerved as they ought, they may avail very much for the obteining of victory.

div.head: CHAP. XI. A comparing of the arms and military orders of the Romanes with tho≈øe of the Grecians.
div.p: THe arms of the Grecians were the buckler, the pike, and the ≈øword. Their order was of great bodies of battalions of 16 deep of the heavie-armed, and then ≈øtrengthened by eight in depth of the light-armed: ≈øo that the battalions came to be 24 in depth, and fought all at once, making all one front.

The arms of the Romanes were the target and the ≈øword; their order was to make ≈ømall bodies
of 150 or 200 ≈øouldiers at the mo≈øt, which were onely ten in depth, and to make three orders of battalia, that ≈øo they might fight three times, one after another.

Concerning the arms of the Grecians; it ≈øeemeth that their long pikes had a great advantage of the Romane targets, becau≈øe they reached farre; and even at this day we find no weapon comparable to the pike again≈øt the violence of the hor≈øe: and for their order, tho≈øe great bodies met with nothing that could re≈øi≈øt them. On the other ≈øide tho≈øe great Romane targets covered the ≈øouldiers ≈øo well as the pikes could not hurt them; and if once they came to joyn, they made a great ≈ølaughter with their ≈øhort & broad ≈øwords; for then the pike was unu≈øefull. Moreover, their ≈ømall troups gave them this advantage, that they brought more hands to fight at once. Concerning their di≈øpo≈øing of their three orders one behind another, to the end they might relieve each other, and to be able to begin the fight again by all three, they had this advantage by it, that all were not wearied nor di≈øordered at once. In ≈øo much that oftentimes they have carried away the victory after the defeat of their two fir≈øt orders: for that their third order being fre≈øh, and having rallied all the re≈øt, gave the la≈øt charge again≈øt an army which was tired and in di≈øorder, and ≈øo gained the battel.

There be two di≈øcommodities more in tho≈øe great bodies; namely, that they mu≈øt ever have a very ≈ømooth field for the battel, el≈øe they are not able to keep their order; and that they cannot agitate on the right or left, but onely fight ju≈øt before them. But the ≈ømall troups weild
them≈øelves on all ≈øides, and continue their order in all places. It is true that the Romanes ≈øometimes joyned all their forces together, making but one body of all their army, in an Orb; but this was but to ≈øave them≈øelves in a retreat, and not to charge an enemy: for as the≈øe great bodies are as it were unmoveable and of little u≈øe in a≈ø≈øaults; ≈øo when they will onely defend them≈øelves, they are hard to be broken.

And yet they u≈øed not this la≈øt order bu ‚Ä¢ when they were per≈øecuted by the arrows of a great Cavalrie, as that of the Parthians: for not being able to come to hand-blows with them, they were con≈øtrained to put them≈øelves into this order, and to ≈øhelter them≈øelves with their targets. So that I conclude that the arms and orders of the Romanes were better then tho≈øe of the Grecians; becau≈øe ≈ømall troups accommodate them≈øelves better to all ≈øites then great ones, and fighting at ≈øeverall times they continue the fight with more ob≈øtinacie then when all fight at once; and that it is more ea≈øie of many ≈ømall troups to make a gro≈ø≈øe readily and without di≈øorder, then of a gro≈ø≈øe to make many ≈ømall troups.

And for my tran≈ølation, your ≈øtudies and travels having made that language naturall to you, I might ju≈øtly fear a ≈øevere cen≈øure; but that I know your candour ≈øuch, as you will excu≈øe

div.head: A Treati≈øe of Warre.
div.p: I ∆≤ndertake not here to treat of all the functions of warre in particular, becau≈øe ≈øo many have written thereof as it would be a thing ≈øuperfluous. I content my ≈øelf to make generall ob≈øervations upon all tho≈øe things which depend thereon, and which may in the≈øe times be put in practice: being loth to touch upon any thing but what experience hath taught me, and in all to be ≈øo brief as I may not weary the Reader.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the election of Souldiers.
div.p:
THe election of ≈øouldiers was by the Ancients and is by Moderns made after divers wayes. The Grecians and Romanes contented not them≈øelves to enroll the ≈øouldiers which of their own accord were willing to go to the warre, but cho≈øe out of them ≈øuch as they judged to be fitte≈øt for that ≈øervice; which is the cau≈øe they had ≈øo good ≈øouldiers. The Carthaginians for the mo≈øt part imployed ≈øtrangers, and therefore had no wor≈øe ≈øouldiers then their own countrey-men. The Turks choo≈øe their ≈øouldiers, and train them. The Swi≈ø≈øes make u≈øe of their own men. The Venetians and Hollanders, in imitation of the Carthaginians, are ≈øerved by auxiliarie ≈øouldiers. The French and Germanes abound in good ≈øouldiers, and may well forbear auxiliaries. England alone,
of all the States of our time, may choo≈øe them, and take ≈øuch as ≈øhe plea≈øeth. Whereupon we mu≈øt con≈øider the con≈øtitution of the≈øe States, on what maximes they be founded, and what either of them may be≈øt do to have good ≈øouldiers. The greater part of States at this time are more founded upon policie then upon warre, and endeavour rather to con≈øerve them≈øelves then to grow greater. Wherefore we ≈øee that learning flouri≈øheth there, and arms degenerate; in ≈øo much that tho≈øe States which are founded upon warre do devour the other.

The example of the Turk to the ≈øhame of the Chri≈øtians, and that of the king of Spain to the prejudice of Germany and Italy, are two manife≈øt proofs. That which cau≈øeth this mi≈øchief is, that men of the gown have po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them≈øelves of the government of almo≈øt all States, which (for that they hate ≈øouldiers) cau≈øe them alwayes to be ill dealt with, and do advi≈øe Princes to imploy auxiliars rather then their naturall ≈øubjects: which is a mo≈øt pernicious maxime. But this being no fit place to treat of it, we will onely ≈øpeak of the election of ≈øouldiers.

England, which hath right by the laws of that kingdome to make choice of her ≈øouldiers, may ob≈øerve the form of the election of the Romanes, which is very good. The other kingdomes which have not that power mu≈øt incite their men which are ambitious of honour to cau≈øe them≈øelves to be enrolled, a≈øwell for the hope of being advanced to other honours by embracing the profe≈ø≈øion of warre, as by ≈øhutting up the means of atteining thereunto by any other way then that‚ñ™
For example, not to be≈øtow any office of the kingdome, nor of the kings hou≈øe, nor any charge among≈øt the ≈øouldiers, to any but ≈øuch, as have ≈øerved in the warres a certain number of years; nor to make any man Colonel of hor≈øe which hath not been a Captain and other officer of the Cavalrie; nor any to be Mar≈øhall of the field, which hath not honourably born le≈ø≈øer charges; nor any to be Generall of the army, which hath not been a worthy Mar≈øhall of the field: briefly, that none may be advanced to any office, which hath not pa≈ø≈øed through the degrees of warre. And as the hope of advancement is a ≈øtrong ≈øpur to encourage every man to exerci≈øe the profe≈ø≈øion of arms; ≈øo the fear of finding ones ≈øelf poore and needy after long ≈øervice is a ≈øharp bit to keep men from ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Therefore I would prevent that by e≈øtabli≈øhing a foundation for men of that profe≈ø≈øion, ≈øo that they might live out the re≈øt of their dayes commodiou≈øly and honourably. Tho≈øe States which by rea≈øon of their form of government are fearfull to arm their own people (as Venice) or where their ≈øub≈øi≈øtence dependeth on traffick (as the Low-Countreys) and which for the≈øe rea≈øons are con≈øtrained to help them≈øelves in their warres by auxiliars, mu≈øt principally be carefull to choo≈øe good Commanders; next, to have a certain body of well exerci≈øed and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øciplined ≈øould ‚Ä¢ ers alwayes in readine≈ø≈øe, ≈øufficient as well to guard them from a ≈øurpri≈øe as to give them time ‚Ä¢ o a≈ø≈øemble greater forces. For an armie formed ‚Ä¢ nd di≈øciplined at lei≈øure, though but ≈ømall, is more capable to defend it ≈øelf, yea to conquer, ‚Ä¢ hen tho≈øe armies which a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves onely
in their great numbers. And great conque≈øts are almo≈øt alwayes made by ≈ømall armies, as great Empires are alwayes lo≈øt with their innumerable forces. For that they which were to fight again≈øt ≈øuch numerous armies, oppo≈øed them with an exact di≈øcipline and good order; and the other, having neglected all di≈øcipline and order, have endeavoured to ≈øupply that defect by their great number of men; which hath brought upon them the greater confu≈øion and hath ≈øerved them for no other end but to make their lo≈ø≈øe the more di≈øgracefull. VVhence I conclude, that the be≈øt means to have good ≈øouldiers is to choo≈øe ≈øuch as are mo≈øt fit for warre; the ≈øecond, to incite men of ambition and vertue freely to enroll them≈øelves, by ≈øhutting the doore of any other way to advancement; and la≈øtly, to entertein a body of an armie‚ñ™ and to be carefull (as well in peace as in warre) to keep them under an exact di≈øcipline, without relaxation One of which three wayes all ≈øorts of States may make u≈øe of.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of Arms.
div.p:
THe mo≈øt u≈øuall arms of the Infanterie at thi ‚Ä¢ pre≈øent time, are (for the defen≈øive) th ‚Ä¢ head-piece, the cuirace, and the ta≈ø≈øes: and fo ‚Ä¢ the offen≈øive, the ≈øword, the pike, and the musket which are rather the arms of the Grecians then o ‚Ä¢ the Romanes. Whereupon we mu≈øt ob≈øerve, that ou ‚Ä¢ muskets ≈øerve us as the ca≈øting-weapons did th ‚Ä¢ Ancients; ≈øo that the body of the battel con≈øi≈øte ‚Ä¢ of pikes, which is a very fit weapon to re≈øi≈øt th ‚Ä¢
Cavalrie, for that many of them joyned together make a very ≈øolid body, and very hard to be broken on their front, by rea≈øon of their length, whereof foure or five ranks extend the heads of their pikes beyond the fir≈øt rank of men, and do alwayes keep out the ≈øquadrons of hor≈øe from them twelve or fifteen foot of. Maurice Prince of Orange had a great de≈øire to make u≈øe of the target, and having cau≈øed divers trials to be made thereof, hath found that it hath not onely re≈øi≈øted the pike, but that half the number of targets hath alwayes entred into twice the number of pikes, and hath routed them. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, being but Generall of the armies of a State, and not a ≈øovereigne and ab≈øolute Prince, he dur≈øt not make ≈øo great a change; whether it were that he feared the Cavalrie, which now-adayes is exceeding well armed or el≈øe the reproch of ≈øome evil ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; not being ignorant that the people Judge of the actions of ≈øuch as ≈øerve them rather by the event then by rea≈øon. For my part, I would adde this kind of arms to our di≈øcipline, making alwayes the principall body of my Infantery to be of pikes, and to have for every battallion a ≈ømall body ≈øeparate of one hundred or one hundred and twentie targets to charge on the flank, which would work a marvellous effect on the day of battel; and this ≈øhould be the true place of voluntiers, and of very brave Nobilitie, which often prove to be but trouble≈øome to an army. Concerning the offen≈øive arms of the Cavalrie, there be of five ≈øorts; namely, the lance, the pi≈øtoll, the ≈øword, the carabine, and the musket: the two fir≈øt are given to the heavie-armed calvarie, which mu≈øt have for
defen≈øive arms the cuiracecask, vambraces, ta≈ø≈øets, cui≈ø≈øes, and guard-rein, and (not many years ≈øince) ≈øome hor≈øes have been armed with barbs. Of the two other kinds, they which ≈øerve with carabines have the head-piece and cuirace; and becau≈øe they fight on hor≈øeback, they mu≈øt be well mounted: but they which ≈øerve with the musket have no defen≈øive arms. Of the≈øe five ≈øorts of offen≈øive arms there be but three much in u≈øe; namely, the pi≈øtol, ≈øword, and carabine. The Spaniards onely have continued ≈øome few companies of lances, which they keep rather for gravitie then rea≈øon; for the lance doth no effect but by the violence of the carreir of the hor≈øe, and be≈øides there is but one rank which can make u≈øe of it; ≈øo that their order mu≈øt be to fight by ≈øingle ranks, which cannot re≈øi≈øt the ≈øquadrons: and if they ≈øhould fight in ≈øquadrons, they would rather be trouble≈øome then ≈øerviceable. And for musketiers on hor≈øeback or dragones, they are al≈øo in a manner left off, for that in the civil warres they ruined the Infantery, every man de≈øiring to have a nag, that ≈øo he might be the fitter to rob and pillage: neverthele≈ø≈øe ≈øome well-ordered troups of this kind in an armie are of very great ≈øervice; either for executions, to gain bad pa≈ø≈øages, to guard the quarters of hor≈øe, or el≈øe (on a day of battel) to cau≈øe them to di≈ømount as forlorn hopes before the ≈øquadrons of Cavalrie.

Now the Cavalrie mu≈øt be proportioned with the Infantery; which may be di≈øtingui≈øhed according to the ≈øituation of the countrey where the warre is made, or el≈øe according to the enemy again≈øt whom you are to fight. For if you
you be in a champain full of forrage, and if ye be to make warre again≈øt a great Cavalrie, as that of the Turk, in ≈øuch a ca≈øe you mu≈øt fortifie your ≈øelf with the greater number of hor≈øe. But if the warre be in a countrey enclo≈øed, either by mountains, forre≈øts, moores, or hedges and ditches, and that hath many fortified places, for that the warre is rather reduced to ≈øieges then to battels and field-combats, in ≈øuch a ca≈øe you mu≈øt ≈øtrengthen your Infanterie. And the≈øe two bodies are ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary the one for the other, as an armie cannot be held to be good nor ≈øub≈øi≈øt unle≈ø≈øe it be equally provided of both. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, if I were not induced by ≈øome extraordinary rea≈øon, I would make the proportion of my army for the open countrey of a fourth part of hor≈øe to three fourth parts of Infantery; as to twentie foure thou≈øand foot, eight thou≈øand hor≈øe: in an inclo≈øed countrey, of a ≈øixth part of hor≈øe to five parts of foot; as to twentie foure thou≈øand foot, foure thou≈øand hor≈øe. It remaineth to give to the≈øe two bodies ≈øuch arms as were before mentioned with the mo≈øt profitable proportion. The Swi≈ø≈øes have many more pikes then muskets, and for this they have made them≈øelves to be much feared in a champain countrey; for in a day of battel where you come to hand, the number of pikes hath much advantage of that of muskets. Other nations do equally divide the pikes and muskets; and becau≈øe the war in the≈øe times is reduced to ≈øieges rather then battels, we de≈øire to have a greater number of muskets then of pikes. For my ≈øelf, which adde the targets to them, my opinion ≈øhould be to have the regiments of 1440 ≈øouldiers,
namely of 600 pikes, 600 muskets, and 240 targets. For the Cavalrie; I would proportion it after this manner: I would compo≈øe the regiments of 500 hor≈øe, whereof I would arm 400 with Cuira≈ø≈øiers arms; 50 with carabines, and 50 to be dragones.

But this is not all, to provide good arms for your ≈øouldiers, unle≈ø≈øe you oblige them to wear them; it being an un≈øufferable ≈øhame to ≈øee their delicatene≈ø≈øe in the≈øe times, and how they di≈øe≈øteem them: and to cover this fault, they publi≈øh that it is want of courage to go armed, and that they will go in their doublets into the mo≈øt dangerous places, a≈øwell as they which are armed. It is not enough to go into a place to cau≈øe ones ≈øelf there to be knocked on the head; we ≈øhould go thither to conquer, and not to be beaten. Be≈øides this inconvenience groweth of it, that if you u≈øe not your ≈øelf to wear your arms, you are ≈øo pe≈øtered with them as you cannot fight in them: on the contrary, if you accu≈øtome your ≈øelf to them, they are no more trouble≈øome to you, and you are at as much libertie in them as if you were in your doublet. But the greate≈øt mi≈øchief that cometh of it is, that the ruine of military di≈øcipline followeth on it; which a good Captain ought to cau≈øe to be exactly ob≈øerved in every part. For if he ≈ølacken it in one, or in favour of ≈øome per≈øons, the con≈øequences which follow on it by little and little will be ≈øuch as they will wholly overthrow it: and then he ≈øhall find him≈øelf without obedience and without re≈øpect; which he ≈øhall never recover without incurring the hatred of tho≈øe whom he hath too much ≈øpared; it being mo≈øt certain that it is
ea≈øier to prevent a mi≈øchief then to help it when it is befallen.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of Militarie Di≈øcipline.
div.p:
BE≈øides that which hath been ≈øaid to incite every one to take upon him the profe≈ø≈øion of arms rather then any other, we mu≈øt make other ob≈øervations to make a man worthy thereof, which con≈øi≈øt in three things: namely in the recompen≈øe of commendable actions, in the puni≈øhment of bad ones, and in the continuall and exact exerci≈øe of militarie di≈øcipline; for there is no profe≈ø≈øion in the world which hath more need of ≈øuch helps then that of warre, where for the ≈øingle pay (which hardly affordeth livelyhood, and with which the meane≈øt arti≈øan would not be contented) the ≈øouldier abandoneth him≈øelf to all ≈øorts of perils and labours: but none are in≈øtigated thereunto unle≈ø≈øe it be by emulation of honour, or by licence to do evil; and as the fir≈øt aim is vertuous, ≈øo you ≈øhall have good ≈øervice of ≈øuch as enter into it for that end. But of the other you ≈øhall reap nothing but ≈øhame; for in ≈øtead of a good and obedient army you ≈øhall find that you have no better then a troup of pillaging rogues, which without order or obedience for≈øake you, either after a good boot-haling, or in any eminent danger. For this rea≈øon the election of ≈øouldiers is a better way of forming an army, then onely to receive voluntaries; where all the vagabonds and evil livers, and ≈øuch as cannot live but by robbing, cau≈øe them≈øelves to be enrolled. Therefore to incite
≈øuch as are vertuous to well-doing, and to deterre the vitious from doing evil, recompen≈øes and puni≈øhments are principally nece≈ø≈øary. The Romanes have made very profitable u≈øe of the≈øe two means: and if we follow not their way we ≈øhall never have good nor well-di≈øciplined ≈øouldiers. It matters not though we u≈øe not the very ≈øame remunerations and the ≈øame puni≈øhments they did; it ≈øufficeth that they be equivalent, that ≈øo we may receive the ≈øame benefit by them: and the≈øe things are diver≈øly done, according to time and cu≈øtome. The principall is to be an exact ob≈øerver of them, that ≈øo the remunerations may excite brave men to worthy actions, and the rigour of puni≈øhment may keep cowards from doing ba≈øely. The manner of decimating the ≈øouldiers which the Romanes had, is held to be cruel: neverthele≈ø≈øe there be ≈øometimes ≈øo infamous actions committed, as you are con≈øtrained to u≈øe great ≈øeverity, to give a terrour to all; finding it very good to ≈øtrike a fear into all tho≈øe that have e≈øcaped by the means of the lot, and to put but few to death. For you mu≈øt imprint this belief into your ≈øouldiers, that by ba≈øe flight they e≈øcape not death, but they onely exchange a glorious death which they ≈øhould have acquired by fighting valiantly for an infamous one. After that the ≈øouldier be incouraged by the honour of being e≈øteemed valiant, and brought to a hatred of being held a coward, it mu≈øt be made a like degree of honour for every one to know how well to obey his ≈øuperiour, from the private ≈øouldier to the Lieutenant generall: for on this obedience all the functions of an army depend, and without it you can keep nothing
in rule, nor do any thing that is good. This mu≈øt be ingraffed into the hearts of the ≈øouldiers, as being one of the principalle≈øt vertues required in them. From hence groweth order; by this military exerci≈øe is mainteined; briefly, by this brave de≈øignes are executed, and without this all goeth to confu≈øion and ruine. I will not trouble my ≈øelf here to ≈øpeak of the particular military exerci≈øes which the ≈øouldier is to be exerci≈øed in, becau≈øe divers books are ful of them, and that cu≈øtome doth alwaies change ≈øomething or other in them. I will onely ≈øay that there is nothing ≈øo profitable as to exerci≈øe every ≈øouldier to carry his arms properly, to u≈øe them ≈øouldierlike, to keep his rank well, and therein well to execute all the motions and charges which are commanded him. So much concerning the ≈øouldiers: But concerning the recompen≈øe of Generals of armies, I will ≈øay the ≈øame which I ≈øaid for the ≈øouldiers, namely, that according to the time, or the con≈øtitution of kingdomes or common-wealths, ≈øuch cour≈øes ought to be taken as the honour of ≈øuch as have done brave actions and great ≈øervices be not dimini≈øhed nor blemi≈øhed: For that the mo≈øt generous ≈øpirits (which will ea≈øily excu≈øe all want of other recompen≈øe for their ≈øervices) will never endure to be robbed of the honour due to their brave actions, and will ≈øooner ≈øtomach ≈øuch a want of due honour then any other thing what≈øoever: whereupon very often great mi≈øchiefs have followed.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the obedience of ≈øouldiers.
div.p:
NOw as the Generall of the armie requireth of the ≈øouldiers that obedience which is due to him, ≈øo he mu≈øt have a care to give them no ju≈øt cau≈øe to exempt them≈øelves from it: to this end he ought to keep them in continuall imployment, for that idlene≈ø≈øe engendreth corruption of manners and di≈øcipline, whence proceed luxury, neglecting of exerci≈øes and the guards, and di≈øobedience to ≈øuperiours. It was the ea≈øe and idlene≈ø≈øe of Capua that de≈øtroyed Hannibals army, and the delicacies of Babylon which corrupted Alexander him≈øelf, and from whence he drew away his army to prevent the totall ruine of it; there being no means of greater efficacy to keep it in due order, and to prevent ≈øeditions, then to imploy it in warre. It is therefore a maxime which mu≈øt be exactly ob≈øerved, never to ≈øuffer your ≈øouldiers in any place to be idle, e≈øpecially when the army is brought together in a body; for if you imploy them not in that which is good, they will bu≈øie them≈øelves in that which is naught. This cour≈øe mu≈øt be taken a≈øwell in the time of ≈øecure≈øt peace as of open warre; particularly, to exerci≈øe them to u≈øe their arms well, and to ob≈øerve good order; and though there be no need, yet to u≈øe them to make retrenchments of the camp, and to make their huts: that ≈øo they may be ≈øo accu≈øtomed to remove the earth, that when nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall require, it may be no trouble to them. I would further imploy them to
make fortifications and other works of this kind, not onely to keep them in exerci≈øe, but that al≈øo they may get (be≈øides their pay) wherewith the better to maintein them≈øelves, and that they accu≈øtome them≈øelves to that which in time of warre is as profitable to them as to fight well, there being nothing impo≈ø≈øible for twenty or thirty thou≈øand men which will work in the earth; for in eight dayes they will make fortre≈ø≈øes which ≈øhall be impregnable: And Ce≈øar hath made him≈øelf as much redoubted and admired by the great works which he hath cau≈øed his ≈øouldiers to make, as by his great battels. Moreover, the Generall mu≈øt take care that they be well clothed and well fed; e≈øpecially that (out of their payes) they be furni≈øhed with clothes and ≈øhoes, otherwi≈øe he will ≈øoon find his army to decay, and di≈øea≈øes to rage in it for want thereof. He mu≈øt al≈øo have a great care of tho≈øe which are ≈øick and hurt, and therein to ≈øpare for no co≈øt; that ≈øo the ≈øouldiers may not excu≈øe them≈øelves from going on upon dangerous ≈øervices, or to undergo laborious imployments, becau≈øe they are abandoned when they are ≈øick or wounded. The General ought al≈øo to take a particular care not to overlabour his ≈øouldiers, nor to put them to extraordinary hard marches without great nece≈ø≈øity: but when need requireth it, he mu≈øt be the fir≈øt to undergo the labour; for the example of the commander maketh all things ea≈øie to the ≈øouldier. The examples not onely of the greate≈øt Captains among≈øt the Ancients, but even of the greate≈øt Monarchs and Emperours, ≈øhould ≈øhame our delicate Captains of the≈øe times, which are afraid
to ≈øpoil their fair complexion in the ≈øunne, and their goodly plumes in the rain, which would believe them≈øelves to be di≈øhonoured if they ≈øhould march on foot at the head of their companies: and tho≈øe great men have not ≈øcorned to march at the head of their armies, and have refu≈øed to quench their extraordinary thir≈øt, becau≈øe there was not water enough to make all the army to drink; and ≈øo making them≈øelves companions of the dangers and labours of their meane≈øt ≈øouldiers, have made them≈øelves ma≈øters of the greate≈øt part of the world, and have gained an immortall glory.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Marching.
div.p:
THere are divers con≈øiderations to be made upon the marching of an army; which may be a≈ø≈øaulted in the day-time, or at its di≈ølodging, or even in the night when it is lodged. If it be not encamped, but lodge in villages, you mu≈øt (to cau≈øe it to meet in one body) give it a Rendez-vous on the way which it mu≈øt take; which if the enemy learn time enough to be there fir≈øt, or that he meet with it there by chance, he will put the army to run a great hazard, which cometh to its Rendez-vous at divers times and by divers wayes. The be≈øt means to guard ones ≈øelf from ≈øuch an accident are, to keep your Rendez-vous very ≈øecret, to have good ≈øpies among≈øt the enemies, and to ≈øend out many di≈øcoverers for intelligence. When you encamp you are not ≈øubject to that danger, becau≈øe the army is alwayes together. For the march you
mu≈øt con≈øider the countrey where you are, and the number of ≈øouldiers which you have. If you march in great plains, you may (for the mo≈øt part) march in battalia; or at lea≈øt with formed battaillons and ≈øquadrons: then it is very ea≈øie to put your ≈øelf readily into a good form to fight well, becau≈øe you march not in a long order. But when you march through a ≈øtrait countrey, where but few can march in front, then you mu≈øt compute the di≈øcommodity of the way, and the time you have for your march, with the number of ≈øouldiers whereof your army con≈øi≈øteth; for 10000 foot marching 10 in front, and 1000 hor≈øe marching 5 in front, with the lighte≈øt baggage they can po≈ø≈øibly have, and ten cannons, with equipage for every piece to ≈øhoot 100 bullets, take up about 28000 foot of way in length; whereby you may judge how much way in file 30000 foot and 6000 hor≈øe will take. Therefore when ≈øo great armies find them≈øelves in ≈øuch a trouble≈øome way, you mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity divide them into ≈øeverall bodies, which may march one after another, and lodge ≈øeverally; or rather cau≈øe them to march by divers wayes, ≈øome miles di≈øtant from each other; or how≈øoever, to make wayes through the fields for your ≈øouldiers to march in, leaving the great road for your cannon and baggage. If there be a river to pa≈ø≈øe where you can make but one bridge, or ≈øome pa≈ø≈øage over a mountain, moori≈øh ground, or forre≈øt where you cannot make ≈øeverall wayes, then you mu≈øt march one after another, and on ≈øeverall dayes. I trouble not my ≈øelf to ≈øhew how you are to pa≈ø≈øe through ≈øuch bad pa≈ø≈øages in view of the enemy, becau≈øe many
have written thereof: yet when it cometh to execution, few will get off well, if they be charged home; but I will onely ≈øay that the be≈øt way is to calculate the time ≈øo well as you may avoid ≈øuch encounters. Concerning the march; I find it almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible that two armies ≈øhould meet each other, if one of the two Generals be de≈øirous to avoid it, e≈øpecially in an inclo≈øed countrey: but what≈øoever happen, the be≈øt way is to have the baggage wholly ≈øeparated from the ≈øouldiers, leaving onely on the rear ≈øome few troups to keep it from di≈øbanding: for if in time of alarm every body have their baggage behind them, it cau≈øeth a great confu≈øion, and hindreth the ≈øouldiers from rallying them≈øelves and helping each other. The time of lodging is al≈øo a dangerous time to be a≈ø≈øaulted in, becau≈øe the army is then tired, and every man (de≈øirous to be lodged) ha≈øtneth to the quarter in di≈øorder, which is a thing hard to avoid, if (before you enter your lodgings) you cau≈øe not your army to ≈øtand in battalia, and ≈øo cau≈øe them to lodge troup after troup, without ≈øuffering any to lodge but by command, mean time ≈øending out on all ≈øides upon di≈øcovery.

There remaineth the a≈ø≈øaulting of a quarter, which is that which is more frequently attempted, e≈øpecially when the army is not encamped; becau≈øe it being lodged in ≈øeverall quarters, the enemy may attempt to ≈øurpri≈øe ≈øome one quarter without hazarding a generall combat: fo ‚Ä¢ which I do not find the ordinary guard alone (how exactly ≈øoever it be performed) ≈øufficien ‚Ä¢ to remedy ≈øuch an accident; becau≈øe it canno ‚Ä¢ give the alarm but at too near a di≈øtance, and tha ‚Ä¢
ofttimes you have not lei≈øure to put your ≈øelf in order to fight; therefore you mu≈øt be carefull to ≈øend out di≈øcoverers every night, by divers ≈ømall troups, which (if they do well perform their task) will not ≈øuffer you to be ≈øurpri≈øed; for an army or a gro≈ø≈øe troup capable to a≈ø≈øail a quarter of an army cannot march ≈øo ≈øecretly that it be not perceived. And when you have to do with a vigilant enemy, and that you fear ≈øuch a≈ø≈øaults in the night, there is nothing ≈øo good as to prevent him, if it be not in earne≈øt, at lea≈øt to give him alarms every night, that ≈øo he may be more troubled about keeping him≈øelf upon his guards, then about a≈ø≈øailing you. If it be in an intrenched camp, where all the army is in one body, it is a high enterpri≈øe to a≈ø≈øault it. And this one chapter ≈øheweth the ≈øecurity of an intrenched camp‚ñ™ which I will end with this conclu≈øion, That all the forementioned things to a≈ø≈øure the quarters mu≈øt never be omitted, though you believe your ≈øelf to be far off from any enemy; for that, be≈øides the profit you draw from hence in accu≈øtoming your army to do their duties, there may ≈øuch an occa≈øion befall you as it may be the ≈øafety of your army, of your life, and of your reputation.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of encamping.
div.p:
I Will not here de≈øcribe the form of entrenched camps, but onely the profitablene≈ø≈øe of them, not being able to wonder enough that they have been wholly di≈øcontinued. No people made ≈øo exact u≈øe of them as the Romanes; and
in our time Maurice Prince of Orange hath revived the u≈øe of them, or at lea≈øt hath given them a great perfection. The entrenchment of a camp a≈ø≈øureth an army, in that it is never di≈øper≈øed in the villages, where ≈øome quarter or other is ever in danger to be ≈øurpri≈øed, but lodgeth all in one body, and in ≈øuch fa≈øhion as being a≈ø≈øailed it may fight with great advantage. The entrenchment ≈øaveth a great deal of trouble, becau≈øe by it there is need of the fewer guards by many, & tho≈øe le≈ø≈øe toil≈øome, e≈øpecially to the Cavalry, which when they are lodged in open villages, are con≈øtrained to be on hor≈øeback almo≈øt all night. The entrenchment enclo≈øeth your army as a walled city; from whence you may march privately with ≈øuch troups as you plea≈øe, to execute all ≈øorts of brave de≈øignes, leaving your baggage in ≈øafety. The entrenchment hindreth the enemy from con≈øtraining you to fight, unle≈ø≈øe when you plea≈øe. The entrenchment cau≈øeth you to be without danger at the head of the mo≈øt dreadfull armies. The entrenchment cau≈øeth you to take ≈øtrong cities in the face of more pui≈ø≈øant armies then your own. Briefly, the entrenchment is le≈ø≈øe ≈øubject to infection then the villages where you lodge, becau≈øe you choo≈øe a whol≈øome place to ≈øit down in, and in villages you mu≈øt take them as they fall out: Al≈øo, becau≈øe this is more ayrie, the lodgings are here better divided, tho≈øe things which may cau≈øe bad air are more ea≈øily removed; and in effect an army incamped and entrenched wil rather ≈øub≈øi≈øt three moneths in health in a camp, then a forthnight in the be≈øt villages. Whence I conclude, that one of the mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary parts of warre is,
well to know how to incamp and entrench.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of Battels.
div.p:
OF all the actions of warre the mo≈øt glorious and mo≈øt important is to give battel: the gaining of one or two acquireth or ≈øubverteth whole Empires. Anciently all warres were divided by battels, which cau≈øed ≈øuch ≈øpeedy conque≈øt: For the pre≈øent, warres are managed more fox-like then lion-like; and are rather founded upon ≈øieges then combats. Neverthethele≈ø≈øe, there be divers nations at this day which decide the mo≈øt part of their warres by battels, as the Turks and the Per≈øians: and even among≈øt the Chri≈øtians we have ≈øeen of late divers battels given in Germanie, whereof onely one had almo≈øt inthralled all the Prote≈øtant Princes. And an army well-di≈øciplined, and which feareth not battel, hath a marvellous advantage in all de≈øignes of that which feareth it. For this rea≈øon (how≈øoever the manner of warring at this time be not ≈øo frequent in the hazarding of battels as in times pa≈øt) the knowledge of them mu≈øt not be neglected. And a Generall of an army cannot be ≈øaid to be a good Captain, which knoweth not all advantages which may be taken on a day of battel, and all di≈øadvantages which ought to be avoyded; that ≈øo he may well di≈øintangle him≈øelf. I will not ≈øpeak of du≈øt, the ≈øunne or rain, whereof it is ob≈øerved that many Captains have made u≈øe, driving them on the face of the enemy by gaining the wind of them; becau≈øe they are ca≈øuall things which may change in a
moment, and which by con≈øequence happen rather by hazard then come by de≈øigne; but of things more ≈øolid.

He then that will give battel mu≈øt have regard to ≈øeven principall things. The fir≈øt is, never to ≈øuffer him≈øelf to be forced to fight again≈øt his will. The ≈øecond, to choo≈øe a field for the battel fit for the quality and number of his ≈øouldiers: for if he feareth to be inclo≈øed by a great number, he mu≈øt ≈øhelter his flanks‚ñ™ or at lea≈øt one of them, by the nature of the place; as by a river, wood, or ≈øome other thing equivalent: and if he be weak in his Cavalry, he mu≈øt avoid the plains; as he mu≈øt ≈øtrait pa≈ø≈øages or enclo≈øed places, if ≈øtronger. The third, ≈øo to range his army in battel, as according to the quality of his ≈øouldiers it may be within its own advantage, ≈øheltring his hor≈øe by his foot, if therein he be the weaker; and if the contrary, his foot by his hor≈øe; di≈øpo≈øing all his ≈øouldiers in ≈øuch order as they may fight divers times before they be wholly defeated: for if we well ob≈øerve the ≈ømall troups of ≈øouldiers which fight not all at once, and believe that a hundred hor≈øe in two troups wil beat two hundred in one entire troup, and have ob≈øerved in our times that divers battels have been won by him which had made a troup of re≈øerve, which was not to fight untill all the re≈øt had fought, how much greater effect will a ≈øecond order of battel produce, which will come to the charge after that all the adver≈øe army hath fought again≈øt the fir≈øt order‚ñ™ and yet after that a third, in imitation of the Romanes, if the two former be defeated It is a maxime, That every troup (how gro≈ø≈øe ≈øoever i ‚Ä¢
be) which hath fought, is in ≈øuch a di≈øorder as the lea≈øt troup that chargeth it, is able to defeat it ab≈øolutely: ≈øo that that Generall which can re≈øerve ≈øome troups to the la≈øt without fighting, will with tho≈øe bear away the victory: it being a long work and difficult to go about to rally an army that hath fought into good order to fight afre≈øh; ≈øome gazing about for pillage, others being vexed to return to the danger again, and all being ≈øo di≈øtracted as they do not or will not under≈øtand any command: on the contrary, ≈øuch as have not as yet fought, are under obedience, and ready to do what≈øoever their Generall ≈øhall command them. So that the knowledge of a Generall of an army is not ≈øo much to rally di≈øordered and defeated troups (which is properly but an action of courage) as to make his troups fight to good purpo≈øe, the one after the other, and not all at once: for he mu≈øt con≈øider that he cannot be well obeyed by his ≈øouldiers, but onely untill the houre that he ≈øendeth them to the combat. After that all the orations of the world will not ≈øtay them when they flie; but this troup which is in good order will ea≈øily do it. The fourth is, to have many good commanders, it being impo≈ø≈øible that a Generall ≈øhould ≈øuffice for all places. After that he hath made a good choice of his field for battel, and put his army into good order, it is altogether impo≈ø≈øible for him (when it cometh to blows) to give order, more then in that part where he is pre≈øent: ≈øo that if he be not well a≈øsi≈øted everywhere el≈øe, a≈øwell among≈øt the hor≈øe as foot, though he ≈øhould work miracles in that place where he him≈øelf is, he cannot make good the
ignorance of tho≈øe officers which command in the other parts of his army. Therefore there mu≈øt be at lea≈øt five principall commanders to make an army fight well, namely for three bodies of Infantery, di≈øtingui≈øhed by vanguard, battel, and rearguard, and two for the hor≈øe which are on the wings. The fifth is, ≈øo to ob≈øerve your di≈øtances in your order of battel, that the foremo≈øt troups being put to recoil, may not fall upon tho≈øe which ≈øhould come up to relieve theÃÑ, nor the ≈øecond upon the third. The ≈øixth is, to place the mo≈øt valiant ≈øouldiers on the wings of the army, and to begin the battel by that wing which you think to be ≈øtronge≈øt; for if you once break one of the enemies wings, you fall upon his flank and rear, and it is impo≈ø≈øible for him to re≈øi≈øt you. The ≈øeventh and la≈øt is, not to ≈øuffer any to pur≈øue the enemy, nor fall to pillaging, untill he be routed on all parts; and although it be good to give him a hot chace, you mu≈øt ever have ≈øome troups in order, which mu≈øt not disband, that ≈øo you may avoid all inconveniences. I will not ≈øpeak of the advantages which may be met with in a field of battel, whereof a good Captain often maketh u≈øe with great profit; becau≈øe there can no certain rule be given for it, by rea≈øon the diver≈øitie of ≈øituations is ≈øuch, that you ≈øhall never find two every-way alike.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of Fortre≈ø≈øes.
div.p: BEcau≈øe the gain and lo≈ø≈øe of battels draweth ≈øuch con≈øequences after it, as it giveth or taketh away whole Empires at once, it hath cau≈øed a re≈øolution of oppo≈øing the conquers by fortified places, to ≈øtay their fir≈øt fury with few men, and to ruine their armies: But ≈øince the invention of the cannon they have been enforced to change their manner of fortifications; and even by rea≈øon of the invention of petards we have beene con≈øtrained to a≈ø≈øure the gates of cities by portculices, palli≈øadoes, draw-bridges, and other inventions; becau≈øe there was no place, how ≈øtrong ≈øoever it were, which did not runne a hazard to be ≈øurpri≈øed by this new invention. Now the be≈øt fortre≈ø≈øes again≈øt the cannon are tho≈øe which are made of earth; becau≈øe (when they have a ≈øufficient thickne≈ø≈øe to make re≈øi≈øtance) they are not ≈øubject to endamage the be≈øieged, as tho≈øe fortifications are which are made of ma≈øons work, the ≈øhivers whereof do much mi≈øchief. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, when a Prince can be at the co≈øt to line them as high as the rampart, leaving the parapet upon it to be of earth cannon-proof, it maketh the work to la≈øt the longer.

In fortre≈ø≈øes you mu≈øt ob≈øerve foure principall things: namely, that the line of defen≈øe be within musket-≈øhot; that the flanked angle exceed not ninety degrees, nor be le≈ø≈øe then ≈øixty; that the gorge of the bul-wark be not too narrow; and that the flank be as great as may be. And
the≈øe foure generall maximes mu≈øt be ≈øo proportioned among≈øt them≈øelves, as that to make one of them exceeding good you de≈øtroy not the re≈øt. You mu≈øt al≈øo avoid tenailles in the principall body of fortification, unle≈ø≈øe the ground be ≈øo ≈ømall as it will not ≈øuffer you to make good flanks. For the interior angle of ≈øuch a fortification rai≈øed as it ought to be cannot be defended by any flank, and men may lodge them≈øelves at the foot of it without receiving any hurt, unle≈ø≈øe it be by ≈øtones thrown over. This is the rea≈øon why tenailles are not u≈øed but in the counter≈øcarps. The moats are u≈øually proportioned according to the earth nece≈ø≈øary to make the fortifications; and ≈øuch as are full of water are be≈øt to hinder a ≈øurpri≈øe, and the forts defend them≈øelves the be≈øt again≈øt an a≈ø≈øault: their breadth mu≈øt have a due proportion; for when they are too broad the out-works are too farre di≈øtant from the defen≈øe of the principall fortification; but depth never ≈øpoiled a moat. The fal≈øe brayes are joyned to the body of the fortification. It is anew invention and excellent to hinder the approching to the bulwarks by galleries. The counter≈øcarp, half-moons, ravelins, and horn-works are beyond the great moat; all the out-works (if it be po≈ø≈øible) mu≈øt be commanded by the body of the fortification. The≈øe are in gro≈ø≈øe the principall ob≈øervations which are in fortifications in a place which is levell and approchable: the re≈øt dependeth on the judgement of the Enginier, which mu≈øt make profitable u≈øe of the ≈øituation of the place which he is to fortifie, either in taking what ≈øerveth for his advantage, or in avoyding what≈øoever is to his
hinderance. I adde further, that there be ≈øituations ≈øo favourable, as nature it ≈øelf defendeth them, and maketh them more inexpugnable then all the art in the world; as an inacce≈ø≈øible rock, a quagmire or a lake: But every commodity hath its di≈øcommodity; ≈øeldome you ≈øhall meet with ≈øuch ≈øituations on frontier-places, or upon any important pa≈ø≈øage, or capable to contein a garri≈øon of ≈øufficient ≈øtrength to give ‚Ä¢ ealou≈øie to an enemy which would invade your countrey; or el≈øe they are found ≈øo ea≈øie to be blocked up, as five hundred men without are able to be≈øiege five hundred within.

They which de≈øire to know the particularities of fortification, may find them among≈øt an infinite number of books where they are de≈øcribed; but much better in the exerci≈øe of warre, where expe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ence cau≈øeth every day ≈øomething to be added.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of defen≈øe again≈øt ≈øurpri≈øes.
div.p: NOw that we have ≈øpoken of fortre≈ø≈øes, we mu≈øt come to the way of guarding them, and not ≈øuffer them to be ≈øurpri≈øed. It is mo≈øt certain that men will alwayes attempt to take them by ≈øurpri≈øe rather then by open force; for that thereby they ≈øave charge and time. But becau≈øe ≈øurpri≈øes are grounded upon ≈øome defects which they find in the place, or in the guard thereof, I will begin with that which mu≈øt be ob≈øerved to defend your ≈øelf again≈øt ≈øuch ≈øurpri≈øes.

The Captain which ≈øhall have a place to guard mu≈øt provide for ≈øix principall things,
whereon all the re≈øt depend: namely, to ≈øee that the walls be out of danger of a ≈øcalado; the gates not ≈øubject to the petard; the way for the rounds ea≈øie and convenient; the ≈øentinels well ≈øet; the guard very exact; and to hinder intelligences and treacheries. For the five fir≈øt, the way is beaten for them, there be books full of in≈øtructions, a ‚Ä¢ d there be now ≈øo many Princes orders in writing and in practice, as he mu≈øt be very negligent which is not carefull therein. But for the la≈øt it is not ≈øo ea≈øie to give rules. Treachery may be wrought by the town≈ømen or ≈øouldiers: the mingling of them together, whether it be on the guards, rounds, or patroullies, may much hinder it; as al≈øo the drawing all the functions of the guard by lot, the keeping a guard without the town, and the having of ≈øpies among≈øt the enemies. You mu≈øt double your guards at times of fairs and markets, in harve≈øt and time of ‚Ä¢ intage, becau≈øe men u≈øe to ≈øpy out ≈øuch times to frame a de≈øigne. You mu≈øt ob≈øerve to be in arms at the opening and ≈øhutting of the gates; and in what≈øoever time of peace it may be, you mu≈øt never neglect the ob≈øervation of any of the≈øe particulars. There is al≈øo a way to avoid intelligences, namely, by making double enterpri≈øes your ≈øelf, feigning to di≈øcontent an officer, private ≈øouldier, or town≈øman, who running over to the enemy, cau≈øeth him to undertake ≈øome de≈øigne probably fei≈øible and facil: for be≈øides the profit which you gain by it, by getting the bolde≈øt of them in a trap, you reap this advantage by it, that your enemie dreameth on no other ≈øo long as he hopeth in that; for that every one alwayes undertaketh
that which he believeth will ≈øucceed mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly. Whereby we may ≈øee how doubtfull tho≈øe enterpri≈øes are which are grounded upon intelligence, either for that they may be double, or el≈øe by the fault of traitours, which in the very point of execution may lo≈øe courage and di≈øcover all; or by their indi≈øcretions and not keeping ≈øecret their negotiations. For the≈øe rea≈øons in enterpri≈øes made upon intelligence both the defendant and a≈ø≈øailant mu≈øt be very ≈øu≈øpicious and exceeding diligent to ob≈øerve the words, actions and behaviour of ≈øuch as promi≈øe to ≈øerve them by betraying their own ≈øide, and to omit no precautions to a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves of their per≈øons, ≈øo that they may not catch them; the ho≈øtages of women and children being not alwayes ≈øufficient (as Montluc ob≈øerveth at the enterpri≈øe of Darges) for that ≈øome traitours are ≈øo re≈øolute as they will hazard all to attein the height of their de≈øignes, and make account to relea≈øe their pledges by ≈øuch pri≈øoners as they intend to take.

There remaineth a word to be ≈øpoken of alarms. You may therein u≈øe two wayes: the fir≈øt and u≈øuall way is to put your ≈øelf in order in the allarm-place, where the governour mu≈øt be pre≈øent, that ≈øo from thence he may lead to the place of danger; the ≈øecond is, for every company to repair to their colours, and from thence to go and find out their ≈øquadron which is upon the guard. If the garri≈øon be weak, the ≈øcalado ea≈øie, and the place large, this la≈øt way of going to the alarm is the be≈øt, becau≈øe they go more readily to the defen≈øe of the walls; but in this ca≈øe they mu≈øt have no ≈øu≈øpicion of the fidelitie of the inhabitants.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of a≈ø≈øaults by ≈øurpri≈øes.
div.p:
THe enterpri≈øes of fortified places are made after ≈øeverall fa≈øhions, either by petard, or by ≈øcalado, or by ≈øome holes in the wals, or by ≈øaucidges, or by ≈øome ≈øuch other wayes and inventions which men ≈øeek every day to encrea≈øe, according to the mea≈øure of the remedies again≈øt ≈øuch as are alreadie invented. But to make them take good effect you mu≈øt be very carefull of three things; namely, intelligence, conducting, and execution: for for want of one of the≈øe we ≈øee all enterpri≈øes mi≈øcarry; either by being prevented by the day-light, or being di≈øcovered too ≈øoon, or for want of ≈øome petard or ladder, or by ≈øome di≈øorder in the execution. For the fir≈øt, which is intelligence, they which are imployed in it mu≈øt inform them≈øelves exactly of the form of the garri≈øon, number of the town≈ømen, and of their affections. They mu≈øt ob≈øerve at the gates whether there be a bridge dormant to come at them; whether it be of wood or ≈øtone; and if of wood, whether they u≈øe not to take away ≈øome planks in the night-time; whether this bridge hath not rails: whe ‚Ä¢ her the moat be deep and broad, and whether by a commodious de≈øcending into the moat you may e≈øcape the draw-bridge, which is u≈øually made upon the bridge dormant: or whether by the benefit of the moat the gate or draw bridge of the town may be petarded without carriages or rolling-bridge. They mu≈øt well ob≈øerve all the hindrances which may be before
the bridge dormant, whether they be gates, barres, palli≈øadoes, or portculices, there being u≈øually a ravelin: and whether there be a corps du-guard kept in the night, either on the out≈øide or upon the bridge dormant: taking notice how many gates, bridges, barres, palli≈øadoes, portculices, trap-doores, grates, iron-pinnes, chains, and other impediments what≈øoever there be from the field to the in≈øide of the town, and how all the≈øe things are fa≈øtened: how many paces of di≈øtance there may be from one piece to another, and (as near as may be) the length, breadth and thickne≈ø≈øe of all tho≈øe things, and in what places they are: whether there be loopholes over the gate, or holes in the roof of it: how many corps du-guards there be, in what places they are, and how ≈øituated; whether the entrance be ≈øtraight on, or winding; ob≈øerving the place of the flanks, whether they be on the ≈øide before, behind, above, or below; whether they keep any ordinance there, and how many; or whether they be onely for musketiers; what number may be lodged on them, and at what di≈øtance they flank the ‚Ä¢ ate; di≈øcovering the way by which you are to go from the town you go from to that which you intend to a≈ø≈øail: To ≈øpie out a fitting place within half a league of it to alight, and to di≈øtribute the petards and other in≈øtruments: they mu≈øt al≈øo ob≈øerve the places and ≈øtreets within the town which mu≈øt be ≈øei≈øed upon, all the corps du-guards to be forced; and well con≈øider the condi ‚Ä¢ ion of the ≈øouldiers, and other nece≈ø≈øarie things, to ≈øurmount all ob≈øtacles which might be met with. If it be to give them a ≈øcalado, they mu≈øt well ob≈øerve
the dvenues, the counter≈øcarp and the moat; to know whether you may come at it undi≈øcovered, go down into the moat, and come up out of it ea≈øily, e≈øpecially over again≈øt the place where you would make the ≈øcalado, or near it. For if you mu≈øt go farre about the town after you be entred into the moat, the enterpri≈øe becometh much the more dangerous and difficult. It mu≈øt be known whether the moat be drie or frozen, or that the water be but ≈øhallow, without mud and ea≈øie to pa≈ø≈øe; whether the wall be low or weak, ≈øo as it may ea≈øily be ≈øcaled or pierced, or whether there be ≈øome hole or drain or other means for the water to pa≈ø≈øe in or out which are ill guarded or weak. You mu≈øt judge what height your ladders mu≈øt be of, and regard how they may be ≈øet on ≈øure footing, and whether there be a ≈øcarp or not; whether the place where you mean to give on be far from guards or ≈øentinels; whether the place of ≈øcalado be capable to rai≈øe good ≈øtore of ladders, and for ≈øtore of men to enter at once: as if it were very ≈øtrait, you mu≈øt ≈øee if the fir≈øt being entred can accommodate them≈øelves upon the rampart to ≈øub≈øi≈øt ≈øo long untill the re≈øt mount. You mu≈øt al≈øo ob≈øerve the di≈øtances of the wall to enter into the town, and to go and ≈øet upon the corps du-guard.

For the ≈øecond, which is the conducting, it may be made two wayes, by parts or in gro≈ø≈øe: by parts, when they are de≈øignes upon places of importance, and which are farre within an enemies countrey, and whereof the enterpri≈øes are held to be very f ‚Ä¢ i≈øible in the execution; for they may not fail, without putting all the ≈øouldiers which
go on that ≈øervice into eminent danger: therefore there mu≈øt be great prudence u≈øed, and none imployed in it but re≈øolute men and ≈øecret, becau≈øe they mu≈øt either there overcome or peri≈øh; which happeneth not in ≈øuch enterpri≈øes where there is as great care taken of the ≈øafety of retreating as of giving on. The Mar≈øhall of Bri≈øac made one (being in Piedmont) upon the ca≈øtle of Millain, which was excellently well conducted, and de≈øerveth to be here taken notice of, to ≈øerve for a le≈ø≈øon for ≈øuch as may de≈øire to undertake the like. He made choice of eightie French men and fourtie Italians, the brave≈øt and re≈øolute≈øt ≈øouldiers of all his army, and made Salvai≈øon Captain of the French, and Peter Maria of Recuperat of Bre≈øignolle commander of the Italians, which two onely knew whither they were to go: then he cau≈øed them to come by five at once to his Secretaries lodging, and cau≈øed twenty five crowns to be given to each of them, and to the chief man of every five there was a note given, wherein was ≈øpecified the way they were to take, and the dayes journeyes they were to go, that ≈øo the brigadoes might not meet each other. The fir≈øt rendez ‚Ä¢ vous was at an out-hou≈øe (or farm-hou≈øe) on the confines of Millanois, whither Lodowick Birague had conveyed him≈øelf ≈øome dayes before very ≈øecretly in di≈øgui≈øed apparel, to give ≈øuch order to this de≈øigne as ≈øhould be nece≈ø≈øary. The manner of meeting at this farm-hou≈øe was thus; At the parting from the valley Camonica or Bergama≈øque, the fir≈øt five or brigado (and ≈øo by turns all the re≈øt) found a countrey-fellow having a ≈øtraw-hat with two phea≈øants feathers on it; to whom the chief
man of every brigado was to ≈øay, O buon compagno, voi tu vender my quella capelina! that is, Ho, good fellow, wilt thou ≈øell me that hat? to which he was to an≈øwer, Me≈ø≈øer no, ne ho bi≈øogno per me; that is, No ≈øir, I must u≈øe it my ≈øelf. That was the watchword; which being ≈øo known, the chief (without ≈øpeaking a word) followed the countrey-fellow, which conducted him with his brigado to the farm-hou≈øe where Lodowick Birague was; and in this wi≈øe the Mar≈øhall of Bri≈øac his hundred and twenty ≈øouldiers pa≈ø≈øed very ≈øecretly to that place. From this farm-hou≈øe they were to get to the hou≈øe of one of Sienna near Millain, who was the plotter of the de≈øigne: to this end they pa≈ø≈øed along as before, by five and five together, and after they had pa≈ø≈øed the river Adde at the haven of Vaure, they had mea≈øured the time to arrive towards night at the bridge Navilio of Millain, near the Mona≈øtery of Angels; on which bridge being arrived, the chief of the brigado ≈øhaked a little bell, at the ≈øound of which he was an≈øwered by another like it, and pre≈øently there came (from below the bridge) the man of Sienna (the authour of this de≈øigne) who conducted the brigado to his own hou≈øe, and continued after this manner every night, untill the whole troup was pa≈øt: which is a matter worth the ob≈øerving, to cau≈øe a hundred and twenty ≈øouldiers to go by ≈øtealth from Piedmont to the very gates of Millain, without being di≈øcovered, and not a man of them (except onely Salvai≈øon and Peter Maria of Recuperat) untill then, knowing whither they went or where they were. Concerning the conducting in gro≈ø≈øe, which is
the more ordinary, you mu≈øt mea≈øure the length of the way to the place upon which you have your de≈øigne, with the time which you mu≈øt have to arrive at the ju≈øt time to execute it: wherein many deceive them≈øelves very often, for that u≈øually there befall unexpected ca≈øualties which prolong the time; in≈øomuch that what mea≈øures ≈øoever you take (without great experience in ≈øuch actions) you ≈øhall commonly find the time too ≈øhort, e≈øpecially if you have a gro≈ø≈øe troup to lead. For to make two thou≈øand men to march by night in their long order, the Altes which mu≈øt be made at the head to ≈øtay for the rear, or tho≈øe which a narrow or trouble≈øome way, or that is cut off by a river compell you to make, are ≈øuch, and cau≈øe you to lo≈øe ≈øo much time, that unle≈ø≈øe you be very diligent to make them march, and that you have cau≈øed good intelligence to be taken of the way, and provided for all the≈øe things, you will find you have not half time enough. I ≈øpeak not of the great ≈øhowers of rain, nor of fro≈øts, which ≈øometimes happen ≈øo unlooked for and extraordinary, that, what fore≈øight ≈øoever you may have u≈øed in all other things, it is impo≈ø≈øible to overcome them. After that you have proportioned the time with the way, you mu≈øt provide your ≈øelf of good guides, and as many of them as may be: then you mu≈øt form your order before you depart, as it ≈øhould be at the execution, giving to every man your commands in writing of what he is to do, and keeping a regi≈øter thereof. For if you deferre to do it untill you come upon the place where you are to alight, and where all the equipage is to be accommodated (which is u≈øually about half
a league from the place) may hinder you therein, the place haply will not be ≈øpacious enough nor commodious to make the order, contentions which may befall, jealou≈øie of honour among≈øt the ≈øouldiers, and divers unthought-of accidents wch ari≈øe, are able to fru≈øtrate the de≈øigne: which things being re≈øolved on before your going out, and there being nothing to be changed in your order, this (mo≈øt certainly) is the means to avoid ≈øuch ob≈øtacles. I adde this, That if it be a citie from whence you go out, you mu≈øt keep the gates ≈øhut long before and after; and cau≈øe the troups to march by day, that ≈øo you may ≈øee that not a man go out but they of the enterpri≈øe. And afterwards to cau≈øe the troups to make Alte, beyond the gate or in ≈øome private place near hand. Concerning the order; you mu≈øt cau≈øe ≈øome hor≈øe to march foremo≈øt, who≈øe ≈øcouts mu≈øt have charge to ride farre enough before, and to ≈øei≈øe upon all ≈øorts of per≈øons where≈øoever they go, that ≈øo they may hinder the giving of intelligence to the town which you intend to ≈øurpri≈øe; e≈øpecially if there be ≈øome bridge or pa≈ø≈øage by which unavoydably you mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe, you mu≈øt gain that. Then mu≈øt fifty musketiers follow; next the train, the petards or ladders, being followed by tho≈øe men which are cho≈øen to carry them; whereof there mu≈øt be a treble number, to ea≈øe and ≈øucceed each other, in ca≈øe any be hurt or killed: and the≈øe mu≈øt be men of execution, the mo≈øt re≈øolute and adventurous of the troup; for on the≈øe foremo≈øt u≈øually the good or bad ≈øucce≈ø≈øe dependeth: you mu≈øt al≈øo carry double equipage of petards, becau≈øe all work not that effect which you purpo≈øe they
≈øhould; and often the want of one petard hath cau≈øed brave enterpri≈øes to fail, and ≈øo of ladders, which are often broken by the enemies, or break by being too much laden. In the pur≈øuit you mu≈øt not make any troup of above fifty ≈øouldiers, namely fifty muskets, then fifty pikes, and ≈øo ≈øucce≈ø≈øively: for you mu≈øt con≈øider that the fir≈øt encounters are in narrow ≈øtreets, and in the night; ≈øo that the gro≈ø≈øe troups cau≈øe but di≈øorder. And if you find ≈øtreets that are broader then the order which you have framed, you mu≈øt joyn two troups together, that ≈øo they may take up the whole breadth of the ≈øtreet. Every troup mu≈øt have officers at the front and rear of it, and the ≈øergeants on the flanks, to keep them to their duties, and to hinder them from ≈øtraggling and pillaging. You mu≈øt al≈øo ob≈øerve in the order you make (when you part from your quarter) that if you make ≈øeverall a≈ø≈øaults, the commanders, ≈øouldiers, and equipage mu≈øt be di≈øtingui≈øhed into ≈øo many troups as you will make a≈ø≈øaults, and that they march according to the order they ≈øhould a≈ø≈øail in. In all enterpri≈øes (e≈øpecially in tho≈øe where the retreat is dangerous and long) you mu≈øt more regard to have good ≈øouldiers then many; for a ≈ømall troup may come from farther off, march more ≈øecretly, and retreat with le≈ø≈øe danger and confu≈øion then a gro≈ø≈øe troup. Be≈øides, a ≈ømall troup with good ≈øtore of officers, is more obedient in execution, and begetteth le≈ø≈øe di≈øorder then a gro≈ø≈øe, I adde further, that in enterpri≈øes by night you affright an enemy as much with a ≈ømall troup as with a great one: for it is a maxime, That they which are ≈øurpri≈øed and a≈ø≈øailed fight in fear, alwayes
per≈øwading them≈øelves that you a≈ø≈øail them with forces ≈øufficient.
