Briefly, if you overcome with a ≈ømall troup you get more honour then if it had been with a great, which ofttimes di≈øturbeth you both in fight, in march, and in their retreat: and if you be beaten, the di≈øhonour is the le≈ø≈øe. Concerning the third, which is the execution, all the order mu≈øt be given in writing, that ≈øo none of them which have any command in the enterpri≈øe may excu≈øe them≈øelves by pretending they mi≈øunder≈øtood you. If it be by ≈øcalado, there mu≈øt be 2 men to carry every piece of a ladder; and becau≈øe it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to do the execution upon a place where there needeth more then five pieces of ladders in height, it is ≈øufficient that there be ten men for every ladder, and one man to command them: The men for every ladder mu≈øt be mentioned in a roll by their names and ≈øurnames, and of what company they be. You mu≈øt command them on pain of death to bring back their ladders if you cannot get the town: for they ≈øeeing the danger and trouble of bringing them back again, will rather de≈øire to do their uttermo≈øt endeavour to enter the town moreover you mu≈øt command ten other men to enter after the fir≈øt ten, which mu≈øt be led by an officer, and another to be on their rear to take care to ≈øee them mount without lo≈øing of time and without making too much ha≈øt: otherwi≈øe the ladders will be ≈øo much laden as that they will break; after this, ten more mu≈øt follow, commanded and divided as the former: and every file of ten mu≈øt know by which ladder they mu≈øt mount, and in what order, that ≈øo al ‚Ä¢ may be done without confu≈øion. The fir≈øt te ‚Ä¢
which follow their ladder mu≈øt carry another, though they have no order to rai≈øe it; that ≈øo if any piece of the fir≈øt ≈øhould break, there may another be rai≈øed in the ≈øtead. If it be by petard, the petardier ≈øhall call him that is to carry the madrier or planchier; then he is to call three for the petard (two to carry it, and the third to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in time of need) and if the planchier be fa≈øtned to the petard, theÃÑ foure men may carry it interchangeably by two and two: and tho≈øe two which carry not the petard with the planchier ≈øhall each of them have a great ≈ømiths hammer. After the≈øe foure, the petardier ≈øhall call two men, each of them carrying a great ax; after them one with a crow-lever, then another with a dark-lantern, then one with three or foure pieces of lighted matches: be≈øides the≈øe there mu≈øt be one to command them, which ≈øhall carry a piercing in≈øtrument, or a coopers turrell, or ≈øome good hooks with ≈øteeled points, and a weighty hammer. So that to attend every petard well there mu≈øt be ten men; this file of ten for the fir≈øt petard ≈øhall be led by ≈øome brave Sergeant, which ≈øhall have the name of every man of his file in writing, and ≈øhall al≈øo know what every of them is to carry. The men mu≈øt know the Mule which carrieth their equipage, and ≈øo ≈øoon as they come to the place where they are to unlade, they mu≈øt place them≈øelves about the Mule, that ≈øo each of them may receive what he is to carry. If the ≈øecond petard mu≈øt be applied to a gate or barres, they which ≈øhall carry it mu≈øt be in the ≈øame order as they of the fir≈øt petard: but if it be for a draw-bridge, the rolling-bridge or carriage goeth formo≈øt, with ≈øeven or
eight men which are imployed as well to carry it as to pu≈øh it forward: after this the planchier and petard mu≈øt be carried, after the ≈øame manner as the fir≈øt; then ≈øhall they follow (in file and in clo≈øe order) which carry the ladders and planks to ca≈øt upon the breach which the petard ≈øhall have made upon the draw-bridge; then ≈øhall they follow which carry haÃÑmers, hatchets, pin≈øoÃÑs, in≈øtruments to pull out bolts and to cut chains; then ≈øome with fire-lances and granadoes, and ≈øome dark lanterns. The officer which ≈øhall have the leading of them mu≈øt take care that not a man lo≈øe his rank, and ≈øhall divide them into files, and ≈øhall take care to cau≈øe the ≈øpare men to carry ≈øuch portions of the equipage as they did carry which ≈øhall happen to be hurt or killed, which he ≈øhall onely cau≈øe to be laid out of the way, without ≈øuffering tho≈øe which are to be imployed about the ≈øervice of the petard to trouble them≈øelves about carrying away any man that is killed or hurt. At all the gates and bridges the men mu≈øt be di≈øpo≈øed in the ≈øame order. But when you go again≈øt iron-grates or portcullices, you mu≈øt cau≈øe tho≈øe to march fir≈øt which carry the tre≈ø≈øes or iron-hooks; then marcheth the planchier and the petard; after which follow hammers, hatchets, crows of iron, and other in≈øtruments which may be thought fitting: you mu≈øt not forget to carry fire-balls, granadoes, or fire-lances, if you have ob≈øerved that you may make u≈øe of them; every man mu≈øt carry a hatchet at his girdle: you mu≈øt rather have a ≈øupernumerary number of in≈øtruments, then want one. Having thus put all into order, and officers at the head and on the flanks of every file,
you mu≈øt have be≈øides ≈øome petards, planchiers, and other in≈øtruments for re≈øerve, which mu≈øt be carried in the ≈øame order as the ‚Ä¢ ther: For you mu≈øt alwayes have a double equipage. When you come near the place where the execution is to be done, you mu≈øt di≈øtribute to every man what he is to carry. The Sergeant ordereth them in file, and commandeth every one duly to follow his leader: then he cau≈øeth them to march forward to give room to tho≈øe of the ≈øecond petard; and ≈øo con≈øequently of all the re≈øt, there being a guide for the fir≈øt file to ≈øhew them the way. And that you may not be intangled, ≈øometimes you may cau≈øe ten cuiraciers to march before one foot, to di≈øcover whether the enemy be not on the advenues; then follow three men bearing good targets, to ≈øhelter (among≈øt others) the petardier; then march they which carry the petards and the other train, in ≈øuch order as hath been ≈øaid, which ≈øhall be followed by fifty muskets led by a Captain, to give fire for their defen≈øe (if need be) with large hail≈øhot. He mu≈øt look that no man ≈øtay by the way as they march; when the enemy asketh, Who goeth there, they mu≈øt ha≈øten their pace, and then the petardier taketh the fir≈øt petard with him, and the re≈øt mu≈øt follow very clo≈øe, that ≈øo when the fir≈øt is fired the ≈øecond be ready to be put into his hands. The ten hor≈ømen which have marched before all the equipage ≈øo farre, ≈øhall not advance further then the di≈øtance of pi≈øtoll-≈øhot from the fir≈øt bars; then they ≈øhall fall back to the Captain which leadeth the fifty musketiers. The fir≈øt petard being fired, the officer ≈øhall cau≈øe his men to be placed on the right and left hand,
to give room for the ≈øecond petard; then that ≈øhall do the ≈øame, to give pa≈ø≈øage to the third; then that maketh room for the rolling-bridge, and they for the petards and other in≈øtruments, and con≈øequently all the re≈øt. And they which are unladen mu≈øt help the re≈øt, without making any noi≈øe. And if the petardier calleth for any thing, he that carrieth it mu≈øt be ready to give it him, and no man upon pain of death mu≈øt ≈øtirre out of the place where he was placed, but onely to give to the petardier what he calleth for, or to ≈øupply ≈øome bodies place which in carrying ≈øomething to the petardier was hurt or killed. The officers mu≈øt take care that the petardier be pre≈øently ≈øerved, and all be done without noi≈øe or confu≈øion. The ouverture being made, they which ≈øhall be commanded for the fir≈øt attempts mu≈øt be ready to enter, and to force what≈øoever ≈øhall re≈øi≈øt them; they which are to follow them mu≈øt do the like, and ≈øo con≈øequently all the re≈øt which are to act any thing: And when they are within, they which fir≈øt entred mu≈øt not ≈øcatter them≈øelves in the town (while≈øt they are yet weak) whether it be in pur≈øuing the enemy, or though they meet none: but they mu≈øt make two bodies, the one to act, the other onely to be put into battalia to ≈øu≈øtein the re≈øt. This done, they mu≈øt march in good order, the one to force that whereunto they are appointed, the other to go and embattel them≈øelves in the ≈øtreets and market-places which you had re≈øolved ought to be ≈øei≈øed upon, by the plat or draught of the town, by which the whole enterpri≈øe ought to have been de≈øigned. For how≈øoever it hath ≈øometimes ≈øucceeded well to fo ‚Ä¢ low the
enemy ≈øpeedily with ≈øuch few men as are entred, yet is it not the ≈øure≈øt way, becau≈øe they may be repul≈øed by a few men; which hath often cau≈øed brave enterpri≈øes to be fru≈øtrated.

There mu≈øt al≈øo be a third body which mu≈øt ≈øtand in battalia without during the execution, to the end that if they which entred ≈øhould be repul≈øed, they may ≈øu≈øtein them; or el≈øe to remedy ≈øuch accidents which might befall them by ≈øome of the enemies troups, which ca≈øually might arrive in that place. If you be wholly repul≈øed, that troup which is without ≈øhall make the retreat, and ≈øhall remain firm in battalia untill that the repul≈øed troups be recollected and put in order: but if they which entred become ma≈øters of the town, to hold it they mu≈øt di≈øarm the town≈ømen before they di≈øarm them≈øelves. And being well a≈ø≈øured of all the corps du-guards and commodious places, the hou≈øes mu≈øt be ≈øhared, that ≈øo every man may have his proportion of the bootie, they being not ≈øuffered to take it any other way; and they which ≈øhall begin to pillage mu≈øt be ≈øeverely puni≈øhed. By this means you may appoint the be≈øt hou≈øes to them which have be≈øt de≈øerved, and do the re≈øt by lot, whereof no man ≈øhall have cau≈øe to complain but of his own ill fortune. If it be needfull, in ≈øuch places as are a≈ø≈øailed by ≈øcalado, you may di≈øpo≈øe ≈øome troups of musketiers, which ≈øhall give fire perpetually upon the flanks; and if you can, you may adde to them ≈øome fire-lances: and ≈øuch as give fire at the top of the ladder, mu≈øt cea≈øe ≈øo ≈øoon as their men begin to mount. I have been more particular in this chapter then in any other; but ≈øo many enterpri≈øes have failed
by the not ob≈øerving of the lea≈øt of the≈øe things, that I rather cho≈øe to be ≈øomewhat long herein then to omit them.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of a≈ø≈øaults by ≈øieges.
div.p: IN the two chapters of ≈øurpri≈øes I have begun with the means to defend ones ≈øelf, for that we mu≈øt never undertake to attempt the ≈øurpri≈øe of any fort, but upon the defects which are to be found in them: ≈øo that he which knoweth not on which part nor after which manner he ought to make his a≈ø≈øault, mu≈øt be prepared for all manner of accidents. In the≈øe two I will begin to treat of the a≈ø≈øailing of towns by ≈øieges, for that you mu≈øt ob≈øerve by what place and after what manner you are a≈ø≈øailed, to make a good defen≈øe again≈øt it.

Sieges are undertaken either by blocking up of towns to fami≈øh them, or by taking them by force; for both the one and the other you mu≈øt be ma≈øter of the field, and you mu≈øt have two armies, the one to hinder the enemy from undertaking any thing, and the other to form your ≈øiege. Or in any ca≈øe you mu≈øt be the fir≈øt in the field, that you may ≈øo fortifie your ≈øelf before the town you be≈øiege as you may be able to maintein your ≈øelf there in ≈øpite of the furious attempts of the enemy. To get the town which you mean to be≈øiege at the ea≈øier rate, you mu≈øt attempt to ≈øurpri≈øe it when there is but a ≈ømall garri≈øon in it: to this end you are to u≈øe all manner of inventions to keep them from the knowledge of your purpo≈øe to be≈øiege it; then all on a ≈øudden you
mu≈øt go and block it up. But if (notwith≈øtanding all your ≈øtratagemes) you be not able to ≈øurpri≈øe it at unawares, or that you apprehend the charge to be too great, it will be better to make ≈øome other ≈øiege of le≈ø≈øe importance: for a town well and ob≈øtinately defended is the ruine of an army; and if it be not taken, it often dimini≈øheth the reputation of the commander which a≈ø≈øailed it.

For this cau≈øe, before you undertake any ≈øuch thing, it mu≈øt be well con≈øidered on; and you mu≈øt provide your ≈øelf abundantly of all things nece≈ø≈øary to effect it. When you form a ≈øiege, you mu≈øt appoint your quarters (a≈ømuch as may be) in healthfull places, and be carefull to make them ≈øpacious enough, and to keep them clean: for you mu≈øt account upon your time of abode there, that your army be not wa≈øted by di≈øea≈øes. You mu≈øt make the quarters of your army ≈øo near the town be≈øieged as may be, yet ≈øo as they be not di≈øcommodated by their artillerie: And if the ground be level and lie open round about, the quarters mu≈øt be out of reach of the cannon. You mu≈øt make as many quarters as the places are which you intend to a≈ø≈øault, or at lea≈øt as the bigne≈ø≈øe of the town be≈øieged, or the ≈øituation thereof requireth. Neverthele≈ø≈øe I would have the Generals quarters to be ≈øo large, as (in a ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity) it might receive all the troups of the other quarters; If you make a ≈øiege with a ≈ømall army, and that the garri≈øon be ≈øtrong, you mu≈øt fortifie the quarters one after another, with the whole body of the army; and in this ca≈øe you mu≈øt make the fewer quarters, and attempt the fewer places. But if you find
your ≈øelf ≈øtrong enough you may abbridge the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe and make them all at once. Be≈øides this, you mu≈øt make a circumvallation wi h forts and redoubts without reach of cannon of the be≈øieged, which ≈øhall joyn all the quarters one to the other, behind which your army may pre≈øent it ≈øelf in battalia, and this line mu≈øt be led in ≈øuch manner as it may po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe all the commanding places. And if the garri≈øon of the town be≈øieged be ≈øo ≈øtrong as you may fear to be a≈ø≈øailed on both ≈øides, you mu≈øt make another circumvallation about the town, the neare≈øt that may be, that ≈øo it may require the fewer men to guard it: for it being made to oppo≈øe your ≈øelf again≈øt the town, you need not take care to make it out of the reach of the cannon. For the opening of the trenches, you are to u≈øe the more or fewer ceremonies, according as the garri≈øon is ≈øtrong or weak. If it be ≈øtrong, you begin by a good fort, and continue by good redoubts along the trenches, leaving onely ≈øentinels in them. For it is an old errour to think to defend trenches. If the garri≈øon be weak, you need not make ≈øo much ado to gain time. The batteries mu≈øt be well ≈øtrengthened by good moats, and flanked by good corps-du-guards, to pre≈øerve them again≈øt the ≈øallies of the be≈øieged. If there be any outworks which are not yet in good defen≈øe, and which may be carried by force, you mu≈øt attempt them; otherwi≈øe you mu≈øt approch them by little and little: for it is there where the brave≈øt defen≈øe is made, becau≈øe that at the beginning they can ea≈øilie≈øt make their ≈øallies. When the outworks are taken, and the cannon is planted on the counter≈øcarp, and you ≈øap into
the moat, and prepare your ≈øelf to lay over your galleries to get over to the bulwarks, you mu≈øt then place your musketiers all along the counter≈øcarp, that ≈øo under favour of them and of your cannon you may pa≈ø≈øe over your galleries. If the moats be drie, they will di≈øpute it with you, but at la≈øt the ≈øtronger overcometh the weaker. If they be full of ≈øtanding water, that hindereth you not from making your caw≈øie whereupon you place your gallerie: If they be full of running water, you mu≈øt make u≈øe of floting bridges to put over your miners. When you are got clo≈øe to the bulwarks, you are to u≈øe mines (great or ≈ømall) ≈øo by little and little to get into the ground, and the retrenchments which may be made behind the bulwarks. I trouble not my ≈øelf here to ≈øhew how to make the quarters, forts, circumvallations, the trenches, (that they lie not open to the enemy) the batteries, (that they be well a≈ø≈øured) the de≈øcents into the moat, how to a≈ø≈øail the fal≈øe brayes, how the galleries are to be made, al≈øo the mines, and the lodgings which are to be made after they be ≈øprung; becau≈øe what≈øoever may be ≈øaid on that ≈øubject is alreadie written, and it mu≈øt be experience that mu≈øt perfect the re≈øt; where every day ≈øomething is altered or ≈øome new thing is added.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the defen≈øe of towns again≈øt ≈øieges.
div.p:
TO with≈øtand a ≈øiege well, the town mu≈øt be well fortified, it mu≈øt have a ≈øufficient number of ≈øouldiers to defend it; it mu≈øt abound in victuall; and it mu≈øt have good ≈øtore of arms and munitions of warre: And the≈øe foure things are ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, as that if there were an abundance of three of them, if the fourth be wanting the re≈øt will ≈øerve for nothing. For what will a well fortified place ≈øerve for if there be not ≈øouldiers to defend it? or what good will ≈øouldiers do if they have neither arms nor munitions of warre to fight? neither will arms nor munitions avail, if they want bread to live by; to which I adde in≈øtruments to work in the earth, without which it is impo≈ø≈øible to make any great re≈øi≈øtance. But it is not enough to have all that is nece≈ø≈øary for re≈øi≈øtance; there mu≈øt be a good order and rule kept, otherwi≈øe it will all be di≈ø≈øipated by tho≈øe which will de≈øire to get out of danger quickly, and will find ≈øome pretext to yield upon terms which ≈øhall not be di≈øhonourable; the number of ≈øuch being alwayes greater then of tho≈øe which will re ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt ≈øtoutly. You mu≈øt proportion the labour an ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt among≈øt the ≈øouldiers and the town≈ømen, that ≈øo they which are well affected be not ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and that the re≈øt grow not lazie through idlene≈ø≈øe. They mu≈øt be di≈øtingui≈øhed by companies of pioners, miners, carpenters, ≈ømiths, and all artificers u≈øefull for a ≈øiege, appointing a commander to every of them.
You mu≈øt take an inventory in the town of all the iron, wood, linen, in≈øtruments to work in the ground, drugs fit for artificiall fires, and other ≈øuch things nece≈ø≈øary for a ≈øiege: and take care that there be alwayes of them in the magazins to ≈øerve for the pre≈øent nece≈ø≈øity: and to avoid di≈øorder in the di≈øtribution of all the≈øe things, there mu≈øt be a coun≈øel which mu≈øt have the over≈øight thereof, and which ≈øhall cau≈øe all to be delivered out and received in according to the order of the Governour and the Coun≈øel of warre. The≈øe things thus put in order, you mu≈øt think upon defen≈øe, which is done principally after two wayes, by holding the enemy off by retrenchment, and by hindring him (when he approcheth) by ≈øallies.

For the fir≈øt; it is approved and practiced by all; and he which breaketh ground be≈øt, and beginneth to di≈øpute it the furthe≈øt off, is he which maketh the longe≈øt re≈øi≈øtance. For the ≈ømalle≈øt retrenchment without (accommodated with palli≈øadoes) is hard to be forced. But if it be mined, and that there be another made behind it, it is a dangerous piece to enter, and you con≈øtrain the enemy to approch by little and little, and with the ≈øame ceremonies which are u≈øed to fall upon the bulwarks and the great moat; ≈øo that by divers retrenchments you keep off the enemy at a di≈øtance a long time before he can come to fall upon the counter≈øcarp, who cannot take away your outworks but by mines, which taketh up good ≈øtore of time. The moat al≈øo may be defended if it be dry by portable ca≈øemats (which are called coffers) incircled by little moats or palli≈øadoes to hinder the approch,
which are placed in ≈øeverall places of the great moat to defend it, and not to be di≈øcovered by the cannon of the a≈ø≈øailant. The bulwarks are al≈øo to be defended by retrenchments, which you are to make either at the point, or at the middle, or at the gorge, according as they are capable, and that the mines of the be≈øiegers do enter forward within the bulwarks. And when all that is forced, the la≈øt defen≈øe is a retrenchment of the whole town, reducing it to keep onely one part of it.

For the ≈øecond way of defen≈øe; in ≈øtead of many ≈øallies to drive back them that work in the approches ≈øome would have onely ≈øome few to good purpo≈øe, in great nece≈ø≈øitie; alleaging that the be≈øieged there alwayes lo≈øe ≈øome men, and of the be≈øt of them, which they ought to con≈øerve again≈øt a ≈øtrong a≈ø≈øault; and that oftentimes they which would have a fair pretext to yield the town cau≈øe their ≈øouldiers to be maimed by continuall ≈øallies, to ≈øhew that they yield not them≈øelves but through nece≈ø≈øitie. For mine own part (which do approve of the quantitie of ≈øallies, and which have alwayes ≈øeen the works of the a≈ø≈øailants retarded by them more in one houre then in eight dayes by other defen≈øes) I an≈øwer, that the≈øe rea≈øons would carry ≈øome ≈øhew if the town were attempted by a≈ø≈øault; for they not taking any other but that way at that time, it were fit to pre≈øerve the ≈øouldiers to with≈øtand them: but while≈øt the a≈ø≈øailant getteth ground by little and little, if you defend not the town otherwi≈øe then by retrenchment, you mu≈øt lo≈øe it at la≈øt: wherein your quantitie of ≈øouldiers ≈øtandeth you in no
≈øtead at all, in ≈øo much that the care you have taken to pre≈øerve your ≈øouldiers doth not prolong the taking of the town one day; but if by your brave ≈øallies you ruine batteries, throw down trenches, force the redoubts which defend them; and when they are within the moat you burn their galleries, they mu≈øt be inforced to begin their work anew as ofttimes as you overthrow it; in≈øomuch as the be≈øieger finding him≈øelf ≈øo enterteined, he approcheth with much more ceremonie, and at la≈øt his ≈øouldiers draw back. So that in my opinion it is very fit that the be≈øieged ≈øhould make frequent ≈øallies; but they mu≈øt make them at ≈øeverall houres, that ≈øo they may the better ≈øurpri≈øe the enemy with few men (but re≈øolute) to avoid the di≈øorder in the retreat, and to do no other thing but what is commanded. For though you find not re≈øi≈øtance at the falling on, as is u≈øuall, if you ≈øtay to little purpo≈øe, you runne the hazard to be ill led off at the retreat. The other particularities of defen≈øe depend upon tho≈øe of a≈ø≈øailing, the be≈øiegers teaching you by nece≈ø≈øitie what you are to do; wherein there is nothing but practice and experience which can well direct you.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of Artillery.
div.p:
IT is fit to ≈øpeak of Artillery after ≈øieges, ≈øince it is principally by means thereof that towns are taken; and that ≈øince this hath been in u≈øe, there are no places found impregnable, if they be not inacce≈ø≈øible: It hath changed all the form and matter of fortifications: for in ≈øtead of towers and ancient walls, which have not been able to re≈øi≈øt it, we now make bulwarks and other works of earth. We may ≈øay that it hath even in a manner altered the manner of making warre. Anciently they began their approches to towns where now we end them: for on the fir≈øt day they lodged on the brim of the moat; and now adayes we mu≈øt go a great way before we come at it: then the circumvallation was made out of reach of arrows onely, now they mu≈øt be made beyond reach of cannon: then it mattered not though the fortre≈ø≈øes of the encamped armies were overtopped, ≈øo as they had their other conveniences; now-adayes there mu≈øt be care taken above all things that they be not. In tho≈øe times two armies were quietly led in batalia at two or three hundred paces di≈øtance from each other, and remained there whole dayes without being able to be di≈ølodged but by a hazard of a general battel; now one cannot be before another but out of the reach of the cannon, otherwi≈øe he that hath mo≈øt of them, or that hath planted them be≈øt, beateth out the other without fighting. At that time a Generall of an army could know the order of his
enemy at a near di≈øtance, and form his own according to that, ≈øeeking his advantages upon the defects of another, and all without danger; now the≈øe things can no more be ob≈øerved but ≈øo farre off as you mu≈øt rather tru≈øt to your own good order then upon any defect in that of your enemy. Then one army could charge another without lo≈øing their order, becau≈øe they had not above two or three hundred paces to march; in the≈øe times it is impo≈ø≈øible to ob≈øerve it in ≈øight of the enemy for half a league together, and to find a plain which ≈øhall be even and without hindrances. Whereunto I adde further, that without a great exerci≈øe of marching in battalia you are not able to march a thou≈øand paces without lo≈øing all your di≈øtances of battalions and ≈øquadrons, and by con≈øequence without being in confu≈øion. Since therefore the cannon is of ≈øo great u≈øe in warre, and hath ≈øo great a ≈øhare in the victory, it is nece≈ø≈øary that you know how to make good u≈øe of it. It is an engine which all cannot well imploy, for it is of great expen≈øe, and belongeth onely to great and pui≈ø≈øant States to make ordinary u≈øe of them. They tie them to a great charge for draught, there being a hundred draught-hor≈øes required to draw one cannon for battery through all kinds of wayes, and to ≈øhoot onely a hundred bullets. By this you may judge according to the number which you mean to imploy what length of ground it taketh up. To mannage one piece of battery well, there mu≈øt be eighteen men: be≈øides, how many ≈ømiths, carters, farriers, and other workmen mu≈øt there be in the train to repair the carriages? how many carpenters to make bridges? how
how many pioners to accommodate the highwayes? Briefly an army which carrieth cannon with it cannot march but lei≈øurely, and that which hath none can do no great effect: therefore in the≈øe times the artillery is an e≈ø≈øentiall part of an army; but withall, if the Generall ≈øuffereth him≈øelf to be approched too near, without entrenching him≈øelf it is impo≈ø≈øible for him to di≈øintangle him≈øelf without fighting, or lo≈øing it; which cannot ≈øo happen without lo≈øing much of his reputation. For this rea≈øon he ought to inform him≈øelf very particularly of all that dependeth on the artillery: and that he may not be deceived, he mu≈øt know the lea≈øt even of the ≈ømalle≈øt things, namely, of the mixture, founding, proportion, weight, calibre, and carriage; of what wood it mu≈øt be, how it mu≈øt be conducted according to the ≈øeverall wayes, miry or mountainous; how to pa≈ø≈øe rivers, how to ≈øecure the batteries, as well again≈øt the cannon of the enemy as again≈øt his ≈øallies; what ground the cannon mu≈øt have for his rever≈øe, what di≈øtance between piece and piece; in what manner the platform mu≈øt be made, at what di≈øtance the batteries are ≈øufficient, and other things, whereof I do not here ≈øpecifie the particulars, becau≈øe others have written of them. It ≈øufficeth me to ≈øhew the u≈øe of artillerie, the chargeablene≈ø≈øe of it, the turmoil of it, and whereunto it engageth you, to incite Generals not to rely upon others; and to know the benefit and di≈øcommoditie thereof ≈øo well, that they may make u≈øe of the one to their advantage, and avoid the other by their fore≈øight.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the baggage and pioners.
div.p:
AFter the great turmoil of the artillery, I will ≈øpeak a word of that of the baggage. It is a great ≈øhame to lo≈øe it, but it is al≈øo a hard matter to pre≈øerve it when it is exce≈ø≈øive; there being nothing that bringeth ≈øo much di≈øorder to an army: therefore it is highly nece≈ø≈øary to reduce it to the ≈ømalle≈øt proportion that may be, and to make a review of it every moneth; for it groweth in the twinkling of an eye. We are ≈øo delicate now a dayes as we will hardly carry our arms, much le≈ø≈øe would we carry a weeks victuall about us. So long as ≈øuch an abu≈øe be ≈øuffered in an army, it will make it ≈øelf incapable to do any thing that is good. For as in a battel he which can la≈øt pre≈øerve ≈øome troups which have not fought, carrieth away the victory; ≈øo he that la≈øt keepeth his army in health, complete, and accu≈øtomed to labour, doth the like: which he cannot do if the ≈øouldiers be ≈øo delicate as they cannot carry their baggage. Be≈øides that, ≈øickne≈ø≈øe and famine getteth not into an army, but by this ra≈øcalli ‚Ä¢ ie of ≈øouldiers boyes: and this thing which ≈øeemeth to be a thing of nothing, is of ≈øuch importance, as it is for the mo≈øt part the di≈ø≈øipation of the mo≈øt flouri≈øhing, yea I dare ≈øay, of the mo≈øt victorious armies. It is principally in the time of pro≈øperity that men grow effeminate, and give them≈øelves to take their ea≈øe; and in that time it ought lea≈øt to be done, if after the example of the delicacies of Capua where Hannibals army imba≈øed it ≈øelf,
they would not do the ≈øame. Whil≈øt we are about cutting off unnece≈ø≈øary things from the army, I will ≈øay a word concerning pioners. There be Captains of our time which will have an unbridled number of them, and ≈øay, that it were better to cut off ≈øome regiments of ≈øouldiers, and to take pioners in their ≈øtead, which are nece≈ø≈øary to make the inclo≈øures of the camp, the trenches in a ≈øiege, the accommodation of the wayes; briefly, to take away all imployment from the ≈øouldiers of working in the ground, for that they in the≈øe times cannot be brought to be ≈øubject to ≈øuch labours as the ancient Romanes were: alledging further, that the ≈øouldier when he arriveth at his quarter, is ≈øufficiently tired, though he be not imployed a new to ca≈øt up earth. An opinion whereat I cannot wonder enough, and which ≈øtrengthneth me in that which I hold, that we ≈øpoil our ≈øouldiers by ≈øparing them too much. There mu≈øt be care taken for their livelihood, for their clothing, for ≈øuch as are ≈øick and hurt: but they mu≈øt be hardned to labour, and their Generall and other Commanders mu≈øt be examples to them. For if you will reduce them to content them≈øelves with a little while≈øt you bur≈øt your ≈øelf with exce≈ø≈øe of meat, and to labour while≈øt you glory it, and live in lazine≈ø≈øe; I confe≈ø≈øe they will murmure. But to return to the pioners: it is nece≈ø≈øary you ≈øhould have them to accommodate the wayes, for the artillery principally; for which five hundred may ≈øerve for a great equipage. Concerning the inclo≈øing of the camp, the ≈øouldier is bound to make it; for that this labour procureth him a means to re≈øt him≈øelf and to ≈øleep in
≈øafetie. I ≈øay further, that it is a work which mu≈øt be done in three or foure houres; to this end all the army worketh at it, or at lea≈øt half of it, when the enemy is near hand. So that if we mu≈øt needs have it done by pioners, there had need be as many of them in an army as there are ≈øouldiers, which would be a means to fami≈øh a whole countrey, and to encrea≈øe the turmoil, which we would dimini≈øh. Concerning the trenches; I never ≈øaw it ≈øucceed well when pioners did it; and while≈øt the danger groweth, the mo≈øt valiant ≈øouldiers are not too good for that imployment; and further they mu≈øt be incited to that work by the gain of it: which will ≈øerve to a≈ø≈øure them≈øelves the better in that danger, and to give them a means to ≈øpare ≈øomething to cloth them≈øelves; and no money is ≈øo well imployed as that in an army.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of ≈øpies and guides.
div.p:
THere be yet two ≈øorts of people whereof (contrary to the pioners) there cannot be too many in an army; which are ≈øpies and guides. The fir≈øt adverti≈øe you of the deportments of the enemy, upon who≈øe report either you enterpri≈øe ≈øomething upon him, or you guard your ≈øelf from his de≈øignes. The ≈øecond give you knowledge of the countrey, of the wayes and pa≈ø≈øages by which you are to pa≈ø≈øe, or el≈øe by what way your enemy can come to you. Both the one and the other mu≈øt be faithfull, for that in advi≈øing you ‚Ä¢ al≈øly, or guiding you maliciou≈øly, they may cau≈øe you to fall into great dangers.
You mu≈øt have good ≈øtore of guides: for that (e≈øpecially if you march by night) every gro≈ø≈øe troup (or at lea≈øt every body) hath need of their own; and before you ≈øet forward, they mu≈øt all be agreed on the way which they will take. There mu≈øt be a Captain of the guides, a man of ≈øpirit, and vigilant, and that may take care to get guides froÃÑ place to place. Concerning ≈øpies, there mu≈øt be ≈øomething more ob≈øerved in them, and you mu≈øt be alwayes ≈øu≈øpicious of them: for that as it is a dangerous task for him that undertaketh it, ≈øo it is al≈øo for him that imployeth them. To this end it is nece≈ø≈øary that no man know them but he which imployeth them; and that ≈øpies may not know each other, that ≈øo they may not agree to give fal≈øe advi≈øes: for by this means by examining them ≈øeverally, by the agreement or di≈øagreement of their advi≈øes, you may judge whether they be good; and by the verification of tho≈øe which ≈øpeak true or fal≈øe, you ≈øhall know who betrayeth you, or doth you true ≈øervice. And how≈øoever when you di≈øcover traitours, yet I ≈øay you may make a profitable u≈øe of them, by feigning that you believe them to be faithfull, and giving them commi≈ø≈øions which they may di≈øcover to the enemy, that you have ≈øome de≈øigne quite contrary to that which you intend to put in execution; that ≈øo while≈øt he is preparing him≈øelf for one ≈øide, you may attempt ≈øomething upon him on the other. But this is not all, to beware of your own ≈øpies; you mu≈øt al≈øo take heed of tho≈øe of the enemy; which you mu≈øt pre≈øuppo≈øe you have within your camp, as the enemy hath of yours. For this rea≈øon be≈øides the ≈øecre≈øie which mu≈øt be u≈øed in all enterpri≈øes,
it is good to give a charge, by publi≈øhing (in a ≈øtill way) that you have a quite contrary de≈øigne to that which you purpo≈øe to put in execution, that ≈øo tho≈øe ≈øpies may ≈øo report it to the enemy. But the mo≈øt e≈ø≈øentiall means to be well ≈øerved by this kind of men, is to be very liberall to them; for they are faithfull to them which give them mo≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of victuall.
div.p:
BUt ≈øeeing it is to no purpo≈øe to have an army compo≈øed of good commanders and valiant ≈øouldiers, well di≈øciplined and obedient, well furni≈øhed with artillery and munition, if they have not what to eat; I will di≈øtingui≈øh this chapter into five parts: the fir≈øt to make provi≈øions of corn; the ≈øecond to provide for the carriage of it; the third of the ≈øafe conveying of it; the fourth of the making of good bread; and the fifth of the di≈øtribution of it. To this end the Commi≈ø≈øary generall of the victuall ought to be a man of authority, faithfull, vigilant, and active; and this office ought not to be de≈øpi≈øed (as nowadayes it is) nor given to men of mean quality; for it is of ≈øuch importance, that according as it is either well or ill di≈øcharged, it cau≈øeth an army to ≈øub≈øi≈øt, or go to ruine. And the Romanes alwayes committed it to ≈øome eminent per≈øon. To come to particulars, I will ≈øay that the provi≈øion of corn ought to be made in due time, in ≈øufficient quantitie, in a commodious place for tran≈øportation, and that choice be made of very good corn. For you mu≈øt not conceive any hope
of finding it, either in the champain or towns where you are to go, becau≈øe the enemy may either hoard it up or burn it; and ≈øo on that hope you ≈øhall find in this onely point all your de≈øignes fru≈øtrated. In the ≈øecond, you mu≈øt make Magazines in divers places, that ≈øo you may not be in danger to lo≈øe all at once, both in towns and ca≈øtles which are neare≈øt and mo≈øt commodious for the tran≈øporting of corn into your army; and (according to the ≈øituation of the countrey) you are to make provi≈øion of waggons or mules to carry it to the camp, where mu≈øt alwayes be a Magazine for a forthnight, which ≈øhould not be meddled with but in extremitie, or for ≈øome extraordinary enterpri≈øe. In the third place, the carriage of it ought not to be performed without a good convoy; and never on any prefixed day, to prevent the preparation of taking of it while≈øt it is on the way. In the fourth, to hinder the abu≈øes which are ordinarily u≈øed (and I dare ≈øay, ever, unle≈ø≈øe there be a very narrow looking to it) about the bread. For, for their private gain, they mingle bad grain with it, yea even earth, and u≈øe other ba≈øe tricks, whence for the mo≈øt part proceed di≈øea≈øes in an army; which is a mi≈øchief which cannot be too ≈øeverely puni≈øhed. And in the la≈øt place, that it may be well di≈øtributed and not wa≈øted; for if you tru≈øt the Sergeants, they alwayes take for double the number of ≈øouldiers they have in their companies: to this end it is nece≈ø≈øary that the Commi≈ø≈øarie generall of the victuall from week to week ≈øhould have an exact li≈øt of tho≈øe that are in the army, ≈øigned by the Generall, that ≈øo he may order the di≈øtribution of bread according
to it. Be≈øides, you mu≈øt cau≈øe them to be puni≈øhed rigourou≈øly which pillage tho≈øe victuallers and other per≈øons which bring victuall to the camp; whereof the price mu≈øt be regulated, that ≈øo the ≈øouldiers may not be ≈øharked upon. When you are at a well retrenched ≈øiege, where the hope to make you quit it con≈øi≈øteth in nothing el≈øe but in cutting off your victuall, you mu≈øt have that fore≈øight to cau≈øe ≈øo much to be brought within your camp as you judge to be nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øerve your turn for the time you believe you ≈øhall ≈øtay to take the town be≈øieged; as Ce≈øar did before Alexia. There be many rules to be given on this ≈øubject, to hinder the abu≈øes which may be u≈øed therein, which I omit to avoid prolixitie: b ‚Ä¢ ≈øides they are pettie ord ‚Ä¢ rs which are changed according to the places and occa≈øions; all which ≈øhould tend to no other end but to draw victuall to the army, and to hinder the exce≈ø≈øive prices of it.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the generall officers of an army, and of their functions.
div.p: THere is nothing more nece≈ø≈øary in an army then to have the offices therein well regulated, and that every man may know whom he is to command, and whom he ought to obey; and yet I never ≈øaw that ab≈øolutely decided in any, which is the rea≈øon why I have been willing here to make a project, how things therein ought to be e≈øtabli≈øhed. The Generall ought to have ab≈øolute power, which ought not to be communicated to any: for in warre more then in any other profe≈ø≈øion the command ought to be ≈øingular: and it is a very bad introduction to make Generals which command the army by the day, or by the week, or by the moneth. At all times when the Romanes did ≈øo, they ≈øped the wor≈øe for it.

Then there mu≈øt be a Lieutenant generall, or Mar≈øhall of the field generall, which ought to take care to cau≈øe all the Generalls commands to be put in execution as ab≈øolutely as him≈øelf, thereby to ea≈øe him: it being too hard a thing for the Generall to do all, e≈øpecially when the army marcheth; for that (of all nece≈ø≈øitie) there mu≈øt be a man of eminent authority at the head of an army, and whom all the other commanders do acknowledge. Sometimes there is a Lieutenant generall and a Mar≈øhall of the field generall to perform the≈øe two offices; neverthele≈ø≈øe the≈øe two places, being born by two men in an army, oftentimes bring confu≈øion, and cau≈øe
that which we de≈øire to avoid: for in the functions thereof they never agree; becau≈øe the Mar≈øhall of the field generall doing his office, mu≈øt di≈øtribute the commands of the Generall to all the other commanders; he mu≈øt march in the vanguard, order the lodgings and encampings: in≈øomuch as I know not what function the Lieutenant generall ≈øhall have unle≈ø≈øe he u≈øurp the others office, or el≈øe that he ≈øerve onely as a ≈øhooting trunk, that ≈øo through him the Generals commands may be delivered to the Ma ‚Ä¢
≈øhall of the field: which is the rea≈øon I conclude that there ought to be but one of the≈øe two offices.
That done, I divide all the functions of the army into foure principall parts, namely the caualrie, the infanterie, the artillerie, and the victuall, and will treat of each part one after another.

The cavalry is a body which often lodgeth ≈ø ‚Ä¢ parated from that of the army, and requireth a principall commander to whom all the re≈øt ≈øhould yield obedience, which mu≈øt be of great authority and eminent qualitie, or of ≈øuch experience and vertue that all the other commanders may voluntarily obey him. For it is in the cavalrie, where you ≈øhall meet with more men of wealth and good families, and con≈øequently more difficult to be made to obey; and therefore this authoritie ought not to be divided. And becau≈øe in marching the cavalrie is ordinarily in the front and in the rear, and that in lodging you are ofttimes compelled to make two fronts, and for that in time of battel the hor≈øe are at lea≈øt on the two wings, it is nece≈ø≈øary that there be a
Lieutenant Generall, a man al≈øo of great authoritie. There mu≈øt further be a third commander, whom the mo≈øt part call a Commi≈ø≈øary generall, who di≈øtributeth the orders, keepeth the li≈øt of the guards, of the convoyes, and other functions; and ought to go and take the orders from the Mar≈øhall of the field generall, to carry them to his Generall of the hor≈øe, who di≈øtributeth them to the Quarter-ma≈øters, which come for them from every quarter. All the cavalry mu≈øt be divided into companies, of which regiments are formed; not after the manner of the infantery, under the command of a Colonell; but onely to maintein the order of the lodgings and of battel. To form the≈øe regiments you put foure or five companies together, with one of carabines, and the anciente≈øt Captain commandeth that body; and ≈øo all the cavalry is divided: which maketh it plainly evident how merely unprofitable an office it is to have a generall commandder of the carabines; for the carabines cannot make a body, for that their want of fighting permitteth it not, neither were they in≈øtituted but to ≈øerve the cavalry, either at their quartering, or to di≈øcover, or for intelligence, or to give a charge in the flank in time of fight, or in a retreat to harrie them whom you chace, or to keep you from being ≈øo when you are pur≈øued. In effect, good carabines mingled among≈øt the caval ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e are of very good ≈øervice; but alone are unprofitable.

If you make more quarters then there be generall officers, the anciente≈øt Captain commandeth in the quarter, and therein taketh the mo≈øt ancient quarter-ma≈øter of his quarter. In≈øomuch
that the Generall of the hor≈øe giving his orders to the Commi≈ø≈øary generall, he to the Quarter-ma≈øter generall, and he to the other Quarter-ma≈øters which come for them from the other quarters (where the ≈øame order is ob≈øerved) the commands are carried without confu≈øion, and pa≈ø≈øe through the hands of few per≈øons; and when there is any deficiency found, it is ea≈øie to be verified whence it aro≈øe.

The infantery is the more ≈øolid body of an army: that of the artillery and victuall alwayes are quartered with it. There is not that diver≈øitie between the companies which is between the hor≈øe; they are all of the ≈øame fa≈øhion, compo≈øed of half-pikes half-musketiers. Many companies make a regiment, which hath its commander; and many regiments make a body, which we call a Brigado of the army. The army is u≈øually divided into three bodies, Vanguard, Battel, and Rearguard. Every brigado hath its commander; and be≈øides it ought to have a Sergeant Major of a brigado, and a Quarter-ma≈øter of a brigado; The fir≈øt to go and take the orders from the Mar≈øhall of the field generall, to carry them to the commander of his brigado; then he giveth the word to the Sergeant Majors of the regiments: and the other to give to every Quarter-ma≈øter of a regiment, either his quarter, or the ≈øpace of ground which is nece≈ø≈øary, for him to encamp in; and he divideth it to the particular Quarter-ma≈øters, or to the harbengers of every company, which afterwards lodgeth them. If there be a Colonel generall of all the infantery, he may have a care in generall of all the government thereof; but in an army he mu≈øt
onely command a brigado, otherwi≈øe we ≈øhould not be able to e≈øtabli≈øh the order which we have propounded. Moreover, there be divers nations which do not judge a Colonell generall of the infantery to be nece≈ø≈øary, but content them≈øelves with particular Colonels for every regiment, which acknowledge onely the commands of the Generall, or of his Mar≈øhall of the field generall.

The artillery ought to have a Generall, a Lieutenant generall, a Quarter-ma≈øter, then other officers. And for that all pioners, miners, enginiers, conductours of works, ≈ømiths, carpenters, wheelwrights, and other workmen depend on him, I would e≈øtabli≈øh a commander for every ≈øort of the≈øe men; which I would take either out of the commi≈ø≈øaries of the artillery, or other per≈øons apart, to addre≈ø≈øe my ≈øelf to them when I had need of ≈øuch men. The Quarter-ma≈øter mu≈øt every night go to receive the orders of the Mar≈øhall of the field generall. The charge of the victuals ought to be performed by a Generall; he ought to have his Lieutenant, his Quarter-ma≈øter, and his other officers: his Quarter-ma≈øter mu≈øt every evening go and take the orders of the Mar≈øhall of the field generall.

So then you ≈øee how the commands are di≈øtributed: the Mar≈øhall of the field generall receiveth them from the Generall, then goeth to his own lodging; there the Commi≈ø≈øary of hor≈øe cometh and receiveth them for the cavalry; the Sergeant Major generall for the infantery, who delivereth it to the Sergeant Majors of brigadoes: for the artillery to the Quarter-ma≈øter thereof; and ≈øo to him for the victuals: Briefly, the Mar≈øhall
of the field generall ≈øpeaking with the≈øe foure per≈øons, giveth the orders to all the army. All orders and commands ought to be given in writing. The Mar≈øhall of the field generall, the Generall of the artillery, the Fi≈øcall, the Controller of the Exchequer, the Generall of victuall, the Quarter-ma≈øter generall, the Sergeant major generall and the Provo≈øt generall mu≈øt alwayes be lodged within the Generalls quarter.

If all the army be encamped in bodies, the Quarter-ma≈øter generall giveth to each of the≈øe bodies the ≈øpace of ground which is fitting; which is afterwards di≈øtributed (in every body) by the officers thereunto appointed.
On a day of battel the Mar≈øhall of the field generall doth a≈ø≈øigne the place for every body; afterwards the Sergeant major generall rangeth the infantery into battalia.

The Mar≈øhall of the field generall ought to have three or foure a≈ø≈øi≈øtants for the field, to carry the extraordinary orders; but they mu≈øt not pretend to command any officer in chief, unle≈ø≈øe they formerly have been either Colonels or Captains of hor≈øe.

The Sergeant major generall mu≈øt command the Colonels; but that they may the readilier obey him, he ought to be taken out of the Colonels; and none ought ever to have that place unle≈ø≈øe he hath been one: as al≈øo the Sergeant majors of brigadoes ought to be taken out of the Sergeant majors of regiments. Things being thus regulated and e≈øtabli≈øhed, you ≈øhall ≈øee a great facilitie in the commands, and none ≈øhall be able to excu≈øe his fault by putting it off upon another, becau≈øe pre≈øently it will be verified whence it
proceeded: which obligeth every man to be carefull to do that exactly which he ≈øhalbe coÃÑmanded

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the a≈ø≈øailing of States, according to their forces and ≈øituations.
div.p: AFter that you have formed an army, you mu≈øt imploy it, either for the conque≈øt of a new countre ‚Ä¢ , or for the defen≈øe of your own. We will begin with the fir≈øt. The Prince which putteth him≈øelf upon the offen≈øive mu≈øt be the ≈øtronger, or mu≈øt ≈øee ≈øome garboils in the State which he a≈ø≈øaileth, and that he be called thither by a partie: otherwi≈øe it would be a ra≈øh enterpri≈øe.

If the countrey which he a≈ø≈øaileth be large and open, he mu≈øt ≈øeek in the beginning to hazard a battel or ≈øome grand skirmi≈øh, that ≈øo by the reputation of his arms he may affright the enemies. If it be a countrey enclo≈øed with mountains, or divided by rivers and ditches, or ≈øheltered with forre≈øts, or full of fortre≈ø≈øes, it is hard to force an enemy to battel; and in this ca≈øe you mu≈øt go to ≈øieges, and make your conque≈øt by little and little. Now he that will make any progre≈ø≈øe by this way mu≈øt at lea≈øt have two bodies of armies; that ≈øo with the one he may hold his enemy in play, and with the other he may actuate without impeachment. For it is mo≈øt difficult to accompli≈øh the de≈øigne of a ≈øiege, ≈øo long as you have a good army encamped near you, which ≈øhall cut off your victuall. If it be a countrey which is hard to enter, and that hath but few pa≈ø≈øages whereby to enter into it, you mu≈øt force one; and before you go further, you mu≈øt there fortifie, and ≈øo well a≈ø≈øure
your way for your victuall as you may not ≈øuffer though the enemy ≈øhould have burned or carried away that of his countrey into his fortre≈ø≈øes. If you be called by a faction, that is a very great advantage for you; becau≈øe you are in≈øtructed of the ≈øituation of the countrey, and of the defects which are to be found in the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tified places, and want not ≈øpies nor punctuall adverti≈øements of what≈øoever pa≈ø≈øeth among≈øt the enemies. You mu≈øt al≈øo be very carefull to u≈øe this faction very courteou≈øly, and to engage them by little and little into actions which may make them irreconcilable to their Prince. But when you ≈øee they make warre with re≈øpect, and that they will but by halves offend him from whom they have revolted, you mu≈øt have them in great ≈øu≈øpicion, and march with them with bridle in hand: for whether it be the fear of a ruine without recovery, or the hope of a reconciliation that hindreth them from putting them≈øelves upon reall extremities, the one and other are equally dangerous; and at la≈øt you may fear they may accommodate them≈øelves to your prejudice: wherefore if they will not engage them≈øelves to do extraordinary and irremi≈ø≈øible actions at the beginning, you ought not to joyn with them but under good pledges: You mu≈øt al≈øo u≈øe ≈øuch as do voluntarily yield them≈øelves to you with all humanitie, clemencie, and liberalitie, and ≈øuch as re≈øi≈øt you with all ≈øeveritie; for beneficence towards the one and ≈øeveritie towards the other are the two principall means which get you obedience. A town taken by force, and hardly u≈øed, or one which yieldeth it ≈øelf of its own accord, and favoured, openeth the
gates of a dozen others: as on the other ≈øide, a town taken by force and ≈øpared, or which rendred it ≈øelf voluntarily and is evil intreated, ≈øhutteth a great many. Whence I conclude, that a Conquerour mu≈øt be as good as his word, what≈øoever he promi≈øeth, be it in clemency or ≈øeverity

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the defen≈øe of States according to their forces and ≈øituations.
div.p:
TO treat of this ≈øubject well, we mu≈øt divide it into three parts; namely, into ≈ømall States, tho≈øe of a middle rank, and tho≈øe which are pui≈ø≈øant. The ≈ømall ones are of that nature as they ≈øub≈øi≈øt not but by the jealou≈øies which their neighbours have one of another; for that if one of them will a≈ø≈øail a weak State, the other will defend it: neverthele≈ø≈øe, it is but a tottering condition and ill a≈ø≈øured; for if the one findeth him≈øelf able enough to a≈ø≈øail them, the other will not find him≈øelf ≈øufficient to defend them. The coun≈øels of Princes and States are not alwayes governed ≈øo equally, but for the mo≈øt part one prevaileth above the other. Be≈øides this inconvenience there is yet another, that ≈øometimes they agree to divide the prey; ≈øo that ≈øuch kind of pettie States which have not ≈øtrength within them≈øelves for their own defen≈øe, are alwayes in perill; and they mu≈øt u≈øe very much pliantne≈ø≈øe to remove all pretexts from their neighbours of undertaking ≈øomething again≈øt them. The onely means which they have is to have one or two towns exceeding well fortified, with arms and money enough to defend them well;
that ≈øo they may give lei≈øure to them which will not ≈øuffer the growth of him which ≈øhall a≈ø≈øail you, to aid you: for if you have no means at all to re≈øi≈øt, your countrey will be taken before they ≈øhall have time to a≈ø≈øi≈øt you: and be≈øides that, the happine≈ø≈øe which they conceive of conquering you giveth them a ≈øpur to a≈ø≈øail you; you ≈øhall find many more per≈øons di≈øpo≈øed to ≈øuccour you then to reconquer your countrey: for that the one is ea≈øie with equall forces, and the other without greater ≈øtrength is very difficult. To which I adde, that there is ofttimes as great danger that he which regaineth your countrey as your friend keep it not for him≈øelf, as well as he which had taken it as your enemy: or if he re≈øtore it to you, it will be with ≈øo hard conditions, as you ≈øhall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe but the ≈øhadow of a Sovereigntie. And thrice happy are they which meet with ≈øo good and ≈øo generous Princes, which do ree≈øtabli≈øh them into their lo≈øt States, with the ≈øame authoritie and liberty as they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them before: for ≈øuch examples are exceeding rare. Concerning tho≈øe States of a middle condition, I propound a Prince (or commonwealth) which for his defen≈øe is able to entertein an army of 20000 foot and 3000 hor≈øe with all nece≈ø≈øary equipage. If his countrey be of a difficult acce≈ø≈øe, and that there be no entrance into it but by certain pa≈ø≈øages and mountains guarded and fortified, he hath a great advantage: but they which too much do tru≈øt and re≈øt upon them, and have neglected other defen≈øes, have deceived them≈øelves, and have been lo≈øt by tho≈øe wayes wherein they thought them≈øelves mo≈øt a≈ø≈øured. If it be encompa≈ø≈øed by the
≈øea, it is a fair moat, notwith≈øtanding he which is ≈øtronger will find means to make his de≈øcent into the i≈øland. If it be environed with moori≈øh grounds and rivers, yet an enemy will find wayes to pa≈ø≈øe them, e≈øpecially when he hath artillery to favouri≈øe ≈øuch pa≈ø≈øages; in≈øomuch that the ≈øure≈øt way is to tru≈øt to your own forces, namely a good army and good fortre≈ø≈øes: I ≈øay, both joynned together: for that the army without fortre≈ø≈øes being weak, and not daring to hazard any thing, leaveth the victuall of the champain to the enemy, and ≈øo the means to ≈øub≈øi≈øt at your charge, and at la≈øt to ruine you. And fortre≈ø≈øes without an army are not able to pre≈øerve you longer then the time you have made your magazines of victuall for, within them: but the≈øe things being proportioned with judgement, you may make a great re≈øi≈øtance. In the≈øe things you mu≈øt not ≈øuffer your ≈øelf to be led by the fan≈øies of the people, which without con≈øidering the ≈øituations of their towns, or the publick good, when they ≈øee their neighbours fortifie them≈øelves, will all imitate them; a thing equally dangerous, to have more fortre≈ø≈øes then you can guard, or to have none at all. Yet I ≈øhould rather like the la≈øt then the fir≈øt: for that at lea≈øt by hazarding a battel you put your enemy to half the fear; but by the other way you mu≈øt ≈øurely peri≈øh, without being able to do any other thing but prolong your ruine: for the jealou≈øie which you have to pre≈øerve all your fortre≈ø≈øes by leaving great garri≈øons in them, hindreth you of the means of keeping an army in the field: and then the ≈øpoil of two or three harve≈øts compelleth you to yield your neck to the halter. I know
there are ≈øome which ground them≈øelves upon this rea≈øon, That when all the principall places of a State be fortified, all the victuall of the champain may be drawn into them, ≈øo that an army coming thither, if it ≈øtayeth there, it dieth through famine; and if it doth but pa≈ø≈øe through, it doth no great hurt: in≈øomuch that it is almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible to make any great ≈øiege there. Whereunto I an≈øwer, that fortre≈ø≈øes are principally invented for the weaker, that ≈øo a few men may re≈øi≈øt a great number: and if you have ≈øo great a number of fortre≈ø≈øes, and tho≈øe requiring great guards (as the great fortified towns do) you mu≈øt have a greater number of ≈øouldiers then he ≈øhall have which cometh to a≈ø≈øail you; otherwi≈øe you were not able to provide them all with ≈øufficient garri≈øons to pre≈øerve them from a ≈øiege. And if you be the ≈øtronger without any fortified place, you ≈øhall pre≈øerve your countrey in keeping the field. There is yet a further inconvenience in the fortifying of great towns; that is, that you make them ≈øo proud as they will not acknowledge their Sovereigne but upon good terms; and upon the lea≈øt di≈øcommoditie they receive in any warre the inhabitants de≈øire rather to change their ma≈øter then to ≈øee their goods wa≈øted. In≈øomuch that I conclude, that you ought to have ≈øo few fortre≈ø≈øes that they may not hinder you from keeping the field; that tho≈øe which you have be ≈øo well fortified and furni≈øhed with munition as they may make a great re≈øi≈øtance; and to place them ≈øo well as they may bridle the great towns, and that they may a≈ø≈øure the frontiers, that ≈øo the enemy may make difficultie to leave a place behind him which might di≈øcommodate
his victuall, and that by intelligence or otherwi≈øe he may not ≈øei≈øe upon ≈øome principall town which may ≈øerve him for a ≈øeat to entertein warre within the countrey. The≈øe things thus di≈øpo≈øed of, you mu≈øt regard what enemy a≈ø≈øaileth you. If it be a power of confederates united together, it is the more ea≈øie to di≈øunite, then when it dependeth on one alone: and in this ca≈øe it is exceeding good to cau≈øe ≈øome diffidence to grow betwixt them, by feigning of intelligence with ≈øome one of the confederates, to whom ≈øhewing more re≈øpect and le≈ø≈øe animo≈øitie, you may give jealou≈øie to the re≈øt: as al≈øo by procuring a diver≈øion upon the countrey of one of the re≈øt. It being a very difficult thing that many ≈øovereigne powers ≈øhould long hold a league together, without ≈øome di≈øgu≈øts to ari≈øe among≈øt them, or mi≈øtakings, envies, and even enmities, by rea≈øon of the diver≈øitie of their humours and intere≈øts; ≈øo that that power which onely dependeth upon one State onely, is much more to be feared. And becau≈øe you may be a≈ø≈øailed more or le≈ø≈øe fiercely, I mu≈øt ≈øay a word for that: If it be by forces which are not too much di≈øproportionable to yours, you may pre≈øerve your countrey without for≈øaking it, and with your army and fortre≈ø≈øes tie up the enemy, in hindring him from victuall; and by entrenching alwayes ≈øo near him as you ≈øhall hinder him from making any ≈øiege of importance. For if a Conquerour advanceth not forward he recoileth; and it is impo≈ø≈øible for him to ≈øub≈øi≈øt in a countrey which he would conquer, if at fir≈øt he taketh no footing, and doth not ≈øtrengthen him≈øelf by ≈øome con≈øiderable pri≈øe. If al≈øo you
be a≈ø≈øailed by a power altogether di≈øproportionable to your forces; in this ca≈øe you mu≈øt leave the field, and burn all the victuall which you cannot contein within your fortre≈ø≈øes, and al≈øo all the towns and villages which you cannot guard: for it is better for you to pre≈øerve your ≈øelf in a ruined countrey, then to keep it for your enemy. And it is in this that a Prince, to gain, as he thinketh, the name of being compa≈ø≈øionate towards his people (which in ≈øuch occa≈øions turn their backs upon him) becometh cruel towards him≈øelf: But it is rather a vice of irre≈øolution and of weakne≈ø≈øe of courage which po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth us, then a true compa≈ø≈øion which we have of the misfortune of another: as that of the Emperour Otho, who upon the fir≈øt ill fortune that befell him (his forces being yet entire) dur≈øt not trie the hazard of a battel any more. And he who could not afford any pitie to Galba in his decrepit age (being his de≈øigned ≈øucce≈ø≈øour to the Empire) and which had committed all kinds of villanies to attein it, would per≈øwade po≈øterity, that compa≈ø≈øion to ≈øee the Romane bloud ≈øhed had made him re≈øolve to e≈øtrange him≈øelf from it by killing him≈øelf. Thus it is that we oftentimes de≈øire to cover our vices with the vertue which is neare≈øt thereunto. But as it is a maxime, that no publick good can be without ≈øome prejudice to ≈øome particular men, ≈øo a Prince cannot di≈øintangle him≈øelf from a perilous enterpri≈øe, if he will plea≈øe every man. And the greate≈øt and mo≈øt u≈øuall faults which we commit in matters of State and war proceed from ≈øuffering our ≈øelves to be carried away with this complacencie, whereof we repent
us when there is no remedy left. But to avoid ≈øuch ≈øtorms you mu≈øt hold this for a fundamentall law for your own pre≈øervation, Never to ≈øuffer that neighbour of yours to grow up which maketh him≈øelf the ≈øtronge≈øt: for it is better to offend him by hindring him from enabling him≈øelf to de≈øtroy you, then to ≈øuffer him to grow greater out of fear to offend him. It being a thing certain, that no man pre≈øerveth his libertie again≈øt a conquering enemy by complements but onely by force.
It remaineth that we ≈øpeak of pui≈ø≈øant States which (without help of another) have arms, money, and what el≈øe is needfull to maintein a continuall warre.

Of this kind there be but few, and they need to care for none but them≈øelves; for that one ≈øole enemy is not able to a≈ø≈øail them, and that it is hard for the leagues of ≈øeverall Princes all to agree in ≈øuch a de≈øigne, or for any long time to ≈øub≈øi≈øt together: Neverthele≈ø≈øe I will ≈øay a word on this ≈øubject. Great States are either compacted altogether, or ≈øpread abroad in ≈øeverall places: the fir≈øt, which have all their forces united, are able to a≈ø≈øail, and to defend them≈øelves more powerfully then they which are ≈øo ≈øeparated; becau≈øe they carry all their forces where need requireth with more diligence and facilitie, and le≈ø≈øe charge: the other put a great part of the world into an alarm and jealou≈øie, becau≈øe they frontier upon the greate≈øt number of States. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, if the one or the other be a≈ø≈øailed, they mu≈øt make u≈øe of the defen≈øes we propounded before: onely I will ≈øay that they ought to have no fortre≈ø≈øes
but good ones, and few in number, and onely on the frontiers, and none within the heart of the countrey; for that having more cau≈øe to fear civil warres then forrein, and without which no man will ever a≈ø≈øail a great Empire, it is the way to take away the main root from them which maketh them to undertake the enterpri≈øe and to ≈øub≈øi≈øt. Be≈øides, you ought not to perpetuate any governments, neither to families, nor yet for life. But the principall and mo≈øt able remedy again≈øt civil warre is to entertein a forrein warre; which cha≈øeth away idlene≈ø≈øe, ≈øetteth all on work, and particularly giveth ≈øatisfaction to ambitious and ≈øtirring ≈øpirits: it bani≈øheth luxurie, it maketh your people warlike, and mainteineth you in ≈øuch reputation among≈øt your neighbours, as you are the arbitratour of all their differences. It is true that this maxime is not good to be ob≈øerved but by ≈øuch States as are of this la≈øt ≈øort. For as it is nece≈ø≈øary for them, I find it hurtfull for pettie States, which mu≈øt fear all ≈øorts of warre; for being too weak to gain by it, they run the hazard to be the pray of ≈øuch as are the ≈øtronger,

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the means how to a≈ø≈øure a conque≈øt.
div.p: A Sovereigne Prince is more capable to make great and ready conque≈øts then a common-wealth; for that finding him≈øelf ≈øecret in his coun≈øel, courageous in his re≈øolution, ready in his execution, and not fearing to be contradicted by any, he maketh more conque≈øts in ten years of his life, then a common-wealth which is le≈ø≈øe ≈øecret, which is long in re≈øolving, which bridleth the authoritie of her Captains, and which every houre contradicteth their actions, ≈øhall be able to do in a hundred yeares: So al≈øo a common-wealth which goeth alwayes upon her own maximes, which is not ≈øubject to the want of one per≈øon, and who≈øe government receiveth no alteration by the death of any of them, con≈øerveth much better and for a longer time that which ≈øhe hath conquered then a Prince; which ofttimes (and almo≈øt alwayes) hath a ≈øucce≈ø≈øour as much a heartle≈ø≈øe dullard as him≈øelf was vertuous. Neverthele≈ø≈øe, I will here e≈øtabli≈øh (as well for the one as for the other) the true maximes for the well a≈ø≈øuring of a conque≈øt: which con≈øi≈øt in two things; namely to take away the de≈øire of revolting from tho≈øe whom you have conquered, and the means of being able to do it.

For the fir≈øt, it is a thing very certain, that if you conquer a free people, you ≈øhall not take away (at lea≈øt during the life of tho≈øe which have lived ≈øo) their de≈øire to recover their liberty. If they be ≈øubjects to a Prince and a State, and that they have onely changed their ma≈øter, they will rather de≈øire to remain under the authoritie of
him which ≈øhall u≈øe them the mo≈øt courteou≈øly. Therefore you mu≈øt alwayes begin by a fair way, and to e≈øtabli≈øh a condition for them which you have conquered which may be ≈øure, both for their life and for their goods. For if even your own ≈øubjects find not this a≈ø≈øurance, it is to be feared they will revolt; how much more they which are newly conquered? it being a law of nature imprinted in every creature, that the meane≈øt and lea≈øt animal taketh care for its own con≈øervation; to which man endued with rea≈øon addeth the con≈øervation of his honour and his welfare, which he ofttimes preferreth before his own life. Therefore a Prince mu≈øt govern according to exact ju≈øtice, uphold the oppre≈ø≈øed in his due right, ab≈øtein from all violence him≈øelf, a≈øwel concerning the honour of their wives as for their goods: for without this it is impo≈ø≈øible to make a conquered people tractable. You mu≈øt al≈øo (≈øo much as may be) maintein them in the form of their government, & exclude none of them out of the po≈ø≈øibility of atteining to tho≈øe offices, dignities and honours which they may po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe without prejudice to your ≈øafetie. And if it be a Prince which maketh this conque≈øt, the means to a≈ø≈øure him≈øelf well therein is there to e≈øtabli≈øh his re≈øidence the mo≈øt that may be; for that his pre≈øence doth hinder many di≈øorders, the ≈øplendour of his court imprinteth a certain veneration into the minds of the people, and it bringeth gain to the artificers and citizens where it is kept.

If it be a common-wealth which cannot change the ≈øeat of their government, it is therefore nece≈ø≈øary that ≈øuch as they ≈øhould ≈øend thither to govern live there with ≈øplendour. For
the people is ≈øometimes more taken with appearance then realitie. The≈øe are the means which do in≈øen≈øibly in≈øinuate obedience into a newly conquered people: but becau≈øe this is not ≈øufficient, and that ofttimes the facilitie of revolting impunely cau≈øeth men to have a de≈øire to it, it is nece≈ø≈øary for you to precaution your ≈øelf by requi≈øite a≈ø≈øurances, which con≈øi≈øt in having their arms and fortre≈ø≈øes in your own hands: I mean not that all the people ≈øhall be wholy di≈øarmed, for if it be po≈ø≈øible it mu≈øt not come to that; but to a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelf of great communalties by good fortre≈ø≈øes; to have arcenals in ≈øeverall parts, and not all in one place; and not to leave any town or ca≈øtle (except your fortre≈ø≈øes of garri≈øon) ≈øo ≈øtrong as to be able to endure 100 cannon-bullets. There is a la≈øt means, whereof the ancients made a profitable u≈øe, and is now wholly left, which I do marvellou≈øly approve of; which is, to e≈øtabli≈øh colonies, and to tran≈øport the people from one countrey to another. For be≈øides that it is a great bridle to keep a conquered countrey in aw, you recompen≈øe by this means the nearer part of tho≈øe ≈øouldiers which have done you good ≈øervice. And I find not the rea≈øon to be ≈øufficient which ≈øome alledge, that it is cruelty to make this permutation, and that it is again≈øt charity; but to the contrary I find indeed tho≈øe remedies to be cruel which are commonly u≈øed, to keep the people ≈øo under as they have nothing but their life, and cannot hope for any honour within their own countrey. For my ≈øelf I profe≈ø≈øe freely, that I had rather be driven out of my countrey into another, where I ≈øhould have a hope for my ≈øelf and mine to be able to attein to
≈øomething more then now I am, then to remain in mine own countrey to be deprived of that hope; finding nothing to be ≈øo hard as to take away hope from a man, which is that which in this world, and for the goods of this world, maketh him undertake all things; and which for the goods of the other world furni≈øheth him with con≈øtancy to ≈øuffer all things: Moreover, there is nothing which di≈øtingui≈øheth a man ≈øo much from a bea≈øt, nor yet a regenerate man from a ≈øen≈øuall, as hope. Which maketh me conclude, that you ≈øhould never take from a man the hope of being able to obtein a better condition then that which he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth, that ≈øo he be not ca≈øt into de≈øpair.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. How you mu≈øt proceed to relieve your allie and confederate.
div.p:
ONe of the mo≈øt honourable actions which a Prince doth, and which bringeth him mo≈øt reputation, is to ≈øuccour his allies in their nece≈ø≈øities: but it is a thing which for the mo≈øt part is very difficult. When you will make war, you choo≈øe your advantages, and you take your time and your mea≈øures according to that which you can and will do: it is not ≈øo in the ≈øuccouring of your allie, which mu≈øt be a≈ø≈øi≈øted with ≈øuch difficulties and di≈øcommodities as you meet with. If his countrey be joyned to yours, and that nothing hindreth you from a≈ø≈øi≈øting him with all your forces united, you cannot excu≈øe the not doing of it, unle≈ø≈øe it be that you fear his enemy, and would not offend him; which is an unmanly and no judicious rea≈øon. For by this excu≈øe
you e≈øcape not the danger which your neighbours lo≈ø≈øe will draw upon you. It being much better for you to re≈øi≈øt joyntly, then ≈øuffer your ≈øelves to be undone one after another. But if it be an allie ≈øeparated from you by other Princes and States (which ofttimes ≈øo hapneth) and that you meet with great difficulties to get into his countrey, you mu≈øt then well con≈øider after what manner you ≈øhould ≈øuccour him: for if the States which are between you both refu≈øe you pa≈ø≈øage, and that you mu≈øt be enforced to give them battel before you be able to a≈ø≈øi≈øt your allie, it is to be feared that you ≈øhall not be able to ≈øuccour him timely enough. And if your neighbour, either for fear of you, or of him which a≈ø≈øaileth your allie, do offer you pa≈ø≈øage, you cannot accept thereof with ≈øafety, unle≈ø≈øe he put you in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe places which are nece≈ø≈øary to a≈ø≈øure your return; which being refu≈øed you, you mu≈øt go no further. But if the enemy of your ally hath territories near you, and ≈øuch as you may ea≈øily a≈ø≈øail; you mu≈øt do it ≈øtoutly; and that ≈øuccour which can be given by diver≈øion is (in my opinion) the ≈øure≈øt and that which ≈øucceedeth be≈øt; becau≈øe you do it with all your forces and conveniences, and ordinarily that countrey which you a≈ø≈øail is not well provided, becau≈øe he which a≈ø≈øaileth another State leadeth out with him the be≈øt Captains and ≈øouldiers which he hath. But if you want all the≈øe means, there is no other left but that of money, wherewith you may a≈ø≈øi≈øt him; which ofttimes is not ≈øufficient to ≈øave him.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Which is best, whether a great Prince make warre in per≈øon, or by his Lieutenant.
div.p:
IT is to the purpo≈øe in this place to treat whether a Prince ought to manage his warre ‚Ä¢ in per≈øon or by Lieutenants: for that the practice thereof being different, every man bringeth his be≈øt rea≈øons to maintein his opinion. They which di≈øapprove of his doing it in per≈øon alledge, that by going out of his territories he openeth the doore for di≈øorders, and robbeth him≈øelf of the means to prevent them; that it is more nece≈ø≈øary for him to keep peace within then to make war abroad, for which nothing can do ≈øo much good as his pre≈øence, which keepeth in aw the mo≈øt ≈øtirring ≈øpirits; that holding them which are within in obedience he may give the better order to his affairs abroad; that there befall greater inconveniences and le≈ø≈øe remediable, when the Prince is ingaged in per≈øon out of his countrey, then when he is within it; that if he ≈øhall receive ≈øome check in his per≈øon being farre from his owne territories, tho≈øe bu≈øie heads are more daring to make innovations, every man emancipateth him≈øelf and ≈øhaketh off his obedience; if he be ≈ølain there, his ≈øubjects are affrighted, and his enemie is encouraged by it, and thence draweth great advantages; if he be taken, that is ≈øtill wor≈øe; for none being able to declare him≈øelf Prince, and the great ones, de≈øiring to make their benefit of his calamity, put all affairs into ≈øuch a confu≈øion that nothing is done in the State with authoritie, becau≈øe they which ≈øei≈øe upon the government tyrannize over the other great
ones which might pretend the ≈øame, which ofttimes love rather to call in the common enemy then to obey their fellows. Whereunto they adde, that a Prince cannot free him≈øelf without giving great advantages to his enemy, which turn to a notable and irremediable prejudice both to him≈øelf and his State: So that all things being balanced, they conclude that the inconveniences are much greater of hazarding the per≈øon of the Prince in the warres then to cau≈øe them to be managed by his Lieutenants. This opinion is principally mainteined by men of the gown, naturall enemies to ≈øouldiers; who for that they can better pre≈øerve their authoritie in peace then war, do not onely di≈ø≈øwade from going in per≈øon to the warre, but even do advi≈øe the ≈øuffering of all ≈øorts of ignominy rather then to make war. Whereunto flatterers, panders, and all the plagues of Princes do adhere, which entertein them within their countrey in a lazine≈ø≈øe wch bringeth them to all ≈øorts of luxurie, making them believe that their States are but made for them, and not they for their States; that the taking of a maidenhead is more honourable then the conque≈øt of a Province; that there belongeth more indu≈øtry and trouble to the well-ordering of a fea≈øt then of a battel; that labour is not appointed but onely for porters; and that great Kings ≈øhould cau≈øe all things to be acted without moving them≈øelves: which is the u≈øuall way of the lo≈ø≈øe of kingdomes and empires. They which coun≈øel a Prince to make warre in per≈øon, alledge that the command of an army is a mor≈øell ≈øo delicious that it ought not to be imparted to others without great nece≈ø≈øitie: for that to acquit
a mans ≈øelf well in ≈øuch a charge, he mu≈øt be very ab≈øolute; and ofttimes the Generall of an army doth not contein him≈øelf within his dutie, e≈øpecially when the Prince performeth not his own. For in this ca≈øe he is naturally envious of the glory of another, and cannot ≈øupport the good actions of his Lieutenant, though they tend to his own profit. In which humour they do entertein him which govern the affairs at court, with this fear, lea≈øt that an eminent vertue ≈øhould ≈øupplant them. And from hence proceedeth the infelicitie of the mo≈øt part of brave de≈øignes, how well ≈øoever undertaken, which are made to peri≈øh either for want of money or of victuall, or by re≈øtraining the authority of the Generall, or by putting officers upon him which oppo≈øe him, and which prove rather ≈øhackles to him then a≈ø≈øi≈øtants: and when affairs have not ≈øucceeded as men imagined, the fault is ca≈øt upon him which is innocent, and the blameworthy triumph: and thus great Princes ≈øhal be ≈øerved which make war by their Lieutenants: That the reputation of a Prince who is a good commander him≈øelf is much greater then a Princes which hath good commanders: that the fir≈øt is feared for his own worth, and the other onely through others: that the fir≈øt cannot betray him≈øelf, but that the commanders of the other may be corrupted: that the fir≈øt can make choice of ≈øuch as are fit for warre, and the other hath no good commanders but by hazard: that the authoritie of the one is not ≈øo envied nor cro≈ø≈øed, ≈øeeing he is ma≈øter, and is to give account of his actions to no man; but that the Generall of the army of another is ≈øubject to a perpetuall jealou≈øie,
and thrice happy is he that e≈øcapeth it: that the means to prevent civil warres is to imploy the mo≈øt ≈øtirring and courageous ≈øpirits in forrein warres, where they ≈øhall find wherewith to ≈øatisfie their ambitions; as al≈øo to be alwayes armed, becau≈øe that will cool tho≈øe which are hotte≈øt: and that the Prince be at the head of his army, that ≈øo none may u≈øe it again≈øt him. They alledge further, that never Prince hath founded a great Empire, but by making warre in per≈øon; nor hath lo≈øt any, but when he made warre by his Lieutenants. It is now left to the choice of Princes what is to be done upon the≈øe two advi≈øes. If he be a drone, which contenteth him≈øelf to be admired by his grooms, which taketh no delight but in voluptuou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and which leaveth off the acting of the part of a King to act that of a ≈øcoundrel, he will never take that coun≈øel to command his armies him≈øelf. If he be a wi≈øe Prince, which loveth tranquillitie to maintein his people in ju≈øtice, neverthele≈ø≈øe he will not omit to be prepared for warre, and to inform him≈øelf therein, that ≈øo when occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve he need not commit the command of his armies to others. But if he be a generous Prince which hunteth after glory, and de≈øireth to imitate tho≈øe great men which live ≈øtill 2000 years after their death, and who≈øe venerable names at this day do honor tho≈øe which mention them, he will doubtle≈ø≈øe choo≈øe for his principall imployment that of war; wherein he will endevour to make him≈øelf expert, that ≈øo he need not depend upon others for the leading of his armies, and will make that his chief delight. And this is the true plea≈øure which contenteth the
≈øpirit, which is particular to man, and common to great men: for corporall plea≈øure hath more of the bea≈øt then of man; and ≈øo he that wholly addicteth him≈øelf thereunto is wor≈øe then a brute bea≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of reputation.
div.p:
IT is a thing which cannot be conceived, how available the reputation of a Generall of an armie is; and how hard it is to be pre≈øerved. For after that you have acquired the e≈øtimation of being a wi≈øe man, and of great managing, if you will con≈øerve it by prudence, men will ≈øay you are become a coward; and if by hazarding ≈øome battel you receive a check, they will hold you to be ra≈øh. So that there is no function in the world more ≈øubject to blame then that of a Generall of an arm ‚Ä¢ ; and very happy is that commander which keepeth his reputation entire untill the the end. Neverthele≈ø≈øe ≈øo long as it la≈øteth it worketh marvellous effects: for when he hath gotten the name of being pro≈øperous in war, the ≈øouldiers believe that he cannot be beaten; and go upon his word ≈øo ≈øecurely to the combat, as they take no more knowledge of the danger; per≈øwading them≈øelves that he never commandeth them to fight, but that he is a≈ø≈øured of the victory: which doth ≈øo encourage them as they fight with much the more re≈øolution. Moreover, the enemies meeting with ≈øuch a man, fight not but in fear, as being a≈ø≈øured to be beaten. There be a thou≈øand of ancient and modern examples of this truth. When the army of Alcibiades (even when he was ab≈øent) was beaten, the Athenians
believed that it was with his con≈øent. The one
‚Ä¢ y report of the arrivall of Ce≈øar and Alexander, how≈øoever but with ≈ømall forces, hath oftentimes cau≈øed the yielding of provinces and the defeat of armies. The ≈øole reputation of Henry the fourth, who was taken notice of in the combat of Fontaine Francoi≈øe, arriving there the day before in po≈øt, made the Spaniards abandon Burgundy. I have ob≈øerved the Dauphinois to have this belief, that the Con≈øtable le De≈ødiguires could not be beaten. But as this opinion is of great profit to a Generall of an army when he hath atteined it, ≈øo to be thought unluckie in warre is a great hindrance to him: for it is impo≈ø≈øible for him to a≈ø≈øure him≈øelf on tho≈øe ≈øouldiers which have ≈øuch an opinion of their Commander. Therefore a Generall of an army mu≈øt make it his principall aim to begin well; then not to omit any thing for the pre≈øerving of what he hath gotten: re≈øolving rather to die gloriou≈øly in ≈øome great action then to linger out a ≈øhamefull life after that he hath committed ≈øome unmanly act. For as the profe≈ø≈øion of war is that of all others which conferreth mo≈øt honour upon a man which therein acquitteth him≈øelf well, ≈øo it draweth the greate≈øt infamy upon him that demeaneth him≈øelf ill.
